administrator or his designated representative shall either approve or
disapprove each application for issuance of a license within thirty (30) days
after the completed application is filed with the village.
   B.   Appeal: In the event that the village administrator or his designated
representative disapproves an application or fails to take any action on an
application within the thirty (30) day period, the applicant shall have the
right to appeal to the mayor and board of trustees at the next regularly
scheduled board meeting. The mayor and board of trustees shall have the right
to review the application and approve or deny issuance of the applied for
license. (1976 Code §9-63)
   C.   Revocation Of License: The village administrator, or his designated
representative, may revoke any license issued by the village if it is
determined that the licensee has violated any provision of this article.
However, no such license shall be so revoked except after a public hearing by
the village administrator, or his designated representative, upon a three (3)
day prior written notice to the licensee affording said licensee an opportunity
to appear and defend. (1991 Code)
The village administrator or his designated representative shall, within three
(3) days after the conclusion of such hearing, decide whether the license shall
be revoked. If he determines that the license should be revoked, he shall state
the reason or reasons for such determination in a written order of revocation
and shall serve a copy of such order upon the licensee within three (3) days
thereafter. (1976 Code §9-63)
3-4B-7: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
   B.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   C.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of the raffle. (1976 Code §9-64)
   D.   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on
the license and winning chances may be determined only at those times and at
those locations specified on the license.
   E.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his parent or guardian. (1976 Code §9-64; amd. Ord. 2010-39, 8-
19-2010)
3-4B-8: RAFFLES MANAGER; BOND:
All operation of and conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a
single raffles manager designated by the organization making application for a
license. The manager shall give a fidelity bond in an amount not less than the
anticipated gross receipts for each raffle. The bond shall be in favor of the
organization and conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties.
Terms of the bond shall also provide that notice be given in writing to the
village of Woodridge not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation.
The village administrator or his designated representative is authorized to
waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in the license
issued; provided, that a license containing such waiver provision shall be
granted only by unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization.
(1976 Code §9-65)
3-4B-9: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Records Kept:
      1.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the
purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount
and date of payment.
      2.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization
pursuant to license thereof issued by the department of revenue of the state of
Illinois, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have
separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same
person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.
      3.   Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3)
years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to
operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places.
   B.   Reports Required: Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall
report monthly to its membership and to the village its gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from the raffles, and the distribution of net
proceeds itemized as required by this section. (Ord. 82-4, §1)
3-4B-10: PENALTY:
Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this article shall be
subject to the penalties contained in sections
1-4-1 and
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 82-4, §1; amd. Ord. 84-52, §17)
ARTICLE C. AMUSEMENT ATTRACTIONS, AMUSEMENT RIDES, CARNIVALS AND FAIRS
SECTION:
3-4C-1: Definitions
3-4C-2: License Required; Special Events Permit
3-4C-3: State Of Illinois Permit Required
3-4C-4: Application For License
3-4C-5: Compliance With Zoning Regulations
3-4C-6: Insurance Required
3-4C-7: Conditions Of License
3-4C-8: Denial Of Entry To Amusement Ride Or Attraction
3-4C-9: Violation And Penalty
3-4C-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them herein:
AMUSEMENT ATTRACTION: An enclosed building or structure, including electrical
equipment which is an integral part of the building or structure, through which
people walk without aid of any moving device, that provides amusement, thrills
or excitement at a fair or carnival, and which includes amusement rides.
AMUSEMENT RIDE: Any mechanized device or combination of devices, including
electrical equipment which is an integral part of the device or devices, which
carries passengers along, around or over a fixed or restricted course for the
primary purpose of giving its passengers amusement, pleasure, thrills or
excitement.
CARNIVAL: An enterprise which offers amusement or entertainment to the public
by means of one or more amusement attractions or amusement rides.
FAIR: An enterprise principally devoted to the exhibition of products or
agriculture or industry in connection with which amusement rides or amusement
attractions are operated.
OPERATOR: A person, or the agent of a person, who owns or controls or has the
duty to control the operation of an amusement ride or an amusement attraction
at a carnival or fair. Operator includes an agent of the state or any of its
political subdivisions. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
3-4C-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; SPECIAL EVENTS PERMIT:
No person shall conduct or operate any amusement attraction, amusement ride,
carnival or fair without first having obtained a license therefor pursuant to
this article. Furthermore, no person shall conduct or operate any amusement
attraction, amusement ride, carnival or fair that is deemed to be a "special
event" as defined in section
3-4D-1 of this chapter without first having obtained a special events permit
pursuant to article D of this chapter. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007)
3-4C-3: STATE OF ILLINOIS PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate any amusement attraction, amusement ride,
carnival or fair without a valid and current state of Illinois permit issued by
the Illinois department of labor pursuant to 1992, 430 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 85/2-1 et seq. Such permit to operate shall be posted in full public
view on or near the amusement attraction, amusement ride, carnival or fair. If
an amusement attraction, amusement ride, carnival and fair undergoes a
substantial alteration or is repaired after a breakdown, it shall be
reinspected or approved for use by the director of the Illinois department of
labor. All such amusement attractions, amusement rides, carnivals or fairs
governed by this article must be assembled, operated and disassembled in
accordance with the provisions of the state of Illinois carnival and amusement
rides safety act. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
3-4C-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Not more than three (3) licenses hereunder shall be issued by the
village, per calendar year. All applications for a license hereunder shall be
in writing to the village clerk, which shall contain such information as the
village may require and shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of
chapter 1 of this title.
   B.   The license fee for each "amusement attraction", "amusement ride",
"carnival" or "fair" as herein defined shall be set forth in subsection
3-1A-3C2 of this title. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
3-4C-5: COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING REGULATIONS:
Any person conducting or operating any amusement attraction, amusement ride,
carnival or fair shall do so in accordance with all regulations contained in
the building code and zoning ordinance, titles 8 and 9 of this code and all
applicable state and federal laws. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
3-4C-6: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Any person conducting or operating an amusement ride, amusement attraction,
carnival or fair shall furnish evidence to the village clerk that public
liability insurance policy or policies in an aggregate amount of not less than
one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury to or death of one
person in any one accident, and subject to the limit for one person, in an
amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury
to or death of two (2) or more persons in any one accident, and in an amount of
not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injury to or destruction
of property of others in any one accident, insuring the operator against
liability for injury or death suffered by a person attending an amusement ride,
amusement attraction, carnival or fair. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
3-4C-7: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Public Safety: All village community development and police department
personnel shall have free access at all times to any amusement attraction,
amusement ride, carnival or fair for the purpose of maintaining the peace and
inspecting the site to ensure public safety as provided by 430 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 85/2-17. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994; amd. Ord. 2010-29, 5-20-
2010)
   B.   Concessions And Food Dispensing Facilities: All concessions and food
dispensing facilities shall be maintained in a safe, clean condition at all
times and be in accordance with applicable ordinances of the village and DuPage
County. Any and all permits issued by the DuPage County health department shall
be posted in full public view at the food service operation and shall be
obtained prior to commencement of such operation.
   C.   Location Restriction: Except for vehicular parking, no portion of a
carnival, exhibition, show or other amusement which takes place in whole or in
part outdoors shall be located less than two hundred feet (200') from the
nearest lot line of a lot in residential use. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
3-4C-8: DENIAL OF ENTRY TO AMUSEMENT RIDE OR ATTRACTION:
The owner or operator of an amusement ride or amusement attraction may deny
entry to a person to an amusement ride or amusement attraction if, in the
owner's or operator's opinion, the entry may jeopardize the safety of such
person or the safety of any other person. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
3-4C-9: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provisions of this article.
Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this article shall be
subject to the penalties contained in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 94-51, 7-28-1994)
ARTICLE D. SPECIAL EVENTS
SECTION:
3-4D-1: Definitions
3-4D-2: Permit Required; Exceptions
3-4D-3: Permit Application
3-4D-4: Review And Issuance Of Permit
3-4D-5: Conditions Of Permit
3-4D-6: Denial Or Revocation Of Permit
3-4D-7: Violation And Penalty
3-4D-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them herein:
FARM STAND: A designated area with one booth where, on designated days and
times, a grower or producer may sell directly to the public in accordance with
village regulations.
FARMERS' MARKET: A designated area with a minimum of two (2) or more booths
where, on designated days and times, growers, producers, and crafters may sell
directly to the public, in accordance with village regulations.
SPECIAL EVENT: Any outdoor temporary event which is held on village owned
property, including streets and sidewalks, or which is held on nonvillage owned
property and significantly impacts the village. Events which significantly
impact the village shall include, but are not limited to, those that include
any of the following:
   A.   Street closures or the posting of "No Parking, Tow Zone" signs.
   B.   Support services provided by the village of Woodridge police or public
works departments or by the fire protection district.
   C.   Closures of required parking facilities or portions thereof.
   D.   The preparation and/or sale of food or drink or alcoholic beverages.
   E.   Fireworks.
   F.   Live music, recorded music, and/or the use of amplifiers.
   G.   The use of tents or canopies larger than three hundred (300) square
feet.
   H.   Gatherings of more than fifty (50) people.
   I.   Farmers' market/farm stand.
   J.   Holiday tree sales.
Examples of special events include, but are not limited to, street dances, car
wash fundraising events, carnivals, circuses, Woodridge Jubilee, Cultural Fest,
marathons, parades, "cruise nights" vehicle exhibitions, Fourth Of July
fireworks, outdoor concerts and/or musical events, and tent sales. (Ord. 2007-
35, 6-7-2007; amd. Ord. 2013-53, 10-24-2013)
3-4D-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
No person or organization shall conduct, participate in, aid, form or start any
special event in the village prior to obtaining a special event permit from the
village administrator of the village or his or her designee.
The provisions of this article shall not apply to:
   A.   Block parties.
   B.   Neighborhood parades.
   C.   Private events on single-family residential lots.
   D.   Events held in a permanent outdoor structure or facility specifically
designed for that event. Examples of permanent outdoor structures or facilities
include, but are not limited to, aquatic parks, sports fields, playgrounds, and
picnic shelters.
   E.   Corporate groundbreaking, grand opening and ribbon cutting ceremonies.
(Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007)
3-4D-3: PERMIT APPLICATION:
   A.   The person or persons in charge of or in control of a special event
shall submit an application for a special event permit to the village
administrator of the village or his or her designee, on forms provided by the
village administrator or designee, at least sixty (60) days prior to the event.
The village administrator or designee may deny the permit if it is determined
that there is insufficient time to review the application.
   B.   At the discretion of the village administrator or designee, special
events that are proposed to occur more than once a year in substantially the
same manner may be approved under a single permit application.
   C.   The application for the special event permit shall include the
following information, as applicable:
      1.   The name, address, and telephone number of the person(s) or
organization(s) seeking to conduct the special event.
      2.   The name, address and telephone number of the person(s) who will be
in charge during the event and who will be responsible for its conduct.
      3.   An original letter of authorization from the owner(s) of the
property where the special event is to occur, authorizing the use of the
property for the event.
      4.   The description and purpose of the event.
      5.   The location of the event.
      6.   A site layout plan for the event and/or a map of the route to be
traveled.
      7.   The date(s) when the event is to be conducted, the desired starting
time and anticipated duration.
      8.   The anticipated number of attendees, and whether the event is open
to the general public or limited to a specific group.
      9.   A written description of the planned role and responsibilities of
volunteers, if any.
      10.   A written description and map of the traffic control and parking
plan.
      11.   An emergency response plan for weather, medical and other
emergencies, which shall include, but not be limited to, an early warning
system, a communications plan, an evacuation plan, shelter locations, first aid
center, and provision for emergency medical staff.
      12.   An event security and safety plan.
      13.   A postevent cleanup plan.
      14.   A resident/business notification plan.
      15.   A lighting plan.
      16.   A sound control plan.
      17.   A description of any proposed food, drink or alcoholic beverage
preparation or sales.
      18.   A written explanation of requested village services, if any
(traffic control, installation of crowd control fencing, setting up street
barriers, etc.) and executed reimbursement agreement in a form provided by the
village administrator or designee.
      19.   Completed applications for other applicable permits and/or licenses
including, but not limited to, tents, electrical hookups, raffles, and liquor
licenses, whether required by the village, county, or any other regulatory
agency.
      20.   An executed hold harmless agreement in a form provided by the
village administrator or designee.
      21.   Evidence of public liability insurance in an amount determined
appropriate by the village administrator or designee. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007)
      22.   As part of the application to permit a farmers' market or farm
stand an applicant shall submit documentation showing (as opposed to merely
stating) that it will comply with the following standards:
         a.   Eligible products for sale include sale articles for human
consumption, such as fruits, vegetables, edible grains, nuts and berries,
apiary products, maple sugars, syrups, eggs, cheese products, sausage, or
nonedible articles such as cut or potted flowers, or arts and crafts which
articles have been raised, prepared, or assembled by the grower, producer, or
crafter by members of their family or by persons in their employ. All articles
offered for sale by the grower or producer must be grown or processed in the
state of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan or Wisconsin. Sale of any type of meat,
fish or poultry and refrigerated dairy products or any article proscribed by
the county health department, with the exception of those products specifically
permitted to be sold under this article, shall be prohibited. The sale of eggs,
cheese products and sausage shall be permitted only if proper refrigeration is
provided.
         b.   All farmers' markets or farm stands and their vendor(s) comply
with all federal, state and local laws relating to the operation, use and
enjoyment of the market premises.
         c.   On site presence of a market/stand manager during all hours of
operation who shall direct the operations of all vendors participating in the
market/stand and verify that the requisite number of individual booth(s) are
operated by grower or producers.
         d.   Assignment of booth(s) and registration of grower or producers.
         e.   An established set of operating rules addressing the governance
structure of the market/stand, hours of operation, maintenance, security
requirements, and the appointment of a market/stand manager.
         f.   Provision for recycling and waste removal in accordance with all
applicable codes. All farmers' markets/farm stands and their vendors receive
all required operating and health permits and these permits (or copies) shall
be in the possession of the farmers' market/farm stand operator or the vendor,
as applicable, on the site of the farmers' market/farm stand during all hours
of operation.
         g.   Each vendor is responsible for collecting his/her own sales
taxes, where it is applicable.
         h.   Hours of operation shall be during a window between seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. but in no event may a market or stand
operate more than three (3) days per week and for more than six (6) hours per
day. Setup of market operations shall begin no earlier than six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. and takedown shall end no later than ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
      23.   Any additional information which the village administrator or
designee shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether
a special event permit should be issued. (Ord. 2013-53, 10-24-2013)
3-4D-4: REVIEW AND ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
Within twenty one (21) days after the receipt of a complete application, the
village administrator, or designee, shall review the application and shall
either issue a special event permit or provide written notice to the applicant
stating the reasons why a special event permit cannot be issued. (Ord. 2007-35,
6-7-2007)
3-4D-5: CONDITIONS OF PERMIT:
All special event permits shall be subject to the following conditions as
deemed applicable by the village administrator or designee:
   A.   The applicant shall provide written notification to adjacent residents
and businesses at least two (2) weeks in advance of any proposed street and/or
parking lot closures.
   B.   The special event shall maintain an appropriate setback from adjacent
properties as deemed appropriate by the village administrator or designee in
order to minimize the impact on surrounding land uses. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007)
   C.   Restroom facilities as deemed appropriate by the building commissioner
shall be provided for events longer than two (2) hours in duration. (Ord. 2007-
35, 6-7-2007; amd. Ord. 2010-29, 5-20-2010)
   D.   The applicant or his designee shall provide for the prompt disposal of
refuse generated by the special event. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007)
   E.   All village community development and police department personnel shall
have free access at all times to the special event for the purpose of
maintaining the peace and inspecting the site to ensure public health, safety
and welfare. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007; amd. Ord. 2010-29, 5-20-2010)
   F.   The chief of police or his designee shall have the authority, but not
the obligation, to terminate a special event in the event of an emergency or
severe weather or in order to preserve the public health, safety and welfare.
   G.   All special events shall comply with all applicable local, state, and
federal government laws and regulations.
   H.   The village administrator or designee reserves the right to make
changes to the proposed event based on availability of services and scheduling
of other events.
   I.   Any other conditions as deemed necessary by the village administrator
or designee to protect the public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-
7-2007)
3-4D-6: DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The village administrator or designee shall have the authority to deny an
application for a special event permit or revoke a permit issued hereunder upon
noncompliance with the standards for issuance as herein set forth, including,
but not limited to, the following:
   A.   The applicant has failed to provide all necessary information.
   B.   The applicant has provided false information.
   C.   The application does not comply with all local, state and federal
governmental laws and regulations.
   D.   The applicant has a history of violating local, state or federal
governmental laws or regulations.
   E.   The proposed special event would adversely affect public health, safety
or welfare.
   F.   The applicant has outstanding fines, fees or monies owed to the
village.
   G.   The permit was issued in error.
   H.   The application was submitted less than sixty (60) days in advance of
the event. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007)
3-4D-7: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this article.
Any person found to be in violation of any provisions of this article shall be
subject to the penalties contained in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2007-35, 6-7-2007)
ARTICLE E. VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
3-4E-1: Definitions
3-4E-2: Video Gaming Allowed
3-4E-2-1: Sweepstakes Machines Prohibited
3-4E-3: Annual Video Gaming License Required
3-4E-4: Application For License
3-4E-5: Term Of License
3-4E-6: Annual License Fee; Proration
3-4E-7: Conditions Of License
3-4E-8: Violations And Penalty
3-4E-9: License Required For Video Gaming Terminal Operators
3-4E-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meaning
ascribed to them herein:
LICENSED ESTABLISHMENT: Any licensed retail establishment where alcoholic
liquor is drawn, poured, mixed or otherwise served for consumption on the
premises. The term licensed establishment includes any licensed fraternal
establishment and/or licensed veterans establishment as those terms are defined
in the Video Gaming Act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., as
amended ("Video Gaming Act").
TERMINAL OPERATOR: Any individual, partnership, corporation, or limited
liability company that is licensed under the Video Gaming Act and that owns,
services, and maintains video gaming terminals for placement in licensed
establishments, licensed truck stop establishments, licensed large truck stop
establishments, licensed fraternal establishments, or licensed veterans
establishments.
VIDEO GAMING: The ownership, placement, maintenance, operation or use of a
"video gaming terminal" (as defined herein) in a "licensed establishment" (as
defined herein) within the Village.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine, that upon insertion
of cash, electronic cards or vouchers, or any combination thereof, is available
to play or simulate the play of a video game, including, but not limited to,
video poker, line up and blackjack, as authorized by the Illinois Gaming Board,
utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which the player may receive
free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does not include
a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash or tokens or is for amusement
purposes only. (Ord. 2016-23, 6-2-2016; amd. Ord. 2020-10, 3-5-2020)
3-4E-2: VIDEO GAMING ALLOWED:
Video gaming is allowed in certain licensed establishments within the Village
only in accordance with this article. Subject to all other provisions of this
article, video gaming shall only be permitted and a video gaming license issued
to a licensed establishment that is the holder of a Class A-1, A-3, or E-
1 liquor license, where meals shall be actually and regularly prepared on the
premises and served in accordance with either a general or specialized menu.
Adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment shall be provided and
maintained. The licensed premises shall have a minimum "total floor area" of
two thousand (2,000) square feet as that term is defined in chapter 1 of this
title. Further, subject to all other provisions of this article, video gaming
shall only be permitted and a video gaming license issued to a licensed
establishment that, in addition to being the holder of a Class A-1, A-3, or E-
1 liquor license, has been issued a supplemental Class VG liquor license. (Ord.
2016-28, 7-21-2016)
3-4E-2-1: SWEEPSTAKES MACHINES PROHIBITED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to own, lease or operate any sweepstakes machine,
as herein defined, in any place of public resort within the Village.
   B.   For purposes of this section, "sweepstakes machines" shall be defined
as any standalone, table top, or similar mechanically, electrically or
electronically operated device in which, upon payment, a participant is
automatically entered into a sweepstakes or similar promotion wherein the
participant has the option to reveal the results of entry into said sweepstakes
or promotion via a display mimicking slot machines, poker, keno, bingo, or any
form of a printed ticket or otherwise, for cash or merchandise as a prize. Any
such device shall be considered a sweepstakes machine regardless of whether a
coupon for a product or service is provided in exchange for the payment.
   C.   Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as prohibiting
video gaming terminals as otherwise authorized by this Code. (Ord. 2019-3, 2-
21-2019)
3-4E-3: ANNUAL VIDEO GAMING LICENSE REQUIRED:
Except as otherwise provided herein, no establishment shall be permitted to
operate any video gaming terminal pursuant to the Illinois Video Gaming Act
unless the establishment has first obtained a license and paid an annual
license fee to the Village as hereafter provided, and has been licensed by the
Illinois Gaming Board. No license may issue where the license applicant owes a
debt, fine, fee or penalty to the Village. No establishment is eligible to
obtain a State license until they have successfully obtained a Village license.
In the event that an existing qualified licensed establishment sells said
establishment to another entity, the new establishment will be considered for
licensure following the approval and submittal of a valid State license. (Ord.
2017-63, 10-19-2017; amd. Ord. 2020-15, 8-6-2020)
3-4E-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application to the Village for a video gaming license shall be made in
conformity with chapter 1 of this title, except as otherwise provided herein.
The application shall in addition set forth:
   A.   The location within the premises, as shown on a floor plan, where the
video gaming terminal(s) is to be located, maintained and/or operated;
   B.   Attach a responsible gaming policy, which outlines all employee
education and training programs, policies, and procedures to promote
responsible gaming. If standardized training for responsible gaming becomes
available at a future date, it shall be required as part of the video gaming
license application;
   C.   Such other information as the Village may determine is necessary as set
forth in the application form. (Ord. 2017-63, 10-19-2017)
3-4E-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
All licenses shall be valid for period not to exceed one (1) year after
issuance, unless sooner terminated, revoked or suspended as provided by law;
and all licenses shall terminate on April 30 next following their issuance. If
an establishment is unable to obtain a State license within one (1) year of the
issuance of a Village license, the Village license will be revoked. If an
establishment does obtain a State license and fails to activate any terminal
within one (1) year of State issuance, the Village license will not be renewed.
(Ord. 2017-63, 10-19-2017; amd. Ord. 2020-10, 3-5-2020)
3-4E-6: ANNUAL LICENSE FEE; PRORATION:
The annual business license fee for a video gaming license shall be as follows:
   Five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for
each video gaming terminal.
License fees are payable at the time of application and are not subject to
proration and are not refundable. (Ord. 2016-23, 6-2-2016)
3-4E-7: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
All such video gaming terminals shall at all times be kept, placed, operated,
and monitored in accordance with State laws and applicable regulations, as well
as all applicable provisions of this Code including, but not limited to:
   A.   Prohibiting persons under the age of twenty one (21) years and persons
who are visibly intoxicated from entering or remaining in the gaming area, and
posting signage thereof.
   B.   Video gaming terminals shall be placed in an area restricted to
individuals age twenty one (21) or over. If individuals under the age of twenty
one (21) are allowed in any portion of the licensed premises, the establishment
shall limit visibility of video gaming terminals from outside the gaming area
in which they are located.
   C.   The operation of video gaming terminals shall only be allowed during
the legal hours of operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages
at the licensed establishment. Upon the suspension or revocation of a
licensee's liquor license, the licensee's video gaming license shall
automatically be suspended (or revoked in the event of a liquor license
revocation) without the requirement of any further action by the Village.
   D.   The video gaming area shall be physically monitored at all times during
the legal hours of operation by an employee over twenty one (21) years of age.
   E.   In addition to subsection D of this section, there shall be installed
camera surveillance of the video gaming area, with equipment that has the
ability to record and may be accessed by the Police Department upon request to
investigate a suspected violation of this Code, any law or administrative code,
or any unlawful activity.
   F.   Required signage pursuant to State laws, regulations and Village
ordinances shall be posted at all times in the establishment's video gaming
area. (Ord. 2016-23, 6-2-2016)
3-4E-8: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this article.
Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this article shall be
subject to the penalties contained in section
1-4-1 of this Code. In addition, any and all licenses issued to the licensee
shall be subject to suspension or revocation as provided in this Code or by
law. (Ord. 2016-23, 6-2-2016)
3-4E-9: LICENSE REQUIRED FOR VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL OPERATORS:
   A.   No terminal operator or any person shall distribute, sell, lease out,
establish or supply any video gaming terminal in the Village without first
obtaining a terminal operator's license from the local liquor control
commission of the Village pursuant to this chapter.
   B.   Each terminal operator is required to apply for licensure by completing
a form as approved by the local liquor commissioner and provided by the
Village. If the applicant is a partnership, all partners shall sign the
application. If the applicant is a corporation or club, the president and
secretary of the applicant business entity shall sign the application. If the
applicant is a limited liability company, the managers of the limited liability
company shall sign the application. If the members of the limited liability
company do not elect managers, the application shall be signed by the members
with interest representing the majority of the book value of the membership
interest unless the articles of organization or operating agreement otherwise
provide the manner in which members or managers may bind a limited liability
company. Each application shall contain at the least the following information
and statements:
      1.   The applicant's name, birthdate, social security number, driver's
license number, address, position and percentage of ownership in the business;
and the name, birthdate, social security number, driver's license number,
address, position and percentage of ownership in the business of every sole
owner, partner, corporate officer, director, manager of a limited liability
company, manager and any person or member of the limited liability company who
owns five percent (5%) or more of the shares of the applicant business entity
or parent corporations of the applicant business entry. The articles of
incorporation for any corporation shall be attached to the application.
      2.   A list of all premises in the Village and number of video gaming
terminals at each premises the terminal operator owns, has sold, leased out,
supplied or delivered for which a terminal operator's license is being sought.
      3.   The number of video gaming terminals for which permission is sought
under the license.
      4.   A copy of the terminal operator license from the State of Illinois.
      5.   Such other information required by the local liquor commission to
determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
   C.   Each terminal operator licensed under this chapter shall maintain a
current list of all premises in the Village, in which the terminal operator
owns, has sold, leased out, supplied or delivered any video gaming terminal.
Such list shall be available for inspection by the village clerk or his or her
designee, on demand, during normal business hours.
   D.   No terminal operator or any other person shall own, sell, lease out,
supply or deliver any video gaming terminal to any premises within the Village
unless the owner or lessee of the premises shall also have applied for and
obtained a current valid Village license for the video gaming terminal.
   E.   Every terminal operator that is licensed to distribute, sell, lease
out, establish or supply any video gaming terminal in the Village pursuant to
this chapter shall pay a yearly license fee to the Village in the amount of one
thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($1,250.00) for each video gaming terminal
distributed, sold, leased out, established or supplied in the Village.
   F.   Failure or neglect to pay the requisite fees in a timely manner shall
be cause for denial of issuance or non-renewal or revocation as the case may
be.
   G.   All terminal operator's licenses shall follow the term of license as
defined in 3-4E-5.
   H.   It shall be a prerequisite to any terminal operator's license from the
Village that the person distributing video gaming terminals have a valid
license from the State of Illinois as a terminal operator of video gaming
terminals. A loss or suspension of any such license by the State of Illinois
shall automatically result in the same status for the license issued hereunder,
without refund of any license fee.
   I.   It shall be noted that no terminal operator licenses issued may be
transferred to any other licensed establishment or terminal operator, as
defined herein.
   J.   Changes In Licensee:
      1.   Any changes in partnership, officers, directors, or persons holding
directly or beneficially more than five percent (5%) of the stock or ownership
interest, or managers of establishments licensed under this chapter, shall be
reported in writing to the local liquor control commissioner within ten (10)
days of the change. All new personnel shall meet all of the standards of this
chapter and must otherwise qualify to hold a liquor license. In addition, an
investigation fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) must be submitted.
      2.   When a license has been issued for a partnership and a change of
ownership occurs resulting in a partnership interest by one who is not eligible
to hold a terminal operator license, said license shall terminate.
      3.   When a license has been issued to a corporation and a change takes
place in officers, directors, managers or shareholders of more than five
percent (5%) of the stock resulting in the holding of such office, position or
such shares of stock by one who is not eligible for a license, said license
shall terminate.
      4.   When a license has been issued to an individual who is no longer
eligible for a license, said license shall terminate. (Ord. 2020-10, 3-5-2020)
CHAPTER 5
PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
ARTICLE A. PEDDLERS
SECTION:
3-5A-1: Definitions
3-5A-2: License Required
3-5A-3: Application For License
3-5A-4: License Fee
3-5A-5: Issuance Or Denial Of License
3-5A-6: Duty Of Peddlers
3-5A-7: Uninvited Peddling Prohibited
3-5A-8: Time Limit And Distance Restrictions On Peddling
3-5A-9: Conditions Of License; Prohibitions
3-5A-10: Revocation Of License; Appeal
3-5A-11: Records Kept
3-5A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words as used in this article shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them unless a different meaning is required by the
context:
FOOD TRUCK: A readily movable, motorized wheeled vehicle, or a towed wheeled
vehicle, designed and equipped to serve food and which has obtained all
required state and local licenses for the operation of said food truck.
PEDDLER: Any person engaged in the act of peddling.
PEDDLING: The act of traveling by foot, motor vehicle or any other type of
conveyance, from place to place, from house to house or from street to street
carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares or merchandise, offering and
exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to
purchasers or, without traveling from place to place, the selling or offering
for sale of goods, wares or merchandise from a motor vehicle or other type of
conveyance. Peddling shall not include "charitable solicitation" by "charitable
organizations" as those terms are defined in section
3-5B-1 of this chapter. Charitable solicitation shall be governed by the
provisions of article B of this chapter. Peddling shall also include the
operations of licensed food trucks as defined herein. (Ord. 84-59, §1; amd.
Ord. 2015-11, 3-5-2015)
3-5A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling within the corporate
limits of the village without first having obtained a license from the village
as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
3-5A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license to engage in peddling shall be made upon a form
provided by the village. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the
information requested on the application as follows: (Ord. 84-59, §1)
   A.   The name, social security number, date of birth and address of the
applicant. (Ord. 94-32, 5-12-1994)
   B.   An address within the state where service of process may be had.
   C.   The age and physical description of each applicant.
   D.   The name and address of any person, corporation or organization by whom
the applicant is employed or represents and the length of time of such
employment or representation.
   E.   A description sufficient for identification of the goods, wares or
merchandise being peddled.
   F.   The date or approximate date of the latest previous application for a
license under this article, if any.
   G.   Whether a license issued to the applicant under this article has ever
been revoked.
   H.   Whether the applicant has been convicted of a violation of any
provision of this article or the ordinances of any other Illinois municipality
regulating peddling.
   I.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a
felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or of a
federal law of the United States.
   J.   If a vehicle is to be used, a description of said vehicle, together
with the license registration number and the driver's license number of the
applicant. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
   K.   Any application for a peddler's license for food vending shall be
accompanied by a current certificate of inspection from the DuPage County
health department. No such license shall be issued unless such certificate is
supplied. In addition a certificate of inspection from the United States
department of agriculture and/or the Illinois department of agriculture shall
be submitted when any such food is beef, poultry or pork and a shellfish tag
from the Illinois department of public health shall be submitted when any such
food is seafood and such seafood is shellfish. (Ord. 94-32, 5-12-1994)
3-5A-4: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a license required pursuant to this article shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per applicant. Said fee shall be paid at the time of
application and prior to the processing of said application. (Ord. 2009-37, 8-
6-2009; amd. Ord. 2024-52, 11-21-2024)
3-5A-5: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
All applications for a license to engage in peddling shall be submitted to the
village clerk and shall be verified under oath. The village clerk shall
acknowledge receipt of such application in writing within five (5) working days
of such receipt. The village clerk shall act upon said applications within ten
(10) days after its receipt. If the village clerk finds and determines that all
of the requirements of this article have been met, the village clerk shall
issue said license forthwith. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
The failure of an applicant to fulfill the requirements of this article shall
be the basis for the denial of a license by the village clerk. In addition, no
license to engage in peddling shall be issued to any person who has been
convicted of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other
state, or under the federal laws of the United States within five (5) years of
the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a sex
offense as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes, act 5, article 11, or any
equivalent law of any other state within five (5) years of the date of the
application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any
provision of this article; nor to any person whose license issued hereunder has
previously been revoked as herein provided. In the event that any license to
engage in peddling is denied for failure to comply with the requirements set
forth hereinabove, the village clerk shall immediately notify the applicant in
writing of the reasons for the denial. If said application is not cured within
ten (10) days after the date on which the village clerk denies the issuance of
said license, said application shall be null and void. (Ord. 94-32, 5-12-1994)
3-5A-6: DUTY OF PEDDLERS:
It shall be the duty of every peddler, upon going onto any premises in the
village, to first examine the notice provided for in section
3-5B-6 of this chapter, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement
contained on the notice. For the purposes of this section, the word
"solicitors" shall be deemed to include the word "peddlers". If the notice
states ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN WOODRIDGE INVITED, then a peddler not
possessing a valid license as herein provided shall immediately and peacefully
depart from the premises; if the notice states NO SOLICITORS INVITED, then the
peddler, whether licensed or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from
the premises.
Any peddler who has gained entrance to any premises, whether invited or not,
shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do
so by the occupant. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
3-5A-7: UNINVITED PEDDLING PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any
person to remain upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door
or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of
the owner or occupant of such premises for the purpose of securing an audience
with the owner or occupant thereof and engage in "peddling" as herein defined
in defiance of the notice exhibited at the premises in accordance with the
provisions of section
3-5B-6 of this chapter as applied to peddlers by section
3-5A-6 of this article. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
3-5A-8: TIME LIMIT AND DISTANCE RESTRICTIONS ON PEDDLING:
   A.   No person shall engage in "peddling" as herein defined prior to nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after five o'clock (5:00) P.M. of any day; provided,
that no person shall engage in peddling at any time on a Sunday or any state or
national holiday. Notwithstanding any provision contained herein to the
contrary, no person shall engage in the operation of a food truck prior to
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. or after ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. of any day and
persons engaged in the delivery of milk products on a regularly scheduled route
may make deliveries after six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on all regularly scheduled
delivery days.
   B.   No peddler shall peddle within five hundred feet (500') of the property
line of any elementary or secondary school. (Ord. 2015-11, 3-5-2015)
3-5A-9: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE; PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Items For Sale: It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any
goods, wares or merchandise other than those specified in the application.
   B.   Fraud: No person shall misrepresent his name, occupation, financial
condition, social condition or residence, and no person shall make or
perpetrate any other misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any
peddling activity or in any application filed under this article.
   C.   Loud Noises; Sound Amplification: No licensee or anyone in his behalf
shall shout, make any outcry, blow any horn, ring a bell or use any other sound
device including any loudspeaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the
streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the village or upon any
private property in the village, where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or
produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, alleys,
parks or other public places, or upon any private premises, for the purpose of
attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which said licensee is
offering for sale. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
   D.   Felons And Persons Convicted Of Sex Offenses As Peddlers: It shall be
unlawful for any person to be a peddler who has been convicted of a felony
under the laws of the state of Illinois, or any equivalent law of any other
state, or under the federal laws of the United States, within five (5) years of
the date of the application. It shall be unlawful for any person to be a
peddler who has been convicted of a sex offense as defined by 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes, act 5, article 11, or any equivalent law of any other state,
within five (5) years of the date of application.
   E.   Governmental Permits: It shall be unlawful to engage in peddling of any
beef, poultry, pork or seafood for human consumption in the village unless
applicant can produce evidence that any such beef, poultry, pork or seafood has
been inspected or tagged by the state and/or federal government and is safe for
human consumption. (Ord. 94-32, 5-12-1994)
3-5A-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE; APPEAL:
The village clerk shall revoke a license for violation of any of the
regulations listed in sections
3-5A-6 through
3-5A-9 of this article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice
thereof shall be given by the village clerk to the holder of the license,
either personally or by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested.
Upon receipt of said notice of revocation, all peddling activity shall cease.
Any person aggrieved by said revocation shall have the right to appeal and have
a hearing before the mayor and board of trustees. Such appeal shall be taken by
filing with the village clerk a written statement under oath setting forth
specifically the grounds for appeal. The mayor and board of trustees shall
thereupon set the time and a place for the hearing on such appeal, and notice
of such hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided
in section
3-1-14 of this title. The decision of the mayor and board of trustees on such
appeal shall be by a vote of a majority of all members then holding office and
shall be final. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
3-5A-11: RECORDS KEPT:
The village clerk shall cause to be kept in her office an accurate record of
every application received and acted upon together with all other information
and data pertaining thereto, all licenses issued under the provisions of this
article and a record of the denial of any and all applications. Applications
for licenses shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every license
issued and any renewal thereof shall be identified with the duplicate number of
the applications upon which it was issued. (Ord. 84-59, §1)
ARTICLE B. SOLICITORS
SECTION:
3-5B-1: Definitions
3-5B-2: Charitable Solicitation; Registration
3-5B-3: Commercial Solicitation; Registration
3-5B-4: Registration Fee
3-5B-5: Reserved
3-5B-6: Notice Regulating Soliciting
3-5B-7: Duty Of Solicitors
3-5B-8: Uninvited Soliciting Prohibited
3-5B-9: Time Limit For Soliciting
3-5B-10: Prohibitions
3-5B-11: Additional Regulations For Charitable Solicitations
3-5B-12: Reserved
3-5B-13: Records Kept
3-5B-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases as used in this article shall have the
following meanings, unless a different meaning is required by the context:
CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS: Any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, not for
profit, religious or eleemosynary person or one purporting to be such which
solicits and collects funds for charitable purposes.
CHARITABLE PURPOSE: Any charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, not
for profit, religious or eleemosynary purpose.
CHARITABLE SOLICITATION: Any request for the donation of money, property or
anything of value, or the pledge of a future donation of money, property or
anything of value; or the selling or offering for sale of any property, real or
personal, tangible or intangible, whether of value or not, including, but not
limited to, goods, books, pamphlets, tickets, publications or subscriptions to
publications or brochures, upon the representation, express or implied, that
the proceeds of such sale will be used for a "charitable purpose" as such term
is herein defined.
COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION: Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods,
wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description
whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; seeking to obtain
subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, etc.
PERSON: Any individual, organization, group, association, partnership,
corporation, trust or any combination thereof.
SOLICITATION: Any "charitable solicitation" or "commercial solicitation", as
those terms are defined herein.
SOLICITOR: Any person who engages in "charitable solicitation" or "commercial
solicitation", as those terms are defined herein. (Ord. 82-10, §1; amd. Ord.
2004-34, 6-17-2004)
3-5B-2: CHARITABLE SOLICITATION; REGISTRATION:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any charitable organization to engage in
charitable solicitation within the corporate limits of the village unless such
organization has registered with the village as hereinafter provided.
   B.   Any charitable organization engaging in charitable solicitation within
the corporate limits of the village shall register the following information
with the village clerk:
      1.   The name and address of the charitable organization and the name or
names under which it intends to engage in solicitation.
      2.   The names and addresses of all persons who will engage in charitable
solicitation in the village.
      3.   The dates and time of day such solicitations are to be made and the
geographic areas within the village wherein such solicitation shall be
conducted at a particular time and day.
      4.   A written statement of recent date issued by the attorney general of
Illinois that the charitable organization has complied with the provisions of
225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/1 et seq., or a written statement by the
attorney general of exemption under 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/3. (Ord.
2004-34, 6-17-2004)
3-5B-3: COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION; REGISTRATION:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in commercial
solicitation within the corporate limits of the village unless such person
shall have first obtained a certificate of registration from the village as
hereinafter provided.
   B.   Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form
provided by the village. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the
following information and submit the following documentation:
      1.   The name and address of the person who intends to engage in
solicitation.
      2.   The name and address of the person or organization by whom the
applicant is employed or represents, and the length of time of such employment
or representation.
      3.   The name and address of the person in charge of solicitation in the
village and an address within the state of Illinois where service of process
may be had.
      4.   Applicant shall submit his or her driver's license number, social
security number and date of birth, as well as a physical description of
applicant.
      5.   The dates and time of day such solicitation is to be made and the
geographic area within the village wherein such solicitation shall be conducted
at a particular time and day.
      6.   The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application
for a certificate under this article, if any.
      7.   Whether a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under
this article has ever been revoked.
      8.   Whether the applicant has been convicted of a violation of any of
the provisions of this article or the ordinances of any other Illinois
municipality regulating solicitation.
      9.   A description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of
the solicitation which the applicant will engage in.
      10.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of
a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or of a
law of the United States.
   C.   An application for a certificate of registration shall be submitted to
the village clerk and shall be verified under oath. The village clerk shall
acknowledge receipt of such application in writing within five (5) working days
of such receipt and shall act upon such application within ten (10) days after
its receipt. No application shall be effective until acted upon by the village
clerk. If the village clerk finds and determines that all the requirements of
this article have been met, the village clerk shall issue said certificate
forthwith.
   D.   The failure of an applicant to fulfill the requirements of this article
shall be a basis for the denial of a certificate of registration by the village
clerk. In addition, no certificate of registration shall be issued to any
person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the state of
Illinois or any other state or under the laws of the United States within five
(5) years of the date of the application; nor to any person who has been
convicted of a sex offense as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes, act 5,
article 11 or any other equivalent law of any other state, within five (5)
years of the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted
of a violation of any of the provisions of this article; nor to any person
whose certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked
as herein provided. In the event that any certificate of registration is denied
for failure to comply with the requirements set forth hereinabove, the village
clerk shall immediately notify the applicant, in writing, of the reasons for
denial. If said application is not cured within ten (10) days after the date on
which the village clerk denies the issuance of said certificate of
registration, said application shall be null and void.
   E.   The village clerk shall revoke a certificate of registration for a
violation of any of the regulations listed in sections
3-5B-6 through
3-5B-10 of this article, inclusive. Immediately upon such revocation, written
notice thereof shall be given by the village clerk to the holder of the
certificate by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. Upon
receipt of said notice of revocation, all solicitation activity shall cease.
Any person aggrieved by said decision shall have the right to appeal and have a
hearing before the mayor and board of trustees. Such appeal shall be taken by
filing with the village clerk within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice
of revocation, a written statement under oath setting forth specifically the
grounds for appeal. The mayor and board of trustees shall thereupon set the
time and a place for the hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing
shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in section
3-1-14 of this title. The decision of the mayor and board of trustees on such
appeal shall be by a vote of a majority of all members then holding office and
shall be final. (Ord. 2004-34, 6-17-2004)
3-5B-4: REGISTRATION FEE:
The fee for a certificate of registration required to engage in commercial
solicitation pursuant to this article shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per applicant. Said fee shall be paid at the time of application and prior to
the processing of said application. (Ord. 2009-37, 8-6-2009; amd. Ord. 2024-52,
11-21-2024)
3-5B-5: RESERVED:
(Ord. 2004-34, 6-17-2004)
3-5B-6: NOTICE REGULATING SOLICITING:
Any person owning or occupying any premises within the village may post a
notice indicating whether or not solicitors are invited at said premises. Any
such notice shall be given in the following manner:
A weatherproof card approximately three inches by four inches (3" x 4") in size
shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the premises
indicating the determination made by the owner or occupant, containing the
applicable words, as follows:
ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN WOODRIDGE INVITED
Or
NO SOLICITORS INVITED.
The letters shall be at least one-third inch (1/3") in height. For the purpose
of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the chief of the police
department to persons requesting same, at cost.
Such cards so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of
the determination by the owner or occupant of the premises of the information
contained thereon. (Ord. 82-10, §1)
3-5B-7: DUTY OF SOLICITORS:
It shall be the duty of every solicitor, upon going onto any premises in the
village, to first examine the notice provided for in section
3-5B-6 of this article, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement
contained on the notice. If the notice states: "ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN
WOODRIDGE INVITED", then the solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of
registration as herein provided shall immediately and peacefully depart from
the premises; if the notice states: "NO SOLICITORS INVITED", then the
solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart
from the premises. (Ord. 82-10, §1)
3-5B-8: UNINVITED SOLICITING PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any
person to remain upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door,
or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of
the owner or occupant of such premises for the purpose of securing an audience
with the owner or occupant thereof, and engage in "solicitation" as herein
defined in defiance of the notice exhibited at the premises in accordance with
the provisions of section
3-5B-6 of this article.
Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any premises, whether invited or not,
shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do
so by the occupant. (Ord. 82-10, §1)
3-5B-9: TIME LIMIT FOR SOLICITING:
   A.   No person shall engage in "solicitation" as herein defined prior to
nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. of any day and
provided further that no person shall engage in commercial solicitation prior
to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after five o'clock (5:00) P.M. of any day and
that no person shall engage in commercial solicitation at any time on a Sunday
or any state or national holiday.
   B.   No commercial solicitor shall solicit within five hundred feet (500')
of the property line of any elementary or secondary school. (Ord. 94-32, 5-12-
1994)
3-5B-10: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Felons And Persons Convicted Of Sex Offenses As Solicitors: It shall be
unlawful for any person to be a solicitor who has been convicted of a felony
under the laws of the state of Illinois, or any equivalent law of any other
state, or under the federal laws of the United States, within five (5) years of
the date of application. It shall be unlawful for any person to be a solicitor
who has been convicted of a sex offense as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes, act 5 article 11, or any equivalent law of any other state, within
five (5) years of the date of application. (Ord. 94-32, 5-12-1994)
   B.   Fraud: No person shall misrepresent his name, occupation, financial
condition, social condition or residence, and no person shall make or
perpetrate any other misstatement, deception or fraud, in connection with any
charitable or commercial solicitation, or in any application or report filed
under this article. (Ord. 82-10, §1)
3-5B-11: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS FOR CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS:
   A.   Financial Disclosure Required: The charitable organization shall
distribute to every person solicited a financial statement of said charitable
organization for the preceding twelve (12) months which shall include a balance
sheet and statement of income and expenses clearly setting forth the following:
gross receipts and gross income from all sources broken down into total
receipts and income from each separate solicitation project or source; cost of
administration; cost of solicitation; cost of programs designed to inform or
educate the public; funds or properties transferred out of the state of
Illinois, with explanation as to recipient and purpose; total net income amount
for each major purpose, charitable or otherwise. Statements shall be signed by
the president or other authorized officer or agent and shall be accompanied by
an opinion signed by an independent certified public accountant that said
financial statement fairly represents the financial operation of the charitable
organization.
A copy of the annual report to the attorney general of Illinois required by 225
Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/4, as amended, may be presented in lieu of the
aforementioned financial statement. For the purpose of financial statements,
the definitions and standards applicable to the annual report to the attorney
general as set forth in paragraph 460/4 shall be utilized.
In the event a charitable organization has not been established for a period of
twelve (12) months, a copy of the registration statement filed with the
attorney general of Illinois pursuant to 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/2,
as amended, may be utilized. (Ord. 82-10, §1)
   B.   Solicitation Of Charitable Contributions On Highways: Solicitation of
charitable contributions on highways within the village shall be permitted;
provided, however, that all such activity shall be conducted in strict
conformity with and shall be limited to that activity permitted under the
provisions of the Illinois vehicle code paragraph 5/11-1006(c) 1  and this
code. (Ord. 80-6, §2)
In order to, on an ongoing basis, evaluate the safety of solicitors and the
safety of motorists, and to otherwise provide for the orderly flow of traffic,
the village may authorize charitable solicitation on highways to take place
during such times as the village may approve, notwithstanding any time
limitations set forth in section
3-5B-9 of this article to the contrary. (Ord. 2011-17, 4-28-2011)

3-5B-13: RECORDS KEPT:
The village clerk shall cause to be kept in her office an accurate record of
every application received and acted upon together with all other information
and data pertaining thereto, all certificates of registration issued under the
provisions of this article, and a record of the denial of any and all

issued. (Ord. 82-10, §1)
CHAPTER 6
FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Licensing Requirements
3-6-2: Garbage Removal Required
3-6-1: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
The Village Clerk shall not issue any license or permit to a retail food
establishment unless the applicant has in his possession evidence of a valid
license or permit from the County Board of Health issued to said retail food
establishment. It shall be a prerequisite to the continuance to the expiration
date of the license or permit issued by the Village that the licensee of said
retail food establishment continues to hold a valid license or permit from the
County Board of Health during the term of the license or permit issued to said
retail food establishment by the Village. (1976 Code §9-8)
3-6-2: GARBAGE REMOVAL REQUIRED:
Every person owning or controlling any hotel, restaurant, cafe or retail food
establishment where more than thirty two (32) gallons of refuse is normally
produced weekly shall cause all garbage to be placed in sanitary refuse
containers and shall cause all substances deposited in such containers to be
removed daily from his premises and to be disposed of at his own expense. 1
(1976 Code §8-88)

CHAPTER 7
BUS SERVICE
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions
3-7-2: License Required; Exceptions
3-7-3: Application for License
3-7-4: License Fees; Vehicle Tags
3-7-5: Investigation of Applicant; Issuance of License
3-7-6: Insurance Requirements
3-7-7: Bus Service Operation
3-7-8: Bus Routes
3-7-9: Right of Village to Maintain Public Ways
3-7-10: Vehicle Inspections
3-7-11: Suspension or Revocation of License
3-7-12: Police Power of Village
3-7-13: Nonliability of Village
3-7-14: Penalty
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following terms are used in this Chapter, they shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows:
BUS: Every motor vehicle, other than a commuter van, designed for carrying more
than ten (10) passengers and used for the transportation of persons, and every
motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation
of persons for compensation.
COMMUTER VAN: A motor vehicle designed for the transportation of not less than
twelve (12) nor more than sixteen (16) passengers when such transportation is
incidental to another purpose of the driver who is not engaged in the
transportation of persons as a business, and providing further that such motor
vehicle is owned, leased for or by a company or an employee organization and
operated on a nonprofit basis with the primary purpose of transporting
employees of the company between the employees' homes and the company's place
of business or a public transportation station and in which the operating,
administrative, maintenance and reasonable depreciation costs are paid
principally by the persons utilizing the commuter van.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, partnership or corporation.
SCHOOL BUS: Every motor vehicle, except as provided in the following paragraph,
owned or operated by or for any of the following entities for the
transportation of persons regularly enrolled in any such entity as students in
grade twelve (12) or below in connection with any activity of the entity. A
school operated by a religious institution or a public or private nursery,
primary or secondary school.
This definition does not include the following:
   A.   A bus operated by a public utility, Municipal corporation or common
carrier authorized to conduct local or interurban transportation of persons
when the bus is on a regularly scheduled route for the transportation of other
fare-paying persons or furnishing charter service for the transportation of
groups on field trips or other special trips, or in connection with special
events or for shuttle service between attendance centers or other educational
facilities and not over a regular or customary scheduled school bus route;
   B.   A motor vehicle of the first division as defined by 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes, 5/1-171.01.
TRANSPORTATION OF PERSONS: Any service in connection with the receipt, carriage
and delivery of the person transported and his baggage, and all facilities used
or necessary to be used in connection with the safety, comfort and convenience
of the person transported. (1976 Code §6-1)
3-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of operating a scheduled bus
service for the transportation of persons within the corporate limits of the
Village without first having secured a license therefor.
Notwithstanding any language contained in this Section to the contrary, no
license shall be required for the following:
   A.   The business of operating a scheduled school bus service within the
corporate limits of the Village.
   B.   The business of operating a scheduled bus service for the
transportation of persons within the corporate limits of the Village, where
such bus service is otherwise being regulated by the Illinois Commerce
Commission and/or the Interstate Commerce Commission. (1976 Code §6-2)
3-7-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for all licenses to operate a bus service for the transportation
of persons shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk. Each application
shall contain:
   A.   Name and address of applicant.
      1.   If applicant is a partnership, list names and addresses of all
partners.
      2.   If applicant is a corporation, give the names and addresses of the
registered agent and all officers, directors and stockholders.
      3.   If applicant is a wholly owned subsidiary of another partnership or
corporation, give the information listed in either paragraph 1 or 2 above for
the parent partnership or corporation.
   B.   A list of names and addresses of all governmental units and all
agencies or authorities organized thereunder that license and/or franchise the
applicant for the operation of a bus service for the transportation of persons.
   C.   A brief summary of the qualifications the applicant feels qualify him
for a license to operate a bus service for the transportation of persons.
   D.   A copy of the applicant's most recent financial statements, including,
but not limited to, balance sheet, profit and loss statement and statement of
changes in financial condition, for the most recent fiscal year available.
   E.   A listing of fares, routes, schedules and the location of all proposed
boarding locations and stops under which the applicant proposes to operate.
   F.   A list of the type of equipment which the applicant proposes to utilize
during the term of the license, which shall consist of such full and complete
description or information as the Clerk may require.
Each application shall contain such additional information as may be needed for
the proper guidance of the Village officials in the issuing of the license. All
applications shall be signed by the applicant or his duly authorized
representative and verified by oath or affidavit. (1976 Code §6-3)
3-7-4: LICENSE FEES; VEHICLE TAGS:
The annual fee, payable in advance, for such licenses shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) plus twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each bus operated.
Whenever the number of buses so operated shall be increased during the license
year, the licensee shall notify the Clerk of such change and shall pay the
additional fee, prorated, for the balance of the license year.
Such fee shall be in lieu of any other vehicle fee required by this Code and
the Village Clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number of buses
covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in the right
front windshield on each bus while it is in use.
The licensee shall notify the Clerk of the motor number and State license
number of each bus operated and of the corresponding Village tag or sticker
number. (1976 Code §6-4)
3-7-5: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Upon the receipt of an application for a license to engage in the business of
operating a bus service for the transportation of persons, the Chief of Police
may cause such investigation or inspections to be made in conformance with
subsections
3-1-5A and B and Section
3-1-6 of this Code, as the Chief of Police shall deem necessary or appropriate.
(1976 Code §6-5)
All licenses shall be issued in conformance with subsections
3-1-5A and B and Section
3-1-6 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-6)
3-7-6: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
Any licensee operating a bus transportation service under this Chapter shall
indemnify, protect and save harmless the Village, its officers, employees and
agents, from and against liability, losses, physical damage to property and
bodily injury or death to persons, including payments made under any workmen's
compensation law, which may arise out of the licensee's operation of its bus
transportation service within or without the limits of the Village. Each
licensee shall further indemnify and hold harmless the Village from and against
any liability or losses sustained as a direct or indirect result of the action
of the licensee's agents or employees or in any way arising out of the granting
of this license. Each licensee shall carry insurance in an insurance company
approved by the Village, said insurance company having a best reporting service
of AAA or better, said insurance to be utilized to protect the licensee and the
Village as their interest may appear from and against all claims, demands,
actions, judgments, costs, expenses and liabilities including, without
limitation, attorney's fees which may arise or result directly or indirectly
from or by reason of any such liability, loss, injury or damage. In addition,
each licensee shall secure said indemnity by obtaining contract insurance. Said
insurance policy shall be in sufficient funds to insure licensee and the
Village, and in any event, said insurance shall be sufficient to insure against
liability to persons and property (including insurance against personal injury,
loss of life and loss of or destruction of property) in the case of each
vehicle operated by a licensee or used in providing the services in an amount
not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per person; one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; and umbrella liability
insurance coverage of not less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00). Said
policy shall contain a provision requiring the insured to notify the Village
not less than ten (10) days prior to cancellation or change of any policy. The
Village, its officers, officials, agents and employees shall appear as
additional named insureds under each policy. Within ten (10) days after the
date thereof, licensee shall provide the Village with certificates of insurance
for each policy. Each licensee shall also carry such insurance as may be
necessary to protect it and the Village from all claims under the workmen's
compensation laws in effect that may be applicable to the licensee. All
insurance required by this Chapter shall be and remain in full force and effect
for the entire period of any license. The policies of insurance, or a certified
copy or copies thereof, shall be approved by the Village legal counsel of the
Village and shall be deposited with and kept on file by the Village Clerk.
(1976 Code §6-14)
3-7-7: BUS SERVICE OPERATION:
   A.   Regulation of Operators: No person shall operate any bus unless such
person has a valid Illinois drivers license with a proper classification to
permit the operation of such vehicle. (1976 Code §6-10)
   B.   Location of Stops: 1  The location of all bus stops shall be subject to
regulation and approval by the Chief of Police. (1976 Code §6-9)
   C.   Exemption from Certain Traffic Regulations: Unless otherwise provided
by the Village, operations conducted under the provisions of this Chapter shall
be exempt from compliance with Village vehicle or axle weight restrictions on
Village streets. 2  However, each operator of licensee's vehicle shall observe
all speed restrictions and other traffic regulations imposed by the Village,
the Counties of DuPage and/or Will and the State of Illinois regulating traffic
on any street or highway within the Village. 3  (1976 Code §6-11; 1991 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  6-5-6-1A of this Code.
2 2. See Section
  6-8A-4 of this Code.
3 3. See Title 6 of this Code for traffic regulations.
3-7-8: BUS ROUTES:
