7-5A-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
ADMINISTRATOR: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
APPLICANT: Any person who makes application for connection or extension to the
system.
APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method, or type of
construction intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system. All
devices used for approved backflow prevention devices in Illinois must meet the
standards of the Illinois plumbing code, the Illinois environmental protection
agency and the requirements herein.
APPROVED CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL DEVICES OR METHODS: Backflow prevention
devices or methods of installation approved by the mayor and board of trustees.
Such approved devices or methods shall include those as described in the "List
Of Approved Backflow Prevention Assemblies", dated August 7, 1987, published by
the Foundation For Cross-Connection Control And Hydraulic Research, University
Of Southern California, devices which are set forth in the American Waterworks
Association standard for backflow prevention devices - reduced pressure
principle and double check valve types AWWA C506-78 (R83) reaffirmed without
revision January 30, 1983.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to the
premises other than the public water supply system and includes the water
supplied by the system. These auxiliary waters may include water from another
purveyor's public water supply system; or water from a source such as wells,
lakes, or streams, or process fluids; or used water. These waters may be
polluted or contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or
system over which the water purveyor does not have control.
BOD (DENOTING BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): The quantity of oxygen utilized in
the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure
in five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in milligrams
per liter.
BACK SIPHONAGE: The flowing back of used contaminated or polluted water due to
a negative gauge or subatmospheric pressure in that pipe.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the
distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the
intended source of the potable water supply.
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which
receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the
walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved
point of discharge, beginning five feet (5') (1.5 meters) outside the inner
face of the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer
(including the connection) or other place of disposal.
CCCDI (CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL DEVICE INSPECTOR): A person who is a licensed
plumber in the state of Illinois and has successfully completed both written
and performance examinations administered by the IEPA, as described in IEPA
regulations, 35 Illinois administrative code 653.802, or an IEPA certified
public water supply operator who has successfully completed both written and
performance examinations administered by the IEPA as described in the IEPA
regulations, 35 Illinois administrative code 653.802.
COMBINED SEWER: A sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater,
storm, surface and ground water drainage.
COMMERCIAL USER: Includes transit loading, retail and wholesale establishments
or places engaged in selling merchandise or rendering services.
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The person in whose name the water service is registered
with the village and shall include the occupant, owner of record, contract
purchaser, lessee or anyone else in control of the premises.
CONSUMER'S OR CUSTOMER'S WATER SYSTEM: Any water system serving the premises,
commencing at the outlet side of the service pipe shutoff valve location and
shall include the fitting for such service pipe.
CONTAMINATION: The introduction into water of any substance to a degree which
could create a health hazard or make the water unfit for its intended use.
COUNTY DIRECTOR: The director of public works, DuPage County.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any actual or potential connection through which a supply of
potable water could be contaminated or polluted.
DEPARTMENT: The department of public works of the village.
DIRECTOR: The director of public works of the village of Woodridge.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly composed of single, independently
acting check valves approved under ASSE standard 1015, including shutoff valves
which inhibit all water flow located at each end of the assembly and suitable
connections for testing the watertightness of each check valve.
DRAIN: Any pipe that carries wastewater or waterborne wastes in a building
drainage system.
DUPAGE COUNTY AGREEMENT: That certain agreement entered into by and between the
village and the county of DuPage, Illinois, wherein said county has or will
acquire the sewage treatment facility known as the Woodridge plant.
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
EFFLUENT CRITERIA: Defined in any applicable "NPDES permit".
EXTENSION: A sanitary sewer main or water main installed by a private person or
persons, firm, association, corporation or partnership for the purpose of
extending the original sanitary sewer mains or water mains of the village or
the sewer mains or water mains of the village which have been extended from
time to time.
FEDERAL ACT: The federal clean water act (33 USC 466 et seq.), as amended (Pub.
L. 95-217).
FEDERAL GRANT: The U.S. government participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided for by title II - grants for the
construction of treatment works of the act and implementing regulations.
FIXED AIR GAP: The unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere
between the water discharge point and the flood level rim of the receptacle.
FIXTURE, PLUMBING: Installed receptacles, devices or appliances supplied with
water or that receive or discharge liquids for liquidborne wastes.
FLOATABLE OIL: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will
separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment
facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is
properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection
system.
FLOOD LEVEL RIM: The edge of the receptacle from which water overflows.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food and from the handling, storage and sale of food.
HAZARD, PLUMBING: Any arrangement of plumbing, including piping and fixtures,
whereby a cross connection is created.
HEALTH HAZARD: Any condition, device or practice in a water system or its
operation resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well
being of customers. The word "severe" as used to qualify "health hazard" means
a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in death or
significant reduction in the quality of life.
HOUSE CONNECTION: A sewer line or pipe extending from the public sewer located
in the right of way or easement to the house or building to be served.
HOUSE SERVICE: That part of the water service extending from the curb stop and
buffalo box to the house or building to be served.
HYDROPNEUMATIC TANK: A pressure vessel in which air pressure acts upon the
surface of the water contained within the vessel, pressurizing the water
distribution piping connected to the vessel.
INDUSTRIAL USERS: Includes establishments engaged in manufacturing activities
involving the mechanical or chemical transformation of materials of substance
into products.
INDUSTRIAL WASTE: Any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted
to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business
establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any
natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage.
INSPECTION: A plumbing inspection to examine carefully and critically all
materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of
plumbing system for compliance with requirements of the Illinois plumbing code,
77 Illinois administrative code 890.
INSTITUTIONAL/GOVERNMENTAL USER: Includes schools, hospitals, churches, penal
institutions and users associated with federal, state and local governments.
MILLIGRAMS PER LITER: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater
constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters
(1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per
million to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of
water and wastewater analysis.
MUNICIPALITY: The village of Woodridge, DuPage, Will and Cook Counties,
Illinois.
NPDES PERMIT: Any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the
administrator or, where appropriate by the director, after enactment of the
federal clean water act, to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to
section 402 of the federal act.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body
of surface or ground water.
NONPOTABLE WATER: Water not safe for drinking, personal or culinary use as
determined by the requirements of 35 Illinois administrative code 604.
NONRESIDENTIAL PREMISES: A customer's premises which are not intended as a
dwelling unit.
OUTLET: The open end of the water supply pipe through which the water is
discharged into the plumbing fixture.
PPM: Parts per million by weight.
PERSON: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual,
firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society,
institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration
expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA division of
laboratories manual of laboratory methods.
PLUMBER, LICENSED: A plumber licensed and certified by the state of Illinois to
do plumbing work.
PLUMBING: The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension
of a plumbing system by any person. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures,
appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes, including,
without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of a private water
supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to,
within and about any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work
or assemble. Plumbing includes all piping, from discharge of pumping units to
and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. Plumbing includes all
piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for a building drain and a
sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building or buildings
where a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection
of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage disposal system
up to and including the connection to the main sewer line.
POLLUTION: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic,
radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as
to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water.
POPULATION EQUIVALENT: A term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or
other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is one
hundred (100) gallons of sewage per day containing two hundred twenty
milligrams per liter (220 mg/l) of BOD and two hundred forty milligrams per
liter (240 mg/l) of suspended solids.
POTABLE WATER: Water which meets the requirements of 35 Illinois administrative
code 604 for drinking, culinary and domestic purposes.
POTENTIAL CROSS CONNECTION: A fixture or other connection which would extend
the customer's water systems supply line beyond its legal termination point
through which the supply of potable water could be contaminated or polluted.
PRETREATMENT: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction
into the wastewater treatment works.
PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM: Any arrangement of devices or structures used
for the treating of sewage on private property.
PROCESS FLUID(S): Any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically
or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would
constitute a health, pollution or system hazard if introduced into the public
or a customer's potable water system. This includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   Polluted or contaminated water.
   B.   Process waters.
   C.   Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality.
   D.   Cooling waters.
   E.   Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes,
streams or irrigation systems.
   F.   Chemicals in solution or suspension.
   G.   Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in
industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") (1.27 cm) in any
dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the
village. It shall also include sewers within or outside the village boundaries
that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the village
sanitary sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed
with village funds.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM: All mains, pipes and structures owned and/or
maintained by the village through which water is obtained and distributed to
the public, including wells and well structures, intakes and cribs, pumping
stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances,
collectively or separately, actually used or intended for use for the purpose
of furnishing potable water.
REASONABLE NOTICE: The time interval in which the director of public works, in
the exercise of standard engineering practice, finds it acceptable to order a
water customer to correct an unprotected cross connection with due
consideration for the potable water supply system as a whole and any oral
notice being followed by written notice.
REDUCED PRESSURE ZONE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE (RPZ): A device
containing a minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves together with
an automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between
the two (2) check valves. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal
flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks shall be less than the supply
pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential release
valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure
between the check valves at less than the supply pressure. The unit must
include shutoff valves which totally inhibit all water flow, located at each
end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly located test
cocks.
RESIDENTIAL DWELLING: A customer's premises which is intended for use as a
dwelling unit.
RESIDENTIAL USER: All dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes, apartments
and permanent multi-family dwellings.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a
combination of both and into which storm, surface and ground waters or polluted
industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The physical connection to the water main including all
fittings and appurtenances, through which water is supplied to the customer.
SEWAGE: Used interchangeably with "wastewater".
SEWER: A pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids
including storm, surface and ground water drainage.
SEWERAGE: The system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection,
transportation and pumping of sewage.
SLUG: Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration
of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of
duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average
twenty four (24) hour concentration of flows during normal operation.
STATE ACT: The Illinois antipollution bond act of 1970 1 .
STATE GRANT: The state of Illinois participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois antipollution
bond act 2  and for making such grants as filed with the secretary of state of
the state of Illinois.
STORM SEWER: A sewer that carries storm, surface and ground water drainage but
excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water.
STORMWATER RUNOFF: That portion of precipitation that is drained into the
sewers.
SURGE TANK: The receiving, nonpressure vessel forming part of the air gap
separation between a potable and an auxiliary supply.
SURVEY: The collection of information pertaining to a customer's piping system
regarding the location of all connections to the public water supply system and
must include the location, type and most recent inspection and testing date of
all cross connection control devices and methods located within that customer's
piping system. The survey shall be completed on a form supplied by the village
and need not be a plumbing inspection.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS (SS): Solids that either float on the surface of or are in
suspension in water, sewage or industrial waste and which are removable by a
laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids
shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the IEPA division of
laboratories' manual of laboratory methods.
SYSTEM: The combined waterworks and sewerage system servicing the village.
SYSTEM HAZARD: A condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or
degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the public water supply
system or a customer's potable water system.
UNPOLLUTED WATER: Water quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria
in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality
standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary sewers and
wastewater treatment facilities provided.
USED WATER: Any water supplied by a public water supply system to a consumer's
water system after it has passed through the service connection and is no
longer under the control of the water supply official custodian.
USER: A facility or customer that receives or sends any flow from or through
the village's water or sewer system or private system to which the village owns
to capacity rights.
USER CHARGE: A charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of
operation, maintenance and replacement.
USER CLASS: The type of user - "residential, institutional/governmental,
commercial" or "industrial" as defined herein.
VACUUM: Any pressure less than exerted by the atmosphere.
VILLAGE: That area within the corporate limits of the village of Woodridge,
DuPage and Will Counties, Illinois.
VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR: The individual appointed by the mayor and board of
trustees to be the direct representative of the corporate authorities in the
transaction of all village business and in all matters concerning the citizens
of the village as provided by ordinance.
VILLAGE BOARD: The mayor and board of trustees of the village.
VILLAGE COLLECTOR: The finance director of the village.
WASTEWATER: The spent water of a community. From this standpoint, of course, it
may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences,
commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any
groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present.
WASTEWATER AND SEWERAGE FUND: The principal accounting designation for all
revenues received in the operation of the system.
WASTEWATER FACILITIES: The structures, equipment and processes required to
collect, carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport
effluent to a watercourse.
WASTEWATER TREATMENT WORKS: An arrangement of devices and structures for
treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. Sometimes it is used as
synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or
"pollution control plant".
WATER PURVEYOR: The owner or official custodian of a public water system.
WATER QUALITY STANDARDS: Defined in the water pollution regulations of
Illinois.
WATERCOURSE: A channel in which a flow of water occurs either continuously or
intermittently.
WATERWORKS SYSTEM: All physical assets used for the production, storage and
distribution of water, whether owned, operated, leased, purchased, possessed or
maintained by the village of Woodridge. (1976 Code §§9-51, 20-2; amd. Ord. 86-
60, §1; 1991 Code; Ord. 94-33, 5-12-1994; Ord. 2009-15, 4-2-2009; Ord. 2011-21,
5-12-2011; Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. 30 ILCS 405/1 et seq.
2 2. 30 ILCS 405/1 et seq.
7-5A-2: COMBINED UTILITY:
The waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system of the village shall be
owned, maintained and operated as a combined utility. (Ord. 71-16, art. I, §2)
7-5A-3: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
Every user of the system shall use the same upon the conditions prescribed in
this chapter. (Ord. 71-16, art. I, §2)
7-5A-4: SUPERVISION OF SYSTEM:
The department of public works under the direction of the director of public
works and such other agents and employees designated by the village board shall
have the supervision, management and control of the maintenance, enlargement
and operation of the system owned and controlled by the village and all matters
and things connected with the operation, maintenance and extension of the
system and preserving the property belonging thereto. (Ord. 71-16, art. I, §2;
amd. Ord. 84-52, §14; Ord. 2011-21, 5-12-2011)
7-5A-5: TAPS:
Whenever any permit for a connection with the water or sewer mains of the
village is issued hereunder, only the employee of the village so designated for
the work or an approved contractor shall tap the main of the system where such
connection is to be made. (Ord. 71-16, art. I, §2; amd. Ord. 82-8, §5; Ord. 83-
53, §6)
7-5A-6: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Permits Required:
      1.   Building Sewer Or Water Main: No person shall install or repair any
sanitary building sewer or water main without first obtaining a written permit
for such work from the director and/or the county director. (1976 Code §20-19)
      2.   Water Or Sewer Connections: No sewer connection, house connection,
house service, or any combination thereof may be connected to the waterworks or
sewerage system of the village unless a permit is obtained therefor as provided
herein. (1976 Code §9-52)
   B.   Bond And Insurance Requirements:
      1.   Bond: No permit for a sewer connection, a house connection, a water
service extension or a sewer extension shall be issued by the director unless
the person applying therefor or the contractor shall have filed in the office
of the director of finance a performance bond with corporate surety acceptable
to the village in a sum equal to one and one-half (11/2) times the estimated
cost of the work to be done. Such performance bond shall be approved by the
village attorney, conditioned upon the applicant indemnifying and saving
harmless the village for any and all damage to underground utilities or to the
water and sewer mains and laterals of the village and from any failure to
restore any road, ditch, pavement or portion thereof damaged during
construction to the condition existing at the commencement of construction.
(1976 Code §20-20)
      2.   Insurance: No permit for a sewer connection, a house connection, a
water service extension or a sewer extension shall be issued by the director
unless the person applying therefor or the contractor shall have first procured
public liability insurance in an amount of not less than one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000.00) for injuries, including accidental death, to any one
person and in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) on account of any one accident, and property damage insurance in
an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) insuring the
village and the applicant as their respective interests may appear. A
certificate of said insurance shall be filed with the village collector. (1976
Code §20-21)
   C.   Excavations 1 :
      1.   Safety Devices: All openings made in rights of way shall be
protected at all times by sufficient barriers on which signal lights or flares
shall be placed and maintained after dark. The owner of the premises for which
the work is being done shall notify the director of public works when a street
is fully obstructed by such opening. (1976 Code §20-18; amd. Ord. 2011-21, 5-
12-2011)
      2.   Restoration Of Excavated Area: Streets, sidewalks, parkways and
other public property disturbed in the course of any such work shall be
restored in a manner satisfactory to the village engineer. (1976 Code §20-18)

1 1. See also subsections
  7-1-3C of this title and 8-1A-7C of this code.
7-5A-7: MEASUREMENTS, TESTS AND ANALYSES:
All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of water and wastes
to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance
with the latest edition of IEPA division of laboratories' manual of laboratory
methods and shall be determined at the control manhole provided or upon
suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event no special manhole
has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest
downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer
is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to
reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the
existence of hazards to life, limb and property. The particular analyses
involved will determine whether a twenty four (24) hour composite of all
samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids
analyses are obtained from twenty four (24) hour composites of all outfalls,
whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples. (1976 Code §20-28)
7-5A-8: FEES AND CHARGES 1 :
   A.   Fees And Charges Established:
      1.   User Charges: All users of the system shall pay such rates for the
use and service of the system as shall be prescribed from time to time by the
village board 2  and, when applicable, by the DuPage County board as set forth
in the county sewer use ordinance. (1976 Code §20-8)
      2.   Wastewater Maintenance Charge: All users of the sewerage system
shall pay a wastewater maintenance charge as set forth in section
7-5D-3 of this chapter. (1976 Code §20-9)
      3.   Connection Permit Fees: The fees to be charged for a permit to tap
or otherwise make a connection with any water or sewer main shall be determined
in such manner and shall be an amount as shall be prescribed by ordinance, from
time to time, adopted by the village board 3  and, where applicable, the county
board as set forth in the DuPage County sewer use ordinance. (1976 Code §20-14)
   B.   Criteria For Charges: A charge shall be made to the users of said
system which shall be reasonable for the use and service of such system, and
such charges or rates for that purpose shall be established and such rates
shall be sufficient to pay the cost of the operation and maintenance of the
entire system of the village including an adequate depreciation fund therefor,
and to pay the interest on and principal of all bonds which by their terms are
payable from the revenues of the system and to maintain the additional accounts
established in the ordinance authorizing the issue of bonds. Notwithstanding
any provision contained in this subsection and subsections C, D1 and D2 of this
section to the contrary, the establishment of, liability for and billing and
collection of user charges for the sewerage system shall be in accordance with
the DuPage County sewer use ordinance. (1976 Code §20-22)
   C.   Liability For Charges: The services of the system are furnished to the
respective premises by the Village only upon the condition that the owner of
the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service are jointly and
severally liable therefor to the Village. (1976 Code §20-23)
   D.   Bills For Service; Delinquencies:
      1.   Rendition Of Bills: It shall be the duty of the Director of Finance
to cause statements for charges to be delivered to each customer of the system
at such intervals as will be determined by the Mayor and Board of Trustees but
in no event at any greater interval than two (2) months. (1976 Code §20-24)
Where both water and sewer service are provided, the bill shall be rendered as
single water and sewer charge. (1976 Code §20-25)
      2.   Payment Of Bills; Delinquencies:
         a.   All charges shall be due and payable on or before the twenty
first day after the date when the statements of such charges are rendered. All
bills not paid within twenty one (21) days of the date of billing shall have a
penalty charge of ten percent (10%) added thereto.
         b.   In the event such charges for service are not paid within thirty
(30) days after the rendition of the bill for such services, such charges shall
be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent and thereafter such
delinquent charges shall constitute liens upon the real estate upon or for
which the services have been supplied. The Village may file a lien with the
Office of the Recorder of Deeds of the County in which the property resides,
which shall be deemed notice of the lien for payment of such service.
         c.   No person owing waterworks and sewerage charges and moving to
other premises where there are such connections or where connections shall
afterwards be made shall be served until all charges in arrears are paid in
full.
         d.   In the event charges for water service are not paid within thirty
(30) days after the rendition of the bill for such services, the Village shall
provide notice informing the customer of the required payment or other action
required to prevent discontinuation of service, the date by which such payment
or other action must be made, the charges for disconnection and reconnection of
service, that the Finance Department has authority to resolve disputes, and the
procedure for making a written request for review of disputed charges. If no
written request for review is made prior to the date on which service was to be
discontinued and payment of the unpaid charges is not made, or other required
action is not done, water service may be discontinued without further notice.
If a written request for review is made, the request will be reviewed by the
Finance Department and a decision rendered within five business days from date
of receipt of written request. Any amounts due or actions required after the
decision has been given shall be made within five business days or the service
shall be discontinued immediately. A fee shall be added to the account once it
has been placed on the shut off list for termination. Water service shall only
be restored (turned back on) during normal Village working hours. The
termination fee shall be as follows: seventy dollars ($70.00) which is intended
to cover administrative time as well as operations time and equipment. Anytime
any services are provided after normal Village working hours, a charge of one
hundred forty dollars ($140.00) shall be assessed.
         e.   If payment received by the Village on a delinquent account is
returned for any reason including, but not limited to, insufficient funds, or
account closed, the Village may disconnect water services immediately without
further notice. In such event, another termination fee would apply along with
the customary returned check fee stated in this Code.
      3.   Payment Plan: If a customer is unable to pay a bill rendered by the
Village for services of the system, the Director of Finance may, in their
discretion, enter into a payment plan agreement with said customer. Customers
who have entered into an agreed upon payment plan at any time during the
previous twelve (12) months shall not be afforded such opportunity.
   E.   Notice When Vacating Or Occupying Premises: Any person who shall vacate
any premises or any person who shall enter upon and occupy any premises shall
immediately, before vacating said premises or occupying said premises, notify
the department and secure a reading of the meter.
   F.   Denial Of Service:
      1.   If after a review of its records, the village finds that an
applicant for water service has failed to pay past due charges for water
service at the same or another address, the village may refuse to provide
service unless the applicant pays any past due bill. Service shall not be
denied for nonpayment of bills other than those for water service.
      2.   The village may refuse to provide water service to any premise for
which a claim of lien for unpaid charges for water service has been filed with
the county recorder on or before the date of application for service, unless
the applicant tenders to the village the amount of the charges due. (1976 Code
§20-27; amd. 1991 Code; Ord. 2000-02, 1-13-2000; Ord. 2009-02, 2-5-2009; Ord.
2011-29, 6-9-2011; Ord. 2018-27, 8-16-2018; Ord. 2018-28, 8-16-2018; Ord. 2022-
53, 9-1-2022; Ord. 2024-46, 9-5-2024)

  7-5D-3, and
  7-5D-4 of this chapter.

  7-5D-1 of this chapter.
7-5A-9: LAND DEVELOPMENTS:
Any land developer, subdivider or construction contractor of land within the
Village, or party or owner or owners of land desiring annexation to the Village
shall provide without expense to the Village a sewage collection system and a
water distribution system for the area within the village for which building
permits are desired or for the area desired to be annexed to the Village, and
all such sewage and water systems shall be deeded over or otherwise legally
transferred to the Village without cost to the Village. (1976 Code §20-29)
7-5A-10: DAMAGING, TAMPERING WITH SYSTEM 1 :
No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy,
uncover, deface or tamper with any of the sewers, appurtenances, equipment,
machinery, lift stations or structures of the system installed, owned and/or
operated by the Village. Any violation hereof may be punishable as hereinafter
provided. (1976 Code §20-15; amd. Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-2022)

1 1. See also subsection
  5-7-3-2B9 of this Code.
7-5A-11: REPORTS AND RECORDS:
   A.   Books, Records And Accounts: The director of finance shall keep or
cause to be kept full and complete books of accounts and records, separate and
apart from any other records of the village, showing in detail all monies
received by them with dates and sources and all matters pertaining to the
financial operation of the system in a clear and methodical manner. They shall
also keep such other books as the village administrator and the village board
may from time to time direct. All such books and records shall at all
reasonable times be open to the inspection of the village administrator and
village board, any member thereof, the holder of any outstanding waterworks and
sewerage revenue bonds or any duly authorized agent or agents of such holder.
(1976 Code §20-6)
   B.   Access To Records: The Illinois environmental protection agency and/or
the United States environmental protection agency or its authorized
representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of
the village which are applicable to the village's system of user charges or
industrial cost recovery for the purpose of making audit, examinations,
excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the
special and general conditions to any federal grant. (1976 Code §20-30; amd.
Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-2022)
7-5A-12: ENFORCEMENT OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Powers And Authority Of Inspectors:
      1.   The village engineer, director, county director and other duly
authorized employees of the village of Woodridge or the counties of DuPage,
Will and Cook, the Illinois environmental protection agency and the United
States environmental protection agency bearing proper credentials and
identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of
inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, testing, improvement,
maintenance and/or repair of the system in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter. Such persons shall have no authority to inquire into any
processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or
other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the use of the
system.
      2.   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred
to in subsection A1 of this section, the village engineer, director, county
director or duly authorized employees of the village of Woodridge, counties of
DuPage, Will and Cook, the Illinois environmental protection agency and the
United States environmental protection agency shall observe all safety rules
applicable to the premises.
      3.   The village engineer, director, county director and other duly
authorized employees of the village of Woodridge and the counties of DuPage,
Will and Cook, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be
permitted to enter all private properties through which the village holds a
duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection,
observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of
the water or sewer system lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent
work, if any, on said easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms
of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property. (1976 Code
§20-7)
   B.   Notice Of Violation; Failure To Comply: Whenever and wherever within
the boundaries of the municipality or other area served by the municipality it
shall be made to appear that any person is violating any of the provisions of
this chapter, the director, village engineer, or the county director (with
respect to the sewerage system) may, but is not required as a condition
precedent to prosecution for violation, cause to be served personally or by
certified mail, return receipt requested, upon the alleged offender a notice in
writing stating the date, nature of the alleged offense and directing that the
same cease and desist immediately upon service of the notice and that the act
or omission causing such violation be corrected within thirty (30) days or
within such reasonable time as the circumstances may require. (1976 Code §20-
10)
The failure, neglect and refusal of the person alleged to be in such violation
to cease and desist therefrom within the time stated in such notice shall be
deemed a violation of the provisions of this chapter and punishable as provided
in this chapter. (1976 Code §20-11)
   C.   Authority To Stop Certain Discharges:
      1.   The director and village engineer shall have the power to stop and
prevent free discharge into the public sewers from any private building drain
through which substances are discharged and which are liable to injure or
seriously obstruct the flow of the public sewers.
      2.   The county director shall have such powers as are set forth in the
DuPage County sewer use ordinance. (1976 Code §20-13)
   D.   Discontinuance Of Service:
      1.   The municipality shall have the right with respect to any violation
of this chapter, except as otherwise herein provided, to:
         a.   Discontinue service to any person; and/or
         b.   Plug or disconnect the sewer at any point in the building drain.
      2.   The county director, with respect to the sewerage system, shall have
the right to take such action as is set forth in the DuPage County sewer use
ordinance. (1976 Code §20-12)
      3.   If, after the water or sewer supply shall have been turned on to any
building, structure or premises, it shall be found by any employee or agent of
the village that fraudulent representations have been made by the applicant for
such water or sewer supply and that water is being used in or upon such
building, structure or premises for purposes not set forth in the application
made for such water or sewer supply, or that there is willful or unreasonable
use or waste of water, the director shall have the authority and it shall be
their duty to turn off and stop the supply of water or sewer to such building,
structure or premises forthwith and the supply shall not be turned on to such
building, structure or premises until the person or persons responsible for
such fraudulent representations or for such use of water shall pay the village
such sums of money for such water and sewer supply or on account of such
unreasonable waste of such water or sewer supply as the village board shall
find properly to be due the village.
   E.   Penalty: Any person found to have violated any provision of this
chapter shall be fined in accordance with provisions contained in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1976 Code §20-16; amd. 1991 Code; Ord. 97-29, 6-26-1997;
Ord. 2009-15, 4-2-2009; Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-2022)
7-5A-13: CONNECTIONS OUTSIDE VILLAGE:
   A.   Connecting To The Village System/Capacity:
      1.   The village will consider serving new users that are located outside
of the corporate limits of the village with water and/or sewer service. The
village will also consider serving new users that are located outside of the
corporate limits of the village with water and/or sewer capacity owned and/or
controlled by the village, which is delivered through lines of a regulated
utility (all such potential new users described above, for purposes of this
subsection A, shall be referred to as "extraterritorial user applicants").
In accordance with the procedures set forth in subsection A2 of this section,
the village will consider applications submitted by extraterritorial user
applicants for water and/or sewer service or use of water and/or sewer capacity
provided that it is determined that the requested water and/or sewer services,
or use of water and/or sewer capacity, will not unreasonably impair the ability
to continue to adequately and safely meet the then current and anticipated
water and/or sewer service demands, or water and/or sewer capacity demands, of
its residents, the owners of vacant lands located within its corporate limits,
and its existing customers or owners of property located outside the village's
corporate limits presently served by the system or with capacity or with whom
the village presently has a contract providing for the provision of water and/
or sewer service, or water and/or sewer capacity, in the future.
All extraterritorial user applicants shall comply with all conditions imposed
by the village. Said conditions shall be set forth in a utility and annexation
agreement which may, in addition to any other conditions required by the
village, provide that the party applying for water and/or sewer service, or
water and/or sewer capacity will:
         a.   Construct any necessary extension and distribution system in
conformance with plans and specifications approved by the village engineer.
         b.   Upon inspection and acceptance by the village engineer and the
submission of proof satisfactory to the village that any such extensions and
distribution systems have been fully paid for, convey to the village such
extensions and distribution systems together with such easements as may be
necessary to permit the village to have adequate access thereto. Such
conveyances shall be by bills of sale, easements or other appropriate
documents, the form and substance of which shall be subject to the approval of
the village's legal counsel.
         c.   To the extent to which the property being or to be served is
located within the village's planning jurisdiction, agree to develop and
utilize the property in a manner consistent with the village's comprehensive
plan and agree to comply with the provisions of the village's codes,
ordinances, rules and regulations.
         d.   Agree to pay to the village all engineering and legal expenses
incurred by the village in reviewing the extraterritorial user applicant's
application, reviewing and approving the plans and specifications for the
construction of any extension or distribution system, inspecting and approving
the construction of the improvements and the negotiation, drafting, review and
execution of any utility and annexation agreement or other document
implementing such agreement.
All utility and annexation agreements shall, in addition to any and all other
terms, require that the property on which the user is located shall be annexed
to the village at such time as it becomes contiguous to the village or is
otherwise subject to annexation as part of a larger territory as permitted by
the Illinois municipal code. All utility and annexation agreements shall be
executed by the extraterritorial user applicant (as well as the record owner[s]
of the property on which the extraterritorial user applicant is located, if
different).
      2.   Extraterritorial user applicants shall make applications upon such
forms as the director may from time to time prescribe. Extraterritorial user
applicants shall provide the director with such information as the director may
deem necessary or appropriate to their review of any such application. If the
director preliminarily determines that the extraterritorial user applicant's
request may be permitted without adversely affecting the village's ability to
adequately and safely meet its other obligations, he shall cause to be prepared
a utility and annexation agreement incorporating the terms and provisions
provided under subsection A1 of this section together with such other terms as
he may determine. The utility and annexation agreement shall be executed by the
extraterritorial user applicant (as well as the record owner[s] of the property
on which the extraterritorial user applicant is located, if different) prior to
submittal of the director's findings and recommendations to the corporate
authorities.
      3.   The director shall submit their findings and recommendations to the
corporate authorities together with a copy of the executed utility and
annexation agreement. Should the corporate authorities concur in the director's
findings and recommendations, they may, by resolution, authorize the mayor and
village clerk to enter into the utility and annexation agreement.
      4.   Should the director find that any request would adversely affect the
village's ability to adequately and safely meet existing water or sewer
service/capacity demands, they shall deny such application. The
extraterritorial user applicant may thereafter appeal the director's denial to
the corporate authorities, whose decision with respect to the application
denial and appeal shall be final.
      5.   In the event the corporate authorities determine that an application
shall be granted, they shall authorize the director to issue necessary permits
for all work to be performed by the extraterritorial user applicant. All work
shall be in conformance with the permit(s), the utility and annexation
agreement, any incorporated engineering plans and specifications approved by
the village engineer and any other applicable provisions of this chapter.
      6.   The corporate authorities shall from time to time establish by
ordinance, rates and charges applicable to the service/capacity being provided,
which shall be incorporated by reference into all utility and annexation
agreements.
   B.   Existing Users Outside Village; Agreement Required; Termination Of
Service:
      1.   The village currently serves commercial, industrial and residential
users that are located outside of the corporate limits of the village with
water and/or sewer service. The village also currently serves commercial,
industrial and residential users that are located outside of the corporate
limits of the village with water and/or sewer capacity owned and/or controlled
by the village, which is delivered through lines of a regulated utility (all
such users described above, for purposes of this subsection B, shall be
referred to as "extraterritorial users").
The corporate authorities of the village have determined that it shall no
longer serve such extraterritorial users unless such extraterritorial users
(including the record owner[s] of the property on which the extraterritorial
user is located, if different) shall enter into a utility and annexation
agreement with the village. The terms of any such agreement shall be in
accordance with the terms set forth in subsection A of this section, to the
extent applicable, and otherwise in a form acceptable to the village attorney.
Extraterritorial users are hereby required to enter into a utility and
annexation agreement with the village on or before the following deadlines:
Commercial and industrial users must enter into a utility and annexation
agreement with the village by December 31, 2009.
Residential users must enter into a utility and annexation agreement prior to
submission of applications to DuPage County for any of the following building
permits: a) principal building addition; b) swimming pool; c) lawn sprinkler or
irrigation systems; d) water features; and e) accessory structures with water
or sewer service. An expansion shall mean an addition to the home, addition of
an accessory structure on the property, or any other expansion of the structure
or use that the village believes may impact the water and sewer system of the
village.
      2.   In the event any extraterritorial user fails to enter into the
required utility and annexation agreement as required in this section, the
water and/or sewer services or water and/or sewer capacity shall be terminated
upon sixty (60) days' prior written notice.
      3.   All extraterritorial users shall pay to the village all engineering
and legal expenses incurred by the village in the negotiation drafting, review
and execution of any utility and annexation agreement or other document
implementing such agreement. (Ord. 2009-15, 4-2-2009; amd. Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-
2022)
7-5A-14: UTILITY SERVICE EXTENSION:
In all situations where the potable water, sanitary sewer, and/or storm sewer
systems are being extended to provide service to a new property, such utility
system shall be extended to the far side of the property in order to be
available for future extensions by adjacent property owners. (Ord. 2013-53, 10-
24-2013)

7-5B-1: USE OF PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM REQUIRED:
   A.   Use Of Public Water System Required: When feasible and where a public
water system main is now installed or hereafter may be installed in any street,
alley, public way or easement, all water users located on any such street,
alley, public way or easement shall make or cause to be made connection to such
public water system main and pay the connection charges therefor within ninety
(90) days hereafter or within ninety (90) days after the installation of such
water main if the same is not now installed, and all users shall discontinue
within the same period of time any connection which they theretofore may have
had with any other water service.
Connection with the public water system main is hereby declared to be feasible
as to any premises where any property line of such premises is within four
hundred feet (400') of any public water system main or the per structure cost
of establishing a connection to the public water system main is less than two
hundred percent (200%) of the cost of constructing a private well for each
structure on the premises.
For the purposes of this section, a "public water system" shall be defined as
any system owned and operated by a municipality, a county or by a utility
company regulated by the Illinois commerce commission. (Ord. 98-40, 7-9-1998)
   B.   Private Wells Prohibited:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to drill or install any well for the purpose of
securing water for use in any premises within the village other than a well or
wells connected with and made a part of the municipal water supply and
distribution system installed and/or operated by the village.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to use water from any well drilled, dug or
installed in violation of the provisions of this chapter. (1976 Code §20-103)
   C.   Tax Supported Governmental Users; Variations From This Section: The
board of trustees may, by ordinance, grant variations from the regulations
imposed under this section for tax supported governmental users. An application
for a variation shall be filed with the director of public works, and shall
identify the specific unique circumstances affecting the subject property and
the specific detriment which would result in the absence of the requested
variation. The director of public works shall promptly review each application
and forward the same, along with recommendations thereon, to the board of
trustees. No variation shall be granted unless unique circumstances affecting
the subject property would result in some substantial detriment in the absence
of the requested variation, nor shall a variation be granted if any material
detriment to the public health, safety or welfare would result therefrom. The
board of trustees may impose such conditions or restrictions upon the grant of
any variation as may be necessary or appropriate to further the purpose and
intent of the connection requirements of this section. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, the granting of a variation pursuant to this subsection is entirely
at the discretion of the board of trustees. No tax supported governmental user
shall be entitled to a variation as a matter of right. (Ord. 96-44, 9-12-1996;
amd. Ord. 2011-21, 5-12-2011)
7-5B-2: WATER SERVICE AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Application For Water Service And Connections: Any person desiring to
make any connection with the combined system or use water therefrom shall first
make application to the director upon a blank form or forms furnished by the
department. Said application shall contain an agreement on the part of the
applicant that all the rules, regulations, conditions and provisions of any
ordinance relating to the system will be complied with and that all water and
sewer rates, assessments and rents and all fines and penalties assessed,
charged or imposed against said applicant upon the property described in said
application will be paid. (1976 Code §20-107)
   B.   Water Connection Permit: When the applicant herein has complied with
all of the provisions of the ordinances of the village, a permit shall then be
issued by the director authorizing the connection to be made and specifying the
size thereof. (1976 Code §20-108)
   C.   Multiple Water Connections: No service pipe shall be laid or used to
supply water to more than one premises or building unless a separate curb stop
for each of the premises or buildings shall be placed outside of such premises
in the parkway as hereinafter provided and a permit fee shall be obtained for
each service connection. (1976 Code §20-109)
7-5B-3: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   State Specifications Adopted: Construction of water improvements shall
be in accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois", first edition, August 1, 1967, as may be amended by
the village. (1976 Code §20-121)
   B.   Water Mains:
      1.   Installation Of Water Mains: Water mains shall be installed to
conform with the comprehensive water plan of the village as the same may be
adopted by the village board and as may be amended from time to time. All mains
shall be a minimum of six inches (6") in diameter. Water mains of eight inches
(8") in diameter or greater are to be ductile iron pipe, cement lined or of
equal material, all as approved by the village. (1976 Code §20-116)
      2.   Valves On Mains: Valves shall be installed on mains at locations to
minimize inconvenience to customers served thereby, but in no case shall be
spaced greater than eight hundred feet (800') apart. All valves must be placed
in valve vaults. Valves of six inches (6") to ten inches (10") in diameter,
inclusive, shall be installed in a four foot (4') diameter vault and those
twelve inches (12") in diameter and above shall be installed in a five foot
(5') vault. Valves shall be located at the extension of the right of way at its
intersection with the water main, wherever possible. (1976 Code §20-118)
   C.   Water Taps: The water main shall be tapped on an angle of forty five
degrees (45°) with the vertical and the corporation stop shall be turned so
that the T handle will be on top. (1976 Code §20-122)
   D.   Service Pipes And Connections:
      1.   Installation And Maintenance Of Service Pipes; Cost: Every person
supplied with water from the village waterworks system shall, at their cost and
expense, have installed and kept in repair all pipes leading from the curb stop
or valve, including the concrete pit or other protected means for the meter if
applicable, to their building, structure or premises supplied with water
through such service pipes.
      2.   Pipe Specifications: All copper service pipes shall be type K, soft
tubing and all joints shall be flared and swaged. The diameter of the service
pipe shall be three-fourths inch (3/4") minimum. (1976 Code §20-120)
      3.   Inspection And Approval Of Pipes And Connections 1 : All service
pipes and connections shall be inspected and approved by the director and no
such service pipes shall be covered until they have been so inspected. (1976
Code §20-123)
   E.   Curb Stops, Cocks, Boxes: Curb stops, cocks and boxes shall be in the
Mueller Minneapolis pattern of the inverted key and extension types. (1976 Code
§20-119)
   F.   Multiple Supply From Single Tap: Whenever two (2) or more distinct
buildings or premises are to be supplied by means of branch or surface pipes
supplied by a single tap in the street main, each branch must be independently
arranged with a stopcock and box in the manner prescribed by this article and
separate meters must be installed for each individual building. (1976 Code §20-
113; amd. 1991 Code; Ord. 2013-11, 3-14-2013; Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 3-1A-3B5 of this code for plumbing inspection fees.
7-5B-4: COMPLIANCE WITH PLUMBING REGULATIONS:
Water shall not be turned on into the supply pipe of any new building in which
the plumbing and drainage systems have been altered until such plumbing and
drainage systems shall conform in all respects to the ordinances of the
village, as evidenced by the report of the director, and until the applicant
shall have paid the water charges due. However, a plumber will be allowed
twenty four (24) hours to test all work. (1976 Code §20-110)
7-5B-5: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR:
All persons taking water shall keep the service pipes and all fixtures
connected therewith in good repair and protected from frost at their own
expense and shall prevent all unnecessary waste of water; provided, however,
that a reasonable time, not to exceed forty eight (48) hours, shall be allowed
to any person having defective pipes to repair or cause the same to be
repaired. (1976 Code §20-124)
7-5B-6: WATER METERS:
All water supplied by the village system shall be measured by outside remote
reading water meters only; except, that in those cases where it is temporarily
impractical to set a meter, the use and consumption of water shall be governed
by other applicable provisions of this chapter. A conduit shall be provided
that runs from the inside meter to a location outside the structure to where
the outside meter is being installed on all new construction installations and
remodeling work where the existing wire run has been exposed. Said conduit
shall be labeled "For Water Meter Remote". (Ord. 97-29, 6-26-1997; amd. Ord.
2012-34, 6-14-2012)
7-5B-6-1: PROPERTY OF VILLAGE:
All meters used in connection with the system shall be furnished by the village
only and shall be and remain for all time the property of the village.
There shall be charges established for water meters and the payment thereof
shall be made upon application for a building permit to the department of
community development of the village. Such charges will be established by the
village board from time to  time 1 . (1976 Code § 20-137 and 20-138; amd. Ord.
2011-21, 5-12-2011; Ord. 2023-63, 12-21-2023)

  7-5D-4 of this chapter.
7-5B-6-2: METER LOCATION:
Water meters shall be located at such places within the premises to be served
in the manner and in accord with such specifications as the director shall
direct. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the director shall retain the ability to
require the installation of the meter in a concrete pit or with other protected
means approved by the director to prevent damage, at the connection point with
the water main, whether on or off the premises. All meter locations shall be so
situated as to prevent freezing of water flowing through such meters. (Ord.
2013-11, 3-14-2013)
7-5B-6-3: METER SPECIFICATIONS:
The director, with the approval of the village board, shall in all cases
determine the kind and pattern of water meters to be installed and no other
kind shall be installed at any time. The size of the meter required for any
metered supply shall be governed by the size and character of the premises
served. The size of the meter for large buildings shall be approved by the
director at the time of application for the water supply. The size of meters so
approved may be changed from time to time if conditions require. (1976 Code
§20-139)
7-5B-6-4: READING, TESTING AND REPAIRING METERS:
   A.   Access To Premises: The Director shall have ready access to the
premises, places or buildings where meters are located for the purpose of
installing, replacing, and reading same, testing and repairing the same and
examining and testing the consumption, use and flow of water, and it shall be
unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent or obstruct the Director in
this undertaking. Where inspections are not of an immediate or urgent nature,
employees of the waterworks system will use best efforts to arrange for
appointments that are mutually convenient to the owners or occupants of the
premises served and such employees. The property owner and/or occupant shall be
responsible for providing unobstructed access to all of the components related
to the water service, including, but not limited to, the inside meter, outside
meter, remote, and buffalo box. In the event there is an obstruction, the
property owner and/or occupant shall be responsible for removing or otherwise
providing unobstructed access within ten (10) working days of notice to
complete the same. In the event the owner does not provide unobstructed access
within ten (10) working days the village shall have the right to disconnect and
refuse further service to the premises until unobstructed access is available.
   B.   Permission Required For Meter Work: It shall be unlawful to tamper at
any time with the installed water meter or have the same removed or repaired or
cause the same to be removed or repaired without obtaining permission from the
director.
   C.   Notice Of Defective Meter: It shall be the duty of the owner or
occupant of any premises to promptly notify the department of any defects in
any meter or of its failure to properly register the quantity of water passing
through the same.
   D.   Inaccurate Meters: Water meters are determined as inaccurate or in need
of repair when the variation of or departure from one hundred percent (100%)
accuracy shall be in excess of two percent (2%). Whenever any meter shall prove
to be inaccurate or in need of repair, the director will cause the meter to be
removed, tested, recalibrated and/or replaced. The charges for these services
as indicated will be the responsibility of the village. If, however, the
customer requests that the meter be checked or replaced and if it is proven
that the meter is accurate and/or not in need of repairs, the customer will be
responsible for the cost of the replacement meter plus village expenses
incurred.
   E.   Repair Or Replacement; Costs: All repair or replacement costs, other
than normal maintenance of the water meter, remote and resetter, including,
without limitation, freezing, hot water damage or damages caused by known or
unknown persons (including theft), shall be the joint and several
responsibility of the property owner and occupant. Such costs for any work
other than the aforementioned normal maintenance shall be paid by the owner/
occupant as soon as a bill from the village for the same is presented, and the
amount therefor shall be a lien against the premises for which the meter was
installed or repaired to the extent and with the same effect as that for water
charges.
In the event the wire between the outside and inside meter needs to be replaced
and is reasonably accessible, or there is functional conduit in place, the
village will complete the work to install the wire. In the event the location
for the wire is not reasonably accessible, or there is not functional conduit,
the village shall supply the wire, at no charge, but the property owner and/or
occupant shall be responsible for completing the work to install the wire
within thirty (30) calendar days of notice to complete the same. In the event
the work in question is not completed by the deadline, water service shall be
temporarily suspended until the required work is completed to the satisfaction
of the village. If water service is suspended reinstatement of the same shall
be subject to the standard village fee. (1976 Code §§ 20-143, 20-144, 20-147
and 20-148; amd. Ord. 2012-34, 6-14-2012; Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-2022; Ord. 2023-63,
12-21-2023)
7-5B-6-5: MULTIPLE METERS:
Where water is supplied through two (2) or more meters to one customer or to
two (2) or more premises owned by any one person, in no instance will readings
of such meters be combined. All readings shall be on a per meter basis. The
village will not recognize a secondary or subtraction meter, nor will it render
any bill or bills on same. Water will always be charged against the property as
registered by the primary meter. (1976 Code §20-149)
7-5B-6-6: TAMPERING, INTERFERING WITH METERS:
   A.   After the meter is placed, only employees or agents of the department
shall be allowed to repair, remove or in any manner interfere with the same. A
meter stop or valve shall be placed on each side of the meter. (1976 Code §20-
145)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, mar, destroy or
in any manner to interfere with any meter 1 . (1976 Code §20-140)

1 1. See section
  7-5A-10 of this chapter.
7-5B-6-7: NONCONFORMING WATER METER REPLACEMENT PROGRAM:
The village has determined that all water meters in the system shall be of the
outside remote reading type which are integrated with the Village's advanced
metering infrastructure (AMI) only. All water meters in the system which are
not of the AMI type are deemed to be nonconforming and shall be replaced as a
part of the replacement program by the village at the expense of the village.
The director shall implement a program for the replacement of all nonconforming
water meters. The program shall provide for three (3) notices to be given to
any user having a nonconforming water meter. The notices shall direct the user
to schedule an appointment with the village for the replacement of the
nonconforming water meter by the village. Any user whose nonconforming water
meter is not replaced within thirty (30) days after giving of the third notice
shall be subject to immediate discontinuance of service as provided in
subsection
7-5A-12D of this chapter.
In the event a customer does not wish to have the AMI infrastructure installed
with the meter due to medical reasons, that request must be supported by a
licensed medical professional. In that specific situation the customer may
elect to keep a manual meter without the remote AMI data transmission
capabilities. As a consequence of this option, the customer will not have
access to usage data, which may have assisted in leak detection for the
property. Prior to the transfer of the account for any reason the installation
of the AMI infrastructure shall be required at the property. The customer may
elect at any time to rescind the medical exemption and to have the AMI
infrastructure installed. In the event the property owner refuses or is
otherwise unwilling to provide access to complete the meter reading, the AMI
infrastructure shall be installed and/or water service shall be discontinued
until the AMI infrastructure is installed. Under all of these circumstances,
the cost for the AMI infrastructure and its installation shall be completed at
the Village's expense.
Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, during the time
period in which the nonconforming meter is not replaced the Village shall
assess an additional fee to the customer of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) to the
account for the additional staff and equipment time associated with obtaining
and entering the data collected each time a manual visit to the water meter
needs to occur which would have otherwise not been needed had the AMI system
been in place. In the event of medical exemption documentation having been
submitted to the Village this fee shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00). Said
charge(s) shall be shown on the user's bimonthly statement of charges. Failure
to pay said charge when due shall subject the user to discontinuance of service
as provided in subsection
7-5A-8D of this chapter. (Ord. 97-29, 6-26-1997; amd. Ord. 2023-63, 12-21-2023;
Ord. 2024-46, 9-5-2024)
7-5B-7: HYDRANTS:
   A.   Installation Of Hydrants: Water hydrants with auxiliary valves shall be
installed at intervals not to exceed four hundred feet (400') and shall be of a
type approved by the Director. Hydrants shall be located within the right-of-
way. Valve boxes shall be placed on all auxiliary valves. (1976 Code §20-117)
   B.   Use Of Fire Hydrants: All hydrants erected and connected with the water
system belonging to the Village for the purpose of extinguishing fires in the
Village are hereby declared to be public hydrants and no person or persons
other than members of a legally constituted fire district or department shall
open any of said hydrants or attempt to draw water from the same, except for
extinguishing fires, and shall not in any manner interfere with or injure any
of said hydrants. If special conditions arise which require utilization of
hydrants for any purposes other than extinguishing fires, upon written
application, the Director may grant temporary use of such facilities. (1976
Code §20-150)
   C.   Violation: In addition to any of the activities described hereinabove,
no person shall attach anything to, alter, or otherwise tamper with a hydrant
in any fashion, except by the express consent and direction of a duly
authorized Village official.
   D.   Payment: Any person charged with a violation of this section may, in
lieu of prosecution for a violation hereof, make payment in accordance with
section
1-4-2 of this Code. (Ord. 2006-43, 8-3-2006)
7-5B-8: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING WATER SUPPLY:
   A.   Purchasing Water From Other Than Village: No person having their
residence or place of business within the territorial limits of the Village
shall be permitted to buy water from any other municipal corporation or other
public utility for such residence or place of business located in the Village
whenever the waterworks system of the Village is adjacent to their property
under the provisions of this chapter. (1976 Code §20-105)
   B.   Supplying Water To Others: No person or persons, whether owners or
occupants, in possession or control of any building, structure or premises into
which water is supplied through the system shall be allowed, without written
permission from the Director, to supply other persons or families, or to supply
water from such building or premises to another building, structure or
premises. The supply of water to a building, structure or premises of any
person who violates any of the foregoing provisions of this subsection shall be
shut off and stopped forthwith and the water shall not again be turned on to
such building, structure or premises from which it was cut off until there
shall have been paid to the Village the sum of money as prescribed by the
Director and deemed properly due the Village. (1976 Code §20-125; amd. Ord.
2022-53, 9-1-2022)

(Ord. 2009-15, 4-2-2009)
7-5B-10: WATER CONSERVATION MEASURES:
   A.   Restricted Hours For Nonessential Outside Water Uses To Prevent
Excessive, Wasteful Use: Commencing on May 15 of each year and extending
through the following September 15 of each year, lawn sprinkling shall not
occur on consecutive days, nor shall water from the Village water distribution
system be used on any day between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. and
five o'clock (5:00) P.M. (local time) when evaporation is at its highest for
the purpose of watering or sprinkling of gardens, lawns, trees, shrubs and
other outdoor plants; except, that such restrictions shall not prohibit the
watering of newly planted gardens, lawns, trees, shrubs and plants by means of
handheld watering devices designed and intended for such purpose and only when
such device is actually being operated by hand. New lawns (less than 3 months
old) may be exempted from this provision. In addition, new/replacement
sprinkler systems shall be equipped with a WaterSense labeled irrigation
controller and shall be in compliance with section 2.5(g) of the Illinois
Plumbing License Law.
   B.   Emergency Water Conservation:
      1.   Authority To Proclaim Emergency: Whenever the water supply of the
Village is diminished from any cause whatever to an amount which in the opinion
of the Village Administrator or their designee is or is likely to become
dangerous to the health and safety of the public, the Village Administrator or
their designee is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a proclamation in
the form of a public notice containing regulations on the use of water from the
Village water distribution system. Such regulations may provide for the limited
usage of water, limitations on days and hours of use for some or all purposes
and the prohibition of specified uses. Upon issuing said proclamation, the
Village Administrator or their designee shall make the contents thereof known
to the public by news release to the local newspapers and radio media and may
also notify the citizens in any other practical manner that he shall devise.
Further, the Village Administrator or their designee shall immediately notify
all members of the Village Board of the nature of the emergency and the
regulations that have been imposed.
      2.   Effect Of Proclamation: The emergency proclamation of the Village
Administrator or their designee and the regulations imposed thereby shall
remain in full force and effect until any one of the following shall occur:
         a.   The Village Administrator or their designee determines that the
emergency proclamation and the regulations imposed thereby are no longer
necessary because the emergency proclaimed has ended.
         b.   The Village Board, by official action, modifies or repeals the
emergency proclamation and the regulations imposed thereby or takes such other
or further action as it in its discretion deems necessary and advisable.
         c.   The first regular meeting of the Village Board occurring more
than thirty (30) days after the emergency proclamation.
      3.   Notice Of Emergency: Any Village employee or officer may, at the
direction of the Village Administrator or their designee, notify or warn any
person of the effect of said emergency proclamation and direct said person to
comply with the watering or sprinkling restrictions imposed as herein provided.
If any such person, after having first been notified and warned about said
emergency proclamation and such restrictions, shall continue to violate said
proclamation and restrictions, they shall be deemed to be in violation of this
section and they shall be liable for the penalties provided for in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1976 Code §20-127)
   C.   Violation: Any person charged with a violation of this section may, in
lieu of prosecution for a violation hereof, make payment in accordance with
section
1-4-2 of this Code. (1991 Code; amd. Ord. 2006-43, 8-3-2006; Ord. 2017-51, 9-
21-2017; Ord. 2022-53, 9-1-2022)
