   Section R304.2 Additional Habitable Rooms. Minimum floor area is eighty (80)
square feet.
   Section R304.4 Bedroom Closets. Provide each bedroom with at least one (1)
closet or wardrobe having a minimum:
      1.   Depth: Two feet (2').
      2.   Floor area: Five (5) square feet.
      3.   Height: Six feet (6').
   Section R304.5 Space For Heating Units.
      1.   Provide space within the building for heating unit or system in
accordance with all applicable village codes.
      2.   Provide clearances for maintenance and repair in accordance with all
applicable village codes.
      3.   Provide clearances for fire safety, determined by insulation of
heater and combustibility of walls, floor, and ceiling, as required by
Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., gas and oil equipment list and the
manufacturer's specifications.
      4.   Furnace shall not be located in any sleeping room.
      5.   Furnace shall not be located in the garage or directly accessible to
the garage.
   Section R304.6 Interior Doors.
      1.   Provide a door for each opening to a bedroom, bathroom, and toilet
compartment.
      2.   Minimum sizes:
         a.   All habitable rooms: Two feet and six inches (2'6") wide by six
feet and eight inches (6'8") high;
         b.   Bathrooms: Two feet and four inches (2'4") wide by six feet and
eight inches (6'8") high;
         c.   Powder rooms: Two feet (2'0") wide by six feet and eight inches
(6'8") high.
      3.   Service entrance doors: A minimum width of two feet and eight inches
(2'8"), and a minimum height of six feet and eight inches (6'8").
   Section R306.5 Townhomes. Amend by adding the following section R306.5:
      Section R306.5 Townhomes. Townhomes, two family, and multifamily homes
must be supplied with its own separate domestic water service and sewer
lateral. These utilities must exit the units independently.
   Section R309.6 Opening Protection. Add the following section R309.6:
      Section R309.6 Opening Protection. Openings from a private garage
directly into a room used for sleeping purposes are not permitted. Other
openings between the garage and the residence shall be equipped with a three-
quarter (3/4) hour fire rated door.
   Section R309.7 Separation Required. Add the following new section R309.7:
      Section R309.7 Separation Required. The garage shall be separated from
the residence and its attic area by means of a minimum 1-hour rated fire
barrier constructed of five-eighths inch (5/8") type X gypsum board or
equivalent applied to all walls, ceilings and support structures, including
beams and columns, of the garage. Said gypsum board assembly shall be fully
fire taped, and all penetrations through said assembly shall be firestopped
with a firestop system listed and approved for the application. Ducts in a
private garage and ducts penetrating the walls or ceilings separating the
dwelling unit from the garage shall be encapsulated in construction equal to
that of those walls and ceilings, and shall have no openings into the garage.
   Section R310.1 Emergency Escape And Rescue Required. Amend by deleting all
three (3) exemptions in their entirety.
   Section R310.4 Area Wells. Amend by adding the following new section
R310.4.5:
   Section R310.4.5 Protective Covers. The opening at the top of all window
wells shall be covered with a grate or other material capable of supporting a
fifty (50) pound live load on an area equal to one square foot, or a three
hundred (300) pound concentrated load acting over an area of four (4) square
inches, whichever produces the greater stresses. Said covers shall be
removable, and, if locked, shall be able to be opened from the inside without
the use of a key, tool or special knowledge.
   Section R311.2 Egress Door Required. Delete in its entirety and in lieu
thereof substitute the following new section R311.2:
      Section R311.2 Egress Door Required. Not less than two (2) exits
conforming to this article shall be provided from each dwelling unit. The
required egress doors shall provide direct access from habitable portions of
the dwelling to the exterior without requiring travel through the garage. The
required egress doors shall be a side-hinged door not less than three feet (3')
in width and six feet and eight inches (6'8") in height, except that, for doors
other than the front or main entry/exit door, a minimum six foot (6') wide
sliding glass door, with a minimum clear width of thirty-two inches (32") when
opened, may be used.
      Exception: Townhomes with rear garage: second means of egress is
permitted to be a window that meets egressing requirements of R310.1.1.
   Section R311.7.8 Handrails. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute the following new section R311.7.8:
      Section R311.7.8 Handrails. Handrails shall be provided on at least one
(1) side of each continuous run of treads or flight with three (3) or more
risers. Spiral stairways shall have the required handrail located on the
outside radius.
   Section R312.1.2 Guards. Add the following new section R312.1.2.1:
      Section R312.1.2.1 Guardrails Required. Porches, balconies or raised
floor surfaces located more than twenty-four inches (24") above the floor or
grade below shall have guardrails not less than thirty-six inches (36") in
height. Porches, balconies or raised floor surfaces located more than eighty-
four inches (84") above the floor or grade below shall have guardrails not less
than forty-two inches (42") in height. Open sides of stairs with a total rise
of more than twenty-four inches (24") above the floor or grade below shall have
guardrails not less than thirty-six inches (36") in height measured vertically
from the nosing of the tread.
   Section R313.2 One- And Two-Family Dwellings Automatic Fire Systems. Delete
in its entirety and in lieu thereof substitute the following new section
R313.2:
      Section R313.2 One- And Two-Family Dwellings Automatic Fire Systems. An
automatic residential fire sprinkler system shall be installed in one- and two-
family dwellings.
      Exemptions:
      1.   An automatic residential fire sprinkler system shall not be required
for additions or alterations to existing buildings that are not already
provided with an automatic residential sprinkler system.
      2.   An automatic residential fire sprinkler system shall not be required
for new construction when the underside of all interior stairs are protected
with fire taped 5/8 type X gypsum board or equal.
   Section R401.1 Application. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute the following new section R401.1:
      Section R401.1 Application. The provisions of this chapter shall control
the design and construction of the foundation and foundation spaces for all
buildings.
   Section R401.2 Requirements. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute the following new section R401.2:
      Section R401.2 Requirements. The foundation and its structural elements
shall be capable of supporting all superimposed live, dead and other loads
according to section R301 and all lateral loads in accordance with the
provisions of this code. Fills, which support footings and foundations, shall
be designed, installed and tested in accordance with accepted engineering
practice. Engineering fill shall be compacted to ninety-five percent (95%)
modified density.
   Section R402.1 Wood Foundations. Delete in its entirety.
   Section R403.1 General. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute the following new section R403.1:
      Section R403.1 General. All exterior walls shall be supported on
continuous concrete footings, or other approved structural systems which shall
be of sufficient design to support safely the loads imposed as determined from
the character of the soil. Footings shall be supported on undisturbed natural
soil or engineered fill.
   Section R403.1.1 Minimum Size. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute the following new section R403.1.1:
      Section R403.1.1 Minimum Size.
      1.   Minimum dimension for spread footings shall be eight inches (8")
deep by eighteen inches (18") wide, except the masonry veneer on frame and
solid masonry walls shall be ten inches (10") deep by twenty inches (20") wide.
      2.   The depth of all footings shall be no less than forty-two inches
(42") below grade.
      3.   Reinforce with steel bars where footings cross or bear on fill
trenches or other unstable soil.
      4.   Footing dimension listed within are based upon soils of average
bearing capacity (3,000 lbs. per square foot). For soils of lesser bearing
capacity or where unusual loading conditions exist, larger footings and
reinforcement may be required. A licensed architect or engineer must provide
design.
      5.   Footing must be keyed a minimum of two inches (2") into undisturbed
soil, or shall be interlocked to the soil by other approved methods.
   Figure R403.1(2) Permanent Wood Foundation Basement Wall section. Delete in
its entirety. Figure R403.1(3) Permanent Wood Foundation Crawl Space section.
Delete in its entirety.
   Section R403.2 Footings For Wood Foundations. Delete in its entirety and in
lieu thereof substitute the following section R403.2:
      Section R403.2. Footings For Walls, Piers, Posts And Columns.
      1.   Provide a minimum of forty-two inch (42") frost protection.
      2.   Provide two inch by two inch (2" x 2") keyway in the top of the
footing underneath the centerline of the wall.
      3.   Trench foundation shall be a minimum eight inches (8") wide and
shall be allowed only for single story frame buildings.
      4.   One story dwellings minimum pier area thirty inches by thirty inches
by twelve inches (30" x 30" x 12"). Two story dwellings minimum pier area
thirty-six inches by thirty-six inches by fifteen inches (36" x 36" x 15"). In
all cases, pier must be designed to support all live and dead loads. Pier
foundations for roofed-in structures attached to the principal dwelling shall
be designed by an architect or structural engineer licensed in the state of
Illinois. These structures shall be open or screened-in porches only.
      5.   Chimney footings for dwellings must have a minimum thickness of
twelve inches (12"), with a minimum projection of six inches (6") on each side.
      6.   Chimney footings must be poured integral with the wall footing when
the chimney occurs in the outside wall or an interior bearing wall and must
start at the level of the lowest adjacent wall footing.
      7.   All stoops, steps and platforms at egress areas must be supported in
a manner acceptable to the building official, such as wing walls extending to
the footing or a full frost protected foundation.
   Section R403.3 Frost Protected Shallow Foundations. Delete in its entirety.
   Table R403.3 Minimum Insulation Requirements For Frost- Protected
   Footings In Heated Buildings. Delete table R403.3 in its entirety.
   Section R404 Foundation And Retaining Walls. Amend by adding the following
new section R404.1.10:
      Section R404.1.10 Anchorage For Slabs, Stairs And Area. Provide dowel bar
anchorage for porch and terrace slabs, concrete or masonry steps and area
walls, which adjoin foundation walls. For basementless portions and attached
garages, embed four (4) one-half inch (1/2") round, four inch (4") long hooked
bars halfway into main wall, two (2) near top and two (2) near bottom of
attached wall. Epoxy into place if holes are oversized.
   Section R404.2 Wood Foundation Walls. Delete in its entirety.
   Section R405.1 Concrete Or Masonry Foundations. Amend by deleting the
exception and adding the following new section R405.1.2:
      Section R405.1.2 Footing Drain Tile.
      1.   Required outside of basement and crawlspace footings. Inside
location only upon approval of the building official. Minimum diameter shall be
four inches (4").
      2.   Provide drains in all below grade stair landings and window wells.
Connect drains to footing drain tile with approved "T" fittings.
      3.   Connect with tight-joint glazed tile or approved equal to storm
sewer, sump pump, dry well or other approved outlet.
      4.   Sump pumps must discharge a minimum of three feet (3') from the
foundation walls. Discharge must conform to the approved grading plan and in no
case shall be extended closer than three feet (3') from the rear or side
property line. Sump pumps may not discharge to the front yard or exterior side
yard unless specifically approved by the village engineer and, regardless of
the permitted location, may not cause a nuisance or hazard to neighboring
properties or public right-of- ways.
   Section R405.2 Wood Foundations. Delete in its entirety.
   Section R406.3 Dampproofing For Wood Foundations. Delete in its entirety.
   Section R407 Columns. Amend by adding the following new section R407.4:
      Section R407.4 Porches And Terraces. Wooden post supports for porches and
decks constructed six feet (6') or more above grade, as measured to the top of
the finished deck floor, shall be no less than six inch by six inch (6" x 6")
nominal lumber. All lumber used for the exterior construction of porches,
terraces and decks shall be naturally durable wood or pressure treated wood.
   Section R408 Under-Floor Space. Amend by adding the following new section
R408.8:
      Section R408.8 Covering. In crawl spaces, the soil shall be leveled, and
covered with a minimum 6 mil polyethylene or approved vapor retarder with
joints lapped not less than six inches (6"). The polyethylene or approved vapor
retarder shall then be covered with a minimum of a two inch (2") screed coat of
concrete.
      Crawlspaces shall be ground level at least twenty-four inches (24") below
bottom of floor joists and girders. Ground under dwelling is to be
approximately level.
   Section R408.4 Access. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof substitute
the following new section R408.4:
      Section R408.4 Access. Provide an access of not less than twenty-four
inches by twenty-four inches (24" x 24").
   Section R502.2.1 Decks. Amend by adding the following new section
R502.2.1.1:
      Section R502.2.1.1 Cantilevered Decks. Decks shall have a maximum
cantilever of two feet (2').
   Section R502.3.1 Sleeping Areas And Attic Joists. Delete in its entirety and
in lieu thereof substitute the following new section R502.3.1:
      Section R502.3.1 Sleeping Areas And Attic Joists. Table R502.3.1(2) shall
be utilized to determine the maximum allowable span of floor joists that
support sleeping areas and attics that are accessed by means of a fixed
stairway provided that the design load does not exceed forty pounds per square
foot (40 lbs. psf) and the design dead load does not exceed ten pounds per
square foot (10 psf). The allowable span of ceiling joists that support attics
utilized for limited storage or no storage shall be determined in accordance
with section R802.4.
   Section R502.4 Joists Under Bearing Partitions. Amend by adding the
following new section R502.4.1:
      Section R502.4.1 Joists Below Bathtubs. The number of joists which
support and run parallel to the length of a bathtub shall be doubled.
   Section R502.11 Wood Trusses. Amend by adding the following new section
R502.11.5:
      Section R502.11.5 Sheathing Required. Engineered trusses and joists used
in floor construction must be fully sheathed on the underside with minimum
five-eighths inch (5/8") type X gypsum board or equivalent.
      Exemption:
      1.   Fully sprinklered structures.
   Section R504 Pressure Preservatively Treated-Wood Floors (On Ground). Delete
in its entirety.
   Section R506.2.2 Base. Amend by deleting the exception in its entirety and
adding the following new sections R506.2.2.1 and R506.2.2.2:
      Section R506.2.2.1 Grade Beams. Grade beam construction permitted
consisting of a four inch (4") concrete floor on a minimum four inches (4") of
crushed stone, sand and gravel poured monolithically with a minimum ten inches
(10") thickened outer edge a width of twenty inches (20") around perimeter of
building, said twenty inch (20") grade beam to be of equal depth on undisturbed
soil.
      Section R506.2.2.2 Gas Curb. All common walls between the garage and
dwelling, including any openings for service doors, shall have a six inch (6")
gas curb, or be made gas tight.
   Section R703.2 Weather Resistant Sheathing Paper. Delete the exception in
its entirety.
   Section R801.3 Roof Drainage. Amend by adding the following section
R801.3.1.
   Section R801.3.1 Gutters And Downspouts. All structures over one hundred
fifty (150) square feet in area shall be provided with gutters and downspouts
along all roof edges located parallel to the grade below unless omission is
specifically permitted by the building official. Downspouts must discharge away
from the building in accordance with the approved grading plans, and the
discharge shall not cause a nuisance or damage to neighboring properties.
   Exception: Drainage from accessory buildings must discharge on a splash
block.
   Section R803.2.2Allowable spans. Delete in its entirety and add the
following section.
   Section R803.2.2 The maximum allowable spans for wood structural panel roof
sheathing shall not exceed the values set forth in Table R503.2.1.1(1) or APA
E30. But in no case shall the sheathing be less than ½" nominal in thickness.
   Section R1004 Factory-Built Fireplaces. Amend by adding the following new
section R1005.9:
      Section R1004.5 Fireplace Chimney Enclosures. All exposed exterior
chimney sections, shall be enclosed in a chimney chase which provides for
proper clearances per manufacturer's requirements and is constructed of masonry
or approved materials consistent with the construction of the existing
structure.
   Section M1401 General. Amend by adding the following section M1401.6:
      Section M1401.6 Solid Fuel-Burning Heaters. Solid fuel- burning heaters
are prohibited.
   Section M1601.1.1 Above-Ground Duct Systems. Amend by adding the following
additional language:
      8.   On all residential developments, flexible metallic air ducts may be
used only where practical difficulties are encountered, subject to review and
approval by the building official prior to installation. In other use groups,
the maximum length shall not exceed fourteen feet (14').
   Section G2414.1 General. Amend by adding the following new section
G2414.1.1:
      Section G2414.1.1 Interior Fuel Gas Piping Materials. All interior gas
supply and distribution piping shall be black iron.
   Section G2445.2 Prohibited Use. Amend by adding the following section
G2445.2.1:
      Section G2445.2.1 Approval. Unvented appliances, including unvented
fireplaces, shall be allowed only by special permission of the building
official.
   Section E3406.3 Minimum Size Of Conductors. Delete in its entirety and in
lieu thereof substitute the following new section E3406.3:
      Section E3406.3 Minimum Size Of Conductors. The minimum size of
conductors for feeders and branch circuits shall be no. 14 copper. All
conductors used for feeders, branch circuits and service entrance conductors
must be copper.
   Section E3602.1 Ampacity Of Ungrounded Conductors. Delete in its entirety
and in lieu thereof substitute the following new section E3602.1:
      Section E3602.1 Minimum Size Of Residential Service.
      - two hundred (200) amp, thirty (30) circuit panel, for new construction,
no. 3/0 AWG minimum conductor size.
   Section E3603.2 Ungrounded Service Connectors For Accessory Buildings And
Structures. Delete in its entirety.
   Section E3703 Required Branch Circuits. Amend by adding the following
section E3703.8:
      Section E3703.8 Branch Circuits For Additional Equipment. The following
additional separate, individual branch circuits shall be required as needed:
      1.   Central air conditioning system.
      2.   Electric range.
         a.   Free standing ranges, wired in accordance with this code, but not
less than two (2) number 6 and one (1) number 8 minimum size copper conductors.
         b.   Built-in counter top and oven units, wired in accordance with
this code, but not less than three number 10 (minimum) copper conductors.
      3.   Built-in microwave oven.
      4.   Through wall air conditioners and heating units.
      5.   Motors of one-half (1/2) horsepower or larger.
      6.   Electric water heaters.
      7.   Electric dryers.
      8.   Sump pump.
      9.   Sanitary ejector pump.
      10.   Central vacuum system.
   Section E3704.2 Minimum Feeder Conductor Size. Delete in its entirety.
   Section E3802 Above-Ground Installation Requirements. Delete in its entirety
and in lieu thereof substitute the following new section E3802:
      Section E3802 Aboveground Installation Requirements. For all new
construction, wiring shall be installed in rigid metallic pipe or tubing.
Surface metal raceways may be used for lighting purposes only. Where flexible
connections are necessary, a separate ground wire shall be pulled in all
flexible conduit. Armored cable (type AC) such as BX shall not be used,
including garage and/or other accessory buildings. All raceway joints shall be
made tight and shall provide a continuous electrical circuit for grounding
purposes.
   Section E3904.7 Air Handling - Stud Cavity And Joist Spaces. Delete in its
entirety. Section E3905.3 Nonmetallic Boxes. Delete in its entirety.

2023)
ARTICLE D. NONRESIDENTIAL AND MULTI-FAMILY BUILDING CODE
SECTION:
8-1D-1: Code Adopted
8-1D-2: Amendments To Code
8-1D-3: Automatic Fire Suppression Systems
8-1D-4: Public Safety Wireless Communication Networks
8-1D-1: CODE ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted by reference as if fully set out herein governing the
construction of all nonresidential and multi-family structures, that certain
Code known as the International Building Code, 2021, second printing, as
prepared and published by the International Code Council, Inc., together with
the additions, insertions, deletions and changes hereinafter set forth, one (1)
copy of which has been for a period of more than thirty (30) days prior to the
effective date hereof and now is on file in the Office of the Village Clerk.
(Ord. 2013-29, 6-13-2013; amd. Ord. 2023-36, 11-2-2023)
8-1D-2: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
The following additions, insertions, deletions and changes are hereby made to
the International Building Code, 2021, second printing:
   A.   Amendments:
   Section 101.1 Title. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 101.4 Amend by adding the following new section 101.4.8:
      Section 101.4.8 Electrical. All references within this code to the ICC
electrical code shall be changed to read, "The National Electrical Code/2020,
prepared and published by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc.". The
provisions of the national electrical code shall apply to the installation,
alteration, repair and replacement of electrical systems, including equipment,
appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances thereto.
   Section 101.4.3 Plumbing. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute with the following new section 101.4.3 Plumbing:
      Section 101.4.3 Plumbing. All references within this code to the
international plumbing code shall be changed to read, "The Illinois Plumbing
Code/as currently adopted, prepared and published by the state of Illinois
department of public health". The provisions of the Illinois Plumbing Code
shall apply to the installation, alteration, repair and replacement of plumbing
systems, including appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances thereto.
   Section 104.11 Alternative materials, designed and methods of construction
and equipment. Amend by adding the following new item number 3:
      3.   [in addition to No.'s 1 and 2] Copies of the system design from
Underwriters Laboratories (UL) or other approved, independent testing agency
shall be submitted to the village, or be made a part of the construction plans
submitted to the village, for all required fire-resistance-rated assemblies and
firestop systems.
   Section 105 PERMITS. Amended by adding the following new section 105.1.1
Workmanship:
      Section 105.1.1 Workmanship. Repairs, maintenance work, alterations or
installations which are caused directly or indirectly by the enforcement of
this code shall be executed and installed in a workmanlike manner and installed
in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
   Section 105.2 Work exempt from permit. Delete in its entirety. Section 105.5
Expiration. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 111.2 Certificate issued. Delete in its entirety. Section 113 Board
of appeals. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 306.3 Factory industrial F-2 low-hazard occupancy. Amend by adding
the following new section 306.3.1 Classification:
      Section 306.3.1 Classification to F-1 moderate-hazard occupancy. The
designation "group F-2" shall be deleted. All factory industrial uses and
occupancies classified as group F-2 shall be classified as group F-1.
Requirements of this code specified for factory industrial group F-1 shall
apply to all factory industrial use and occupancies.
   Section 311.3 Low-hazard storage, group S-2. Amend by adding the following
new section 311.3.1 Classification to moderate-hazard storage, Group S-1:
      Section 311.3.1 Classification to moderate-hazard storage, Group S-1. The
designation "group S-2" shall be deleted. All storage uses and occupancies
classified as group S-2 shall be classified as group S-1. Requirements of this
code for storage group S-1 shall apply to all storage use and occupancies.
   Section 403.3 Automatic Sprinkler System. Delete exception in its entirety.
   Section 406.3.2.1 Dwelling unit separation. Delete in its entirety and in
lieu thereof substitute with the following new section 406.3.2.1 Dwelling unit
separation:
      Section 406.3.2.1 Dwelling unit separation. The private garage shall be
separated from the dwelling unit and its attic area by a minimum 1-hour rated
fire barrier using minimum five-eighths inch (5/8") Type X or equivalent gypsum
wallboard on all walls and ceilings. Door openings between a private garage and
a dwelling unit shall be equipped with either solid wood doors or solid or
honeycomb core steel doors not less than 1-3/8 inches in thickness, or doors in
compliance with Section 716.2.2.1 with a fire protection rating of not less
than 20 minutes. Doors shall be self-closing and self-latching. Openings from a
private garage directly into a room used for sleeping purposes shall not be
permitted.
   Section 406.3.2.2 Ducts. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute with the following new section 406.3.2.2 Ducts:
      406.3.2.2 Ducts. Ducts in a private garage and ducts penetrating the
walls or ceilings separating the dwelling unit from the garage shall be
encapsulated in construction equal to that of those walls and ceilings, and
shall have no openings into the garage.
   Section 406.5.3 Mixed occupancies and uses. Delete in its entirety and in
lieu thereof substitute with the following new section 406.5.3 Mixed
occupancies and uses:
      Section 406.5.3 Mixed occupancies and uses. Parking garages shall be
separated from other occupancies and uses in accordance with section 302.1, but
in no case shall the separation be less than a 1-hour rated fire barrier.
   Section 503.1 General. Delete in its entirety (not inclusive of subsections
503.1.1, 503.1.2, 503.1.3 and 503.1.4) and in lieu thereof substitute with the
following new Section 503.1 General:
      Section 503.1 General. The height and area for buildings of different
construction types shall be governed by the intended use of the building, and
shall not exceed the limits in Table 504.3 and Table 506.2 except as modified
hereafter. Each part of a building included within the exterior walls or the
exterior walls and fire walls where provided shall be permitted to be a
separate building.
      Exceptions:
      1.   Type III, VA and VB construction is prohibited for all new
construction other than use group R-3 structures.
      2.   Existing buildings of type 5 construction may be converted to use
group B only, provided the structure does not exceed two (2) stories in height,
and the gross floor area does not exceed twenty-two hundred (2,200) square
feet. Such buildings shall be equipped with an approved fire alarm system
interconnected to an approved location providing 24-hour supervision of alarm
and system trouble, and shall comply with the current Illinois Accessibility
Code as if new construction.
   Section 505.2.3 Openness. Delete exception 5 in its entirety. Section 507.3
Nonsprinklered, one story. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 507.4 Sprinklered, one story. Delete exception 1 in its entirety.
Section 507.5 Two-story buildings. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 509.4 Separation and protection. Delete in its entirety and in lieu
thereof substitute with the following new section 509.4 Separation and
protection:
      Section 509.4 Separation and protection. All rooms and areas listed under
the column "Separation and/or protection" in Table 509.1 shall require the
installation of the fire-resistance-rated separation indicated, and shall be
protected with an approved fire suppression system.
   Section 602.3 Type III. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute with the following new section 602.3 Type III:
      Section 602.3 Type III. Type III construction is that type of
construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and
the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code.
Fire-retardant-treated wood framing complying with section 2303.2 shall be
permitted within exterior wall assemblies with a 2-hour rating or less. Type
III construction shall be permitted for use group R-3 structures only.
   Section 602.5 Type V. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof substitute
with the following new section 602.5 Type V:
      Section 602.5 Type V. Type V construction is that type of construction in
which the structural elements, exterior walls, and interior walls are of any
materials permitted by this code. Type V construction shall be permitted for
use group R-3 structures only.
   Section 708.4.2 Fireblocks and draftstops in combustible construction.
Delete exception no. 3, no. 4 and no. 5 in their entirety.
   Section 721 PRESCRIPTIVE FIRE RESISTANCE. Delete in its entirety. Section
722 CALCULATED FIRE RESISTANCE. Delete in its entirety. Section 903.2 Where
required. Delete exception in its entirety.
   Section 903.2.1 Group A. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute with the following new section 903.2.1 Group A:
      Section 903.2.1 Group A. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided
throughout all buildings containing a group A occupancy.
      Section 903.2.1.1 Group A-1. Delete in its entirety.
      Section 903.2.1.2 Group A-2. Delete in its entirety.
      Section 903.2.1.3 Group A-3. Delete in its entirety.
      Section 903.2.1.4 Group A-4. Delete in its entirety.
      Section 903.2.1.5 Group A-5. Delete in its entirety.
      Section 903.2.1.6 Assembly occupancies on roofs.
      Section 903.2.1.7 Multiple fire areas. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 903.2.2 Ambulatory care facilities. Amend section by deleting the
Exception.
   Section 903.2.3 Group E. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof

      Section 903.2.3 Group E. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided

   Section 903.2.4 Group F-1. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof

      Section 903.2.4 Group F. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided

   Section 903.2.4.1 Woodworking Operations. Delete in its entirety. Section

   Section 903.2.5.1 General. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof

      Section 903.2.5.1 General. An automatic sprinkler system shall be
provided throughout all buildings containing a group H occupancy.
   Section 903.2.7 Group M. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof

   Section 903.2.9 Group S-1. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof

   Section 903.2.9.1 Repair Garages. Delete in its entirety. Section 903.2.9.2

   Section 903.2.9.3 Group S-1 Distilled spirits or wine. Delete in its

   Section 903.2.9.4 Group S-1 Upholstered furniture and mattresses. Delete in

   Section 903.2.10 Group S-2. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof

      Section 903.2.10 Group S-2. An automatic sprinkler system shall be
provided throughout all buildings containing a group S-2 occupancy.
   Section 903.2.10.1 Commercial Parking Garages. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 903.2.11 Specific building areas and hazards. Delete in its entirety
and in lieu thereof substitute with the following new section 903.2.11 Specific
building areas and hazards:
      Section 903.2.11 Specific building areas and hazards. An automatic
sprinkler system shall be installed for building design or hazards and provided
throughout all buildings containing any Use Group other than U. For Use Group
R-3 refer to the IRC section 313.
   Section 903.2.11.1 Stories without openings. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 903.2.11.1.1 Opening dimensions and access. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 903.2.11.1.2 Openings on one side only. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 903.2.11.1.3 Basements. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 903.2.11.3 Buildings over 55 feet in height. Delete in its entirety.
   Section 903.3 Installation requirements. Delete in its entirety and in lieu
thereof substitute with the following new section 903.3 Installation
requirements:
      Section 903.3 Installation requirements. Automatic sprinkler systems
shall be designed and installed in accordance with sections 903.3.1 through
903.3.8, except that flexible sprinkler pipe or tubing shall be prohibited.
   Section 903.3.1.1.1 Exempt Locations. Delete subsection 3 of section
903.3.1.1.1 in its entirety and in lieu thereof substitute with the following
new subsection 3:
      3.   Generator and transformer rooms separated from the remainder of the
building by walls and floor/ceiling assemblies or roof/ceiling assemblies
having a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2 hours, when approved in
writing by the Building Official.
   Section 903.3.1.1.1 Exempt Locations. Delete subsection 4 of section
903.3.1.1.1 in its entirety and in lieu thereof substitute with the following
new subsection 4:
      4.   In rooms or areas that are of noncombustible construction with
wholly non-combustible contents when approved in writing by the Building
Official.
   Section 903.1.1.2 Bathrooms. Delete in its entirety and in lieu thereof
substitute with the following new section 903.1.1.2 Bathrooms:

automatic fire alarm system shall be provided in all new buildings, other than
buildings of group U. For use group R-3 refer to section 313 of the IRC as

fire alarm system and smoke detection system shall be provided in accordance

installed in accordance with section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 is provided and

      An approved automatic fire detection system shall be installed in

of devices, appliances and equipment shall comply with section 907.1.2. The
automatic fire detectors shall be smoke detectors, except that an approved
alternative type of detector shall be installed in spaces such as boiler rooms
where, during normal operation, products of combustion are present in
sufficient quantity to actuate a smoke detector. In all cases, rate-of-rise
type heat detectors are prohibited for use in guest rooms and dwelling units.
      All wiring in non-accessible areas shall be installed in electrical
metallic tubing but may be run exposed in accessible areas over eight feet (8')
above finished floor such as, but not limited to, spaces above dropped
ceilings, attic spaces, and crawl spaces; all said tubing must be properly
fastened.

   Section 1006.2.1 Egress based on occupant load and common path of egress

      Section 1017.2.2 Groups F-1 and S-1 Increase Exception: The maximum exit
access travel distance may be increased to 400 feet for buildings with a
ceiling height of less than 24 ft., where the portion of the building
classified as Group F-1 or S-1 is equipped with an Early Suppression Fast
Response (ESFR) fire sprinkler system and Mechanical Smoke Exhaust as outlined
and installed in accordance with Chapter 9 Section 910.4 of the 2015
International Fire Code, as modified by Appendix A of this Chapter. For one
story buildings ceiling height of 24 ft. or greater height reference Chapter 10
Section 1017.2.2 of the 2021 International Fire Code. A smoke study
commissioned and paid for by the building owner may be submitted for approval
to allow a 400-foot travel distance for buildings less than 24 feet in height.
The smoke study shall prove favorably that the smoke will not go below the six-
foot interface level during the travel time established by the study. The study
shall include six fire scenarios and include all documentations and
calculations to substantiate the time and distance.

   Chapter 29 Plumbing Systems. Delete in its entirety.
   B.   Tenant Separation: Minimum required fire rating for tenant separation
assemblies is one (1) hour. (See IBC table 508.4 for fire resistant
requirements for mixed use separations.) In unlimited area buildings, tenant
spaces shall be separated by a minimum of a two (2) hour assembly.
   C.   Groups R-1 and R-2; Additional Requirements: The following additional
requirements apply to structures of IBC Use Groups R-1 and R-2:
      1.   Firewall assemblies shall have a minimum of a three (3) hour rating.
Firewall assemblies may be used to separate up to a maximum of three (3)
buildings.
      2.   Dwelling units and guestrooms shall have a minimum fire separation
of one (1) hour. Separation shall be a fire barrier.
      3.   Building storage rooms, meeting rooms and attached parking garages
shall have a minimum fire separation of two (2) hours. Separation shall be a
fire barrier.
      4.   Mechanical ventilation systems for attached parking garages shall be
independent from the building ventilation system.
   D.   Group R-3; Additional Requirements: The following additional
requirements apply to structures of IBC Use Group R-3:
      1.   In side by side construction, firewall assemblies may be used to
separate up to a maximum of three (3) buildings.
      2.   Over and under construction shall be limited to a maximum of four
(4) dwelling units per building.
      3.   Dwelling units shall have a minimum vertical fire separation of a
two (2) hour fire barrier. The vertical fire separation must extend to the roof
deck, and the roof sheathing must be fire retardant treated on either side for
a minimum distance of four feet (4'). The treated sheathing must extend at
least to the next farthest rafter on alternating sheets. Roof covering
materials shall be Class A or Class B.
      4.   Construction and insulation requirements shall comply with the
provisions set forth in article C of this chapter. Automatic fire detection
system requirements shall comply with the provisions set forth in article I of
this chapter. The height and area limitations set forth in Sections 504 and 506
of the International Building Code as adopted, and the fire resistance rating
of structural elements set forth in Tables 601 and 705.5 of the International
Building Code as adopted, and elsewhere in this Code, shall be employed in the
design of all buildings of Use Group R-3.
   E.   Unlimited Area Buildings; Additional Requirements: The following
additional requirements apply to unlimited area buildings:
      1.   Office spaces two thousand (2,000) square feet and larger in
buildings of Use Groups S and F shall be separated from the warehouse area with
a minimum floor to roof deck fire barrier of no less than one (1) hour.
      2.   Perimeter doors shall be installed in all new unlimited area
buildings at intervals not to exceed one hundred fifty feet (150'). Alternate
methods for positive smoke ventilation and Fire department entry shall be
subject to the approval of the Building Official.
   F.   Buildings Exceeding Four Thousand (4,000) Square Feet: On all buildings
exceeding four thousand (4,000) square feet, roof coverings shall be a minimum
of class A or B.
   G.   Type 3 And Type 5 Construction; Additional Requirements: The following
additional requirements apply to buildings of type 3 and type 5 construction:
      1.   Wooden structural support columns for balconies shall be no less
than six inch by six inch (6" x 6") nominal lumber when over six feet (6') in
height.
      2.   Open frame wood trusses used in floor construction must be sheathed
on the underside and shall be divided into areas no greater than five hundred
(500) square feet by draft stopping parallel to the main framing members. Draft
stopping materials shall not be less than one-half inch (1/2") gypsum board,
three-eighths inch (3/8") plywood or other approved materials adequately
supported.
      3.   Each new stair, platform, and landing used in buildings three (3) or
more stories in height shall be of noncombustible materials throughout.
   H.   Elevator Enclosures: Elevator and hoistway enclosures shall be
constructed of concrete or masonry materials providing a fire resistance rating
of not less than two (2) hours.
   I.   Fence And Dumpster Support Posts: Fence and dumpster enclosure support
posts shall be installed to a minimum depth of forty-two inches (42"). (Ord.
2013-29, 6-13-2013; amd. Ord. 2017-51, 9-21-2017; Ord. 2023-36, 11-2-2023)
8-1D-3: AUTOMATIC FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEMS:
An automatic fire suppression system shall be installed and maintained in full
operating condition, as specified in the International Building Code referenced
above, and throughout the entire building or structure as modified below:
   A.   In all existing construction in which:
      1.   The cost of remodeling or reconstruction exceeds twenty five percent
(25%) of the value of the building or structure in any five (5) year period;
      2.   The height of the building or structure is enlarged; or
      3.   The floor area of the building or structure is enlarged in excess of
five hundred (500) square feet. (Ord. 2013-29, 6-13-2013; amd. Ord. 2023-36,
11-2-2023)
8-1D-4: PUBLIC SAFETY WIRELESS COMMUNICATION NETWORKS:
   A.   Purpose: The purpose of this section is to promote, protect and
safeguard the public safety, health and welfare of the citizens of Woodridge by
ensuring the uninterrupted operation of the village's wireless communication
networks used for public safety, police and fire, law enforcement, and other
emergency related activities.
   B.   Definitions: For this section, the following definitions shall apply:
   ADEQUATE RADIO COVERAGE: A minimum of ninety percent (90%) of each floor of
a building shall be able to receive a minimum signal strength of one microvolt
when transmitted from village communication networks and specifically also to
accommodate village two-way wireless communications from such locations within
a building to a location outside of said building; the frequency range must be
supportable for village police department communications and shall be at least
from seven hundred sixty four (764) MHz to eight hundred sixty nine (869) MHz,
and one hundred fifty (150) MHz to one hundred fifty five (155) MHz, or as
otherwise required by the chief of police.
   BUILDING: Any multi-family residential or nonresidential structure, or any
part thereof, including underground floors.
   C.   Frequency and level specifications: Except as otherwise provided, no
person shall erect, construct or modify any building or cause the same to be
done which fails to support adequate radio coverage.
   D.   Owner's responsibility: It shall be the responsibility of any building
owner who currently holds a certificate of occupancy or allows the building to
be used for any purpose other than construction to be in compliance with this
section.
   E.   Testing Procedures:
      1.   Initial testing and compliance: If a building is believed to fail to
support adequate radio coverage, the building owner shall contact the chief of
police who shall have conducted a test of the building to determine whether or
not the building supports adequate radio coverage, as follows:
         a.   Each floor of the building shall be divided into a grid of
approximately twenty (20) equal grid areas.
         b.   A center spot located approximately in the center of each grid
area will be selected, which, once selected, cannot be changed.
         c.   Portable radios of the type the village police department
utilizes will be "keyed" to verify two-way communications between the center
spot of each grid area and the outside of the building.
         d.   If such communications are verified for a given grid area, that
grid area will be counted as passed, and if not, it will be counted as failed.
         e.   In the event that three (3) or more grid areas fail, the building
will be considered preliminarily failed.
         f.   Upon a preliminary test failure, each floor of the building may
be divided into forty (40) equal grid areas and the test repeated. In the event
that five (5) or more grid areas then fail, the building will have failed the
test.
         g.   If the building fails the test, the building owner shall install
a radio amplifier system in the building as described in subsection F of this
section and then schedule to have the building retested until it is shown to
provide adequate radio coverage. A building with a radio amplifier system will
not be considered in compliance with this section unless, in addition to
providing adequate radio coverage, the building also passes the radio amplifier
system test described in subsections F.1. through F.4. of this section.
      2.   Five (5) year testing: Once a building is shown to support adequate
radio coverage, the building owner shall contact the chief of police to arrange
for a radio coverage test as set forth in subsection E.1. of this section at
least once every five (5) years to ensure that the building continues to comply
with this section. However, if the building is modified, expanded, or otherwise
structurally altered, or if the building owner believes that the building may
not be in compliance, the building owner shall contact the chief of police at
that time to arrange for such test to be conducted.
   F.   In-building radio amplifier system: If any building fails to support
adequate radio coverage, or whenever a building without an in-building radio
amplifier system fails to pass the test set forth in this section, then its
owner shall, within ninety (90) days of failing the test, provide to the chief
of police a plan illustrating how the building will be modified to support
adequate radio coverage by installing or modifying a radio amplifier system
within the building. Review and approval of the plan may be extended by the
Chief of Police. The building owner shall enact the plan within one year after
its approval and the building shall be retested upon completion of such
installation.
   The radio amplifier system may include any of the following to achieve the
required adequate radio coverage: radiating cable system, internal multiple
antenna system with eight hundred (800) MHz and one hundred fifty (150) MHz
amplification system, or any combination thereof. If any part of the installed
system contains an electrically powered component, the system shall be capable
of operating on an independent battery and/or generator system for a period of
at least two (2) hours without external power input. The battery system shall
automatically charge in the presence of an external power input.
   When a radio amplifier system is installed, the building owner shall cause a
technician in possession of a current FCC license, or a technician certified by
the Associated Public-Safety Communications Officials International (APCO), to
test all active components of the system, including, but not limited to,
amplifiers, power supplies and backup batteries, initially in conjunction with
a test to establish that the building supports adequate radio coverage, and
subsequently at least once every twelve (12) months thereafter, as follows:
      1.   Amplifiers shall be tested and gain levels measured upon initial
installation and acceptance; gain levels shall be measured as part of
subsequent tests to ensure that they remain the same as that found upon initial
installation and acceptance.
      2.   Backup batteries and power supplies shall be tested under load for a
period of one hour to verify that they will properly operate during an actual
power outage. If within the one hour test period, in the opinion of the testing
technician, the battery exhibits symptoms of failure, the test shall be
extended for additional one hour periods until the testing technician confirms
the integrity of the battery.
      3.   All other active components shall be checked to determine that they
are operating within the manufacturer's specifications for the intended
purpose.
      4.   The technician who performed the test shall prepare a written report
documenting the test findings and all measurements. The building owner shall
provide to the chief of police a copy of the test findings within ten (10) days
of the completion of testing and shall maintain a copy on file within the
building.
   The building owner shall be responsible for all maintenance and repair of
any system installed to comply with this section. Every building owner with a
system installed to comply with this section shall provide to the chief of
police the following contact information:
      a.   The name, address, and telephone number of the maintenance
contractor who will supply a twenty-four (24) hour, seven (7) day emergency
response to the building within two (2) hours after notification by either the
village or the building owner in order to repair the in-building system; and
      b.   The name, address, and telephone number of the primary contact
personnel for the building owner.
   G.   Routine inspection upon notice: Police department personnel, at any
time after providing reasonable notice to the building owner or his
representative, shall have the right to enter onto the property and into the
building to conduct a radio coverage test to confirm compliance with this
section. (Ord. 2013-29, 6-13-2013; amd. Ord. 2023-36, 11-2-2023)
