      2.   In the event a subdivider or developer files a written objection to
the Table of Estimated Ultimate Population listed herein, he shall submit his
own demographic study showing the estimated additional population to be
generated from the subdivision, planned unit development, or regional planned
unit development and in that event final determination of the density formula
to be used in such calculations shall be made by the Village Board based upon
such demographic information submitted by the subdivider or developer and from
other sources which may be submitted to the Village Board by the park
districts, school districts, or others. It is recognized that population
density, age distribution, and local conditions change over the years, and the
specific formula for the dedication of land, or the payment of fees in lieu
thereof, as stated herein, is subject to periodic review and amendment if
necessary.
   E.   Reservation Of Additional Land: Where the Comprehensive Plan of the
Village calls for a larger amount of park and recreational land or school sites
in a particular proposed subdivision, planned unit development, or regional
planned unit development than the subdivider or developer is required to
dedicate, the land needed beyond the subdivider's or developer's contribution
shall, if so determined by the Village Board, be reserved for subsequent
purchase by the Village or other public body designated by the Village provided
that such acquisition is made within one year from the date of approval of the
final plat or plan.
   F.   Combining With Adjoining Developments: Where the subdivision, planned
unit development, or regional planned unit development is less than forty (40)
acres, public open space or a school site which is to be dedicated should,
where possible, be combined with dedications from adjoining developments in
order to produce usable recreation areas or school sites without hardship on a
particular developer.
   G.   Topography And Grading: The slope, topography and geology of the
dedicated site as well as its surroundings must be suitable for its intended
purposes. Grading on sites dedicated for park and recreational uses shall not
differ greatly from surrounding land. (Ord. 94-72, 10-13-1994)
   H.   Improved Sites: All sites shall be dedicated as improved sites, i.e.,
in a finished graded, seeded and/or sodded condition with appropriate storm
water management and erosion control systems and ready for full service of
streets (including, but not limited to, pavement, curbs, gutters, sidewalks,
street trees and streetlights), sewers, water, and electrical and other
utilities, or acceptable provisions made therefor. All required improvements to
sites, including, but not limited to, finished grading, seeding and/or sodding,
storm water management and erosion control systems, streets, sewers, water and
electrical and other utilities shall be completed prior to issuance of any
building permits in excess of fifty percent (50%) of the building permits for
the subdivision, planned unit development or regional planned unit development,
but not later than two (2) years after the initial final plat approval for the
subdivision, planned unit development or regional planned unit development. If
the required improvements for a site are not completed at the time of
dedication due to the delay in time between dedication of any such school or
park sites and construction of school or park facilities thereon, the
subdivider or developer shall provide the school or park district accepting the
site with funds sufficient to complete the required improvements. (Ord. 98-22,
4-23-1998)
   I.   Title To Sites: All sites shall be conveyed to the Village either by
warranty or trustee's deed. The sites shall be conveyed prior to issuance of
any building permits in excess of fifty percent (50%) of the building permits
for the subdivision, but not later than two (2) years after the initial final
plat approval for the development. The subdivider or developer shall be
responsible for conveying good, merchantable title to such sites, and shall be
responsible for payment of all real estate taxes to the date of conveyance,
including any agricultural rollback taxes which might be extended or levied
against such sites for any tax years or periods prior to the time of
conveyance. (Ord. 94-72, 10-13-1994; amd. Ord. 98-22, 4-23-1998)
   J.   Dedicated Land Sold; Trust Established: When, in the opinion of the
unit of local government holding title to any parcel of land dedicated under
this Section, any such parcel has become unnecessary or unsuitable or
inconvenient, such parcel may be sold as provided by applicable statutory
authority and the proceeds shall be held in trust by said unit of local
government, solely for such uses as are provided for in subsection
10-5-12C of this Section, and said proceeds shall be subject to the ten (10)
year expenditure requirements from and after the date when said land is
converted to cash proceeds. (Ord. 94-72, 10-13-1994)

   B.   Standard Specifications: Before a subdivision shall be approved, the
village engineer shall certify that the improvements described in the
subdivider's plans and specifications, together with agreements, meet the
minimum requirements of all ordinances of the village and that they comply with
the following: (1976 Code §16-86)
Unless otherwise specified, all construction work shall be in accordance with
the provisions of the current issue of the standard specifications for road and
bridge construction adopted January 2, 1958, by the Illinois department of
transportation, as the same is amended from time to time and hereinafter
referred to as the standard specifications. Unless otherwise specified, design
standards shall be as specified in the current issue of the manual "Highway
Standards" as published by the Illinois department of transportation bureau of
design and environment, as the same is amended from time to time and
hereinafter referred to as highway standards. (1976 Code §16-86; amd. Ord.
2002-23, 5-23-2002)
   C.   Record Drawings; Deviations: Prior to final approval of improvements 1
, the subdivider shall submit one complete set of twenty four inch by thirty
six inch (24" x 36") mylar drawings, and reproducible drawings in the scanned
digital format as TIFF (tag image file format) or equivalent approved by the
village engineer, accurately depicting the location of all improvements
constructed. Additionally, at the discretion of the village engineer, drawings
may be required to be submitted in digital format as .DXF or .DWG (AutoCad)
files. Copies of same shall be submitted to all public bodies accepting sites
for public purposes within the subdivision.
No substantial deviations from the approved plans and specifications will be
allowed without the approval of the village board. Field changes may be allowed
by the village engineer. (Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
   D.   Inspections; Fee: All public improvements to be made under the
provisions of this chapter shall be inspected during the course of construction
by the village engineer or other competent person appointed by the village
board. The subdivider shall pay to the village, as and for the village's costs
for plan review, inspections and related inspection costs, the sum of one and
one-half percent (11/2%) of the cost of construction of the required public
improvements. (1976 Code §16-100)

10-5A-2: SANITARY SEWER CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
The standards and requirements found in this section govern the materials and
construction of sanitary sewers within the village. (1976 Code §16-142.10)
10-5A-2-1: APPLICATION AND INTERPRETATION:
These specifications cover pipe for sanitary sewers and service connections,
sewer fittings, manholes and all appurtenances normally used for sanitary sewer
collection systems. Special considerations will be covered in the detailed
plans and special provisions covering the proposed construction. Sanitary
sewers shall be installed in accordance with the provisions of the current
issue of the standard specifications for water and sewer main construction in
Illinois, and this code. In case of conflict, the village sanitary sewer
construction standards and other applicable ordinances of the village shall
take precedence and shall govern. (1976 Code §16-142.11; amd. Ord. 2002-23, 5-
23-2002)
10-5A-2-2: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Additional rules and regulations governing the construction of sanitary sewers
in the village are:
   A.   The restrictions, policies and instructions that may be adopted or
issued from time to time by the village.
   B.   The Illinois pollution control board regulations.
   C.   The environmental protection act 1 .
   D.   The rules and regulations set forth by the DuPage County public works
department. (1976 Code §16-142.12)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
10-5A-2-3: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
All sanitary sewage consisting of domestic and other waterborne wastes shall be
collected and conveyed in a sanitary sewer pipe system to a point of discharge
into an existing sanitary sewer system. No sanitary sewage shall be allowed to
enter any storm sewer system or discharged onto the ground or into receiving
streams without first being treated. (1976 Code §16-142.13)
   A.   Protection Of Water Mains: Water mains shall be protected in accordance
with the applicable Illinois pollution control board regulations and the
Illinois environmental protection agency, division of public water supplies,
technical policy statements. Wherever the sanitary sewer main, building service
sewer, or any storm drain crosses a water main, a minimum eighteen inches (18")
vertical separation shall be provided between the top of the lower pipe and the
bottom of the upper pipe. If an eighteen inch (18") vertical separation cannot
be maintained, the sanitary or storm sewer shall be constructed of ductile iron
pipe, or shall be totally encased in concrete for a minimum distance of ten
feet (10') on each side of the water main and be pressure tested to ensure
watertightness. (1976 Code §16-142.30)
   B.   Survey Lines And Grades: Survey lines and grade hubs shall be provided
by the engineer at maximum fifty foot (50') intervals and at all changes in
line and grade. All installations in excess of one hundred fifty (150) lineal
feet shall be horizontally and vertically controlled by the use of a laser
target device. (1976 Code §16-142.40)
   C.   Pipe Materials: Pipe material used in sanitary sewer construction,
unless otherwise specified, shall be SDR-26 (polyvinyl chloride) PVC pipe
conforming to ASTM D 3034, type PSM for sizes six inches (6") to fifteen inches
(15") and ASTM F-679-89 for sizes eighteen inches (18") to thirty six inches
(36"), or class 52 cement lined ductile iron pipe conforming to ANSI A 21.51
(AWWA C-151), with poly wrap. Selection of materials shall consider local
conditions such as character of industrial wastes, possibility of septicity,
soil characteristics, exceptionally heavy external loads, abrasion and similar
problems. (Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
   D.   Installation Of Pipe:
      1.   Depth Of Pipe Cover: All pipe shall be laid to a minimum depth of
five feet (5') measured from the existing or proposed ground surface to the top
of the pipe barrel unless specifically allowed otherwise, in special
circumstances by the village engineer. (1976 Code §16-142.41)
      2.   Pipe Bedding: Granular pipe bedding material or granular cradle
shall be required on all sanitary sewers installed in the village. Granular
pipe bedding shall be a minimum of four inches (4") in earth excavation and a
minimum of six inches (6") in rock excavation before the trench is backfilled
with granular material to six inches (6") over the top of the pipe per
Woodridge standard. The granular material shall conform in gradation to type A,
B or C listed in provisions of the current issue of the standard specifications
for water and sewer main construction in Illinois. (1976 Code §16-142.42; amd.
1991 Code; Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
      3.   Granular Backfill: All trenches for sanitary sewers falling under
and within two feet (2') of a proposed or existing paved surface shall be
backfilled with select granular material conforming to gradation types A or B
only as listed in provisions of the current issue of the standard
specifications for water and sewer main construction in Illinois. Selected
granular backfill shall be placed in uniform layers not exceeding six inches
(6") (loose measure) and compacted with mechanical equipment to ninety percent
(90%) maximum density in accordance with AASHO T-99. (1976 Code §16-142.43;
amd. Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
      4.   Handling Of Pipe: Sanitary sewer pipe shall be handled in a manner
that will prevent damage. Damaged or defective material on the job site shall
be rejected and replaced to the satisfaction of the village engineer. Methods
of construction conducive to the damage of sewer pipe shall be corrected when
called to the attention of the contractor. All pipe and fittings shall be
examined by the contractor above grade before placement in the trench. (1976
Code §16-142.50)
      5.   Laying Of Pipe:
         a.   Generally: Sanitary sewer pipe shall be laid true to line and
grade as set forth in provisions of the current issue of the standard
specifications for water and sewer main construction in Illinois. Dirt or other
foreign material shall be prevented from entering the pipe or pipe joint during
handling or laying operations and any pipe or fitting that has been installed
with dirt or foreign material in it shall be removed, cleaned and relaid. At
times when pipe laying is not in progress, the open end of the pipe shall be
closed with a watertight plug or by other means approved by the village
engineer to ensure absolute cleanliness inside the pipe. (1976 Code §16-142.60;
amd. Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
         b.   On Curves: The curvature of sanitary sewers is not allowed
unless, in the opinion of the village engineer, special circumstances dictate
otherwise. Pipe required to be laid on curved alignment shall be joined in
straight alignment and then deflected, joint by joint. Special care shall be
taken in blocking the pipe and in no case shall the degree of deflection exceed
manufacturer's recommendations for the respective pipe size, material and
barrel length. (1976 Code §16-142.61)
   E.   Sewer Connections: Sanitary sewer services shall be a minimum of six
inches (6") in diameter and connected to the sewer main with a manufactured wye
at a minimum angle of thirty degrees (30°) and a maximum angle of forty five
degrees (45°). Sanitary sewer services shall be extended to the property line
or building at a minimum gradient of one percent (1%). Sanitary sewer service
connections to sewer mains twelve feet (12') or more in depth shall be
constructed with a six inch (6") tee and riser and backfilled with select
granular material or encased in concrete at the option of the village engineer.
On a temporary basis, sanitary services may be terminated with a manufactured
plug, in which case the location shall be staked and an accurate record kept of
the distance from the nearest downstream manhole along the sewer main. Sanitary
sewer service connections to existing sewer mains shall be made with a tapping
machine and saddle tightly secured to the existing sanitary sewer. (1976 Code
§16-142.62)
   F.   Sanitary Sewer Manholes:
      1.   Location: Manholes shall be located at the junction of two (2)
sanitary sewer pipes or at any change in grade, alignment or size of pipe. The
maximum spacing of manholes shall be three hundred feet (300') or as approved
by the village engineer. (1976 Code §16-142.71)
      2.   Construction And Installation Regulations:
         a.   Manholes for sanitary sewers shall have a minimum inside diameter
of forty eight inches (48") and be constructed of precast portland cement
concrete units in accordance with provisions of the current issue of the
standard specifications for water and sewer main construction in Illinois, and
shall follow the village standards. (1976 Code §16-142.70; amd. Ord. 2002-23,
5-23-2002)
         b.   Sanitary manholes shall have poured in place or precast inverts
made to conform accurately to the sewer grades with smooth, well rounded
junctions and transitions satisfactory to the village engineer. If the invert
is to be poured in place, the sanitary sewer pipe shall be extended through the
manhole, the concrete poured and formed, and the pipe then broken or sawed out
through the manhole. It is preferred that the sewer pipe to manhole joint be a
flexible gasket or mechanical seal to ensure a leakproof joint. The complete
manhole shall be rigid, true to dimensions and watertight. (1976 Code §16-
142.72)
         c.   Manholes shall be furnished with a watertight frame and solid
cover conforming to the requirements of gray iron castings ASTM A 48 (the
manufacturer shall be specified on the approved plans) with the words "Sanitary
Sewer" imprinted on the cover in raised letters. Both the manhole frame and
cover shall have machined horizontal and vertical bearing surfaces. Pick holes
shall not create openings in the manhole cover. Manholes located in areas
subject to inundation shall be furnished with waterproof, bolt down frames and
covers conforming to the requirements of gray iron castings ASTM A 48 (the
manufacturer shall be specified on the approved plans). Manhole frames shall be
adjusted to proper grade utilizing reinforced, precast concrete rings; brick or
concrete blocks will not be allowed. Adjusting rings shall be securely sealed
to the cone section or top barrel section of the manhole using resilient,
flexible, nonhardening, preformed bituminous mastic material (Ram-Nek, or
approved equal). This mastic shall be applied in such a manner that no surface
water or ground water inflow can enter the manhole through gaps between the top
barrel section or cone section and the first adjusting ring, between adjusting
rings or between the last adjusting ring and the manhole frame. Up to twelve
inches (12") of adjusting rings may be installed on a given manhole; however,
no more than one 2-inch adjusting ring shall be used. Manhole steps on maximum
sixteen inch (16") centers shall be furnished with each manhole, securely
anchored in place true to vertical alignment, in accordance with the Woodridge
standard. (1976 Code §16-142.73; amd. Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
         d.   Drop manhole assemblies shall be provided at the junction of
sanitary sewers where the difference in grade exceeds two feet (2'). The entire
drop assembly shall be cast in concrete monolithically with the manhole barrel
section and shall follow Woodridge standard. (1976 Code §16-142.74)
      3.   Inspection Of Manholes: All manholes shall be thoroughly cleaned of
dirt and debris and all visible leakage eliminated before final inspection and
acceptance. (1976 Code §16-142.75)
   G.   Testing And Inspection Of Sanitary Sewers:
      1.   Low Air Pressure Tests:
         a.   Tests Required: All sanitary sewers twenty one inches (21") and
smaller including service lines shall pass a low pressure air test before
acceptance. In addition, the village engineer may, at his discretion, require
an exfiltration test as described in section 307.2 1  prior to final
acceptance. Sanitary sewers twenty four inches (24") and larger shall pass an
exfiltration test described in section 307.2 2  and be subject to a physical
inspection by the village engineer. All sanitary sewers eight inches (8") in
diameter or larger shall be televised. All testing and televising shall be
controlled by and is subject to the acceptance of the village. In addition to
the above, manholes are subject to physical inspection. All testing materials
and documents shall become the property of the village. (1976 Code §16-142.80)
         b.   Procedures And Requirements: The procedure for low pressure air
testing shall follow that set forth in provisions of the current issue of the
standard specifications for water and sewer construction in Illinois. All plugs
including those in sanitary services must be carefully braced to prevent
leakage and blowout. The line being tested shall be deemed acceptable when the
time taken for the one pound pressure drop is not less than that shown in the
enclosed table. (1976 Code §16-142.81)
      2.   Exfiltration Test Procedures And Requirements: The exfiltration test
shall be performed in the absence of ground water in accordance with the
following procedure:
         a.   Plug the upper and lower section of sewer main to be tested.
         b.   Fill the line and all manholes with water to a depth of four feet
(4') above the invert of the midpoint of the section being tested.
         c.   Let the water stand in the section of the sewer main being tested
for a period of twenty four (24) hours to allow for absorption and escape of
trapped air.
         d.   After a period of twenty four (24) hours has elapsed, refill the
section to its original depth.
         e.   After an additional one hour period has elapsed, refill the line
again to its original depth, recording the total amount of water necessary
(measured in gallons) for refill. (1976 Code §16-142.82)
         f.   Flexible thermoplastic pipe (PVC) shall be tested for excess
deflecting by pulling a "go - no go" mandrel through the pipe from manhole to
manhole. The mandrel shall be sized in accordance with section
31-1-11C(4), of the current issue of the standard specifications for water and
sewer main construction in Illinois. (Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
The amount of exfiltration shall not exceed two hundred (200) gallons per inch
of pipe diameter per mile per day, including all manholes and service lines.
The village engineer shall be the sole judge of the results. (1976 Code §16-
142.82)
      3.   Test Results: If the sanitary sewer installation fails to meet the
test requirements specified, the contractor shall determine the cause or causes
of the defect and shall, at his own expense, repair or replace all materials
and workmanship as may be necessary to comply with the test requirements. (1976
Code §16-142.83)
      4.   Certification: It shall be the responsibility of the pipe
manufacturer to certify that pipe and joint materials furnished are capable of
meeting the low pressure air tests, infiltration test and exfiltration test and
are manufactured in conformance with the ASTM, ANSI, AWWA or AASHO. (1976 Code
§16-142.90)
 
Notes
  1. Section 307.2 of the "Standard Specification for Water and Sewer Main
1 Construction in Illinois", as referred to in section
  10-5A-2-1 of this article.
  2. Section 307.2 of the "Standard Specification for Water and Sewer Main
2 Construction in Illinois", as referred to in section
  10-5A-2-1 of this article.
10-5A-3: STORM SEWER CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
The standards and requirements found in this section are for the materials and
constructing of storm sewer systems within the village. (1976 Code §16-143.10)
   A.   Scope Of Regulations; Specifications: These specifications cover
materials, construction and all appurtenances normally used for the
construction of a storm sewer system. Storm sewer systems shall be installed in
accordance with section 600 of "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction", as amended, and in accordance with the "Standard Specifications
for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois", as amended. (1976 Code §16-
143.11; amd. 1991 Code)
   B.   Pipe Materials: All pipe material used in storm sewer construction,
unless otherwise specified, shall be reinforced concrete pipe conforming to
designation C 76, classes I, II, III, IV or V or SDR-26 (polyvinyl chloride)
PVC pipe conforming to ASTM D 3034, type PSM for sizes six inches (6") to
fifteen inches (15") and ASTM F-679-89 for sizes eighteen inches (18") to
thirty six inches (36"), or class 52 cement lined ductile iron pipe conforming
to ANSI A 21.51 (AWWA C-151). (Ord. 2002-23, 5-23-2002)
   C.   Storm Sewer Manholes:
      1.   Location: Manholes shall be located at the junction of two (2) storm
sewer pipes or at any change in grade, alignment or size of pipe. The maximum
spacing of manholes shall be three hundred feet (300') or as approved by the
village engineer. (1976 Code §16-143.31)
      2.   Construction And Installation Regulations: Manholes for storm sewers
shall have a minimum inside diameter of forty eight inches (48") and be
constructed of precast portland cement concrete units in accordance with
section 612 of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction",
as amended. Manholes for storm sewers shall be type A Illinois department of
transportation standard 1527-0 constructed of precast reinforced concrete
sections in accordance with section 512 of the "Standard Specifications for
Road and Bridge Construction", as amended, and installed in accordance with the
applicable portion of section 600 of the standard specifications. (1976 Code
§16-143.30)
   D.   Catch Basins:
      1.   Location: Catch basins shall be located prior to the introduction of
any surface water into storm sewer systems. Catch basins shall be utilized in
all locations where it is intended to direct surface flow into the storm sewer
system. Under no circumstances will any connections be made to the storm sewer
system prior to routing surface water collected through a catch basin. The
village engineer shall recommend the placement of all catch basins within a
storm sewer system. (1976 Code §16-143.41)
      2.   Construction, Installation: Catch basins utilized for storm sewer
systems shall be type A Illinois department of transportation standard 1514-
9 constructed of precast, reinforced concrete sections in accordance with
section 612 of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction",
as amended, and installed in accordance with the applicable portions of section
600 of the standard specifications. (1976 Code §16-143.40)
   E.   Inlets:
      1.   Location: Inlets will be located as necessary to collect surface
water that is to be directed into the storm sewer system. In all cases, inlets
shall be required to be connected to catch basins prior to allowing water
collected by it to be transmitted into the storm sewer system. Inlets may be
connected to inlets prior to their connection to catch basins, but in no case
will more than one inlet be allowed to be connected to another. Maximum amount
of inlets allowed to be connected to said catch basins shall be three (3).
(1976 Code §16-143.51)
      2.   Construction Regulations: Inlets utilized for storm sewer systems
shall be type A Illinois department of transportation standard 1683-
4 constructed of precast, reinforced concrete sections in accordance with
section 612 of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction",
as amended, and installed in accordance with the applicable portions of section
600 of the standard specifications. (1976 Code §16-143.50)
   F.   Frames And Grates: Frames and grates utilized for storm sewer systems
shall be of the respective types as specified by the Illinois department of
transportation highway standards book, as amended. All frames and grates shall
be constructed in accordance with section 614 of the "Standard Specifications
for Road and Bridge Construction", as amended. Closed lids to be furnished
shall be imprinted with the words "Storm Sewer" on the cover in raised letters.
All frames shall be adjusted to proper grade utilizing reinforced precast
concrete rings; brick or concrete blocks will not be allowed. Adjusting rings
shall be securely sealed to the manhole catch basin or inlet using resilient,
flexible, nonhardening, preformed bituminous mastic material (RAM-NEK, or
approved equal) or of a material approved by the village engineer. Up to twelve
inches (12") of adjusting rings may be installed on a given structure; however,
no more than one 2-inch adjusting ring shall be used. (1976 Code §16-143.60)
10-5A-4: STREET LIGHTING STANDARDS:
   A.   Design: Street lighting shall be designed in accordance with the
requirements of the "American National Standard Practice For Roadway Lighting",
latest edition.
      1.   Luminaire Mounting Heights:
 
Residential     7 meters 23.0 feet
Industrial      9 meters 29.5 feet
Commercial      9 meters 29.5 feet
Office district 9 meters 29.5 feet
 
      2.   Luminaire Type And Power Output: An equivalent light emitting diode
(LED) luminaire of a type and manufacturer may be selected at the sole
discretion of the village engineer in lieu of the high pressure sodium
luminaire. The light source may not exceed four thousand Kelvin (4000 K) for
new or replacement lighting installations.
 
Zone            Luminaire                  Wattage   Alternative Luminaire Type
Residential     High pressure sodium vapor 100 watts LED
Industrial      High pressure sodium vapor 250 watts LED
Commercial      High pressure sodium vapor 250 watts LED
Office district High pressure sodium vapor 250 watts LED
 
      3.   Luminaire Spacing:
         a.   Residential: 35 LF roadway and less
       200 LF on center
       Staggered spacing
         b.   Industrial:
            (1)   35 LF roadway and less
       200 LF on center
       Staggered spacing
            (2)   Greater than 35 LF roadway width
       200 LF on center
       Opposite spacing
         c.   Commercial:
            (1)   35 LF roadway and less
       200 LF on center
       Staggered spacing
            (2)   Greater than 35 LF roadway width
       200 LF on center
       Opposite spacing
         d.   Office district:
            (1)   35 LF roadway and less
       200 LF on center
       Staggered spacing
            (2)   Greater than 35 LF roadway width
       200 LF on center
       Opposite spacing
      4.   Circuiting: 120/240 volt, single phase, sixty (60) cycle, 3-wire
multiple circuits shall be provided.
   B.   Materials: All materials shall meet the requirements of the appropriate
IES NEMA standard and shall be approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories.
   C.   Standards: Standards shall be concrete, or as otherwise specified by
the village engineer. Along roadways with speeds in excess of thirty (30) miles
per hour breakaway installations may be recommended. Standards shall be
designed to withstand a wind velocity of at least one hundred (100) miles per
hour. Standards shall be equipped as follows:
      1.   A wiring handhold with a heat treated aluminum alloy door above
finished grade and tamperproof screws.
      2.   An aluminum tenon two and three-eighths inches (23/8") OD by six
inches (6") in length.
      3.   A festoon lighting outlet for standards installed in industrial,
commercial and office districts.
      4.   For residential purposes, the standard is AMERON (Centrecon series
M) MEQ-7-512A-T4. For industrial, commercial and office districts, the standard
is AMERON (Centrecon series M) MEQ-9.4-512A-T4.
      5.   Concrete standards are to be butt-base and shall be located a
minimum of three feet (3') behind back of curb. Where curbs do not exist, the
standard shall be located at the direction of the village engineer.
   D.   Alternative Standards: Standards shall be round tapered aluminum with
mast arm. Along roadways with speeds in excess of thirty (30) miles per hour
breakaway installations may be recommended. Standards shall be designed to
withstand a wind velocity of at least one hundred (100) miles per hour.
Standards shall be equipped as follows:
      1.   The standard Valmont Industries or approved equal height for
residential shall be twenty three feet (23') above grade and for industrial,
commercial and office districts shall be thirty feet (30') above grade. The
Davit or approved equal mast arm span shall be eight feet (8') for all
standards.
      2.   The standard shall be dark bronze in color and include base nut
covers.
      3.   A four inch by six inch (4" x 6") nominal aluminum wiring handhole
with reinforcement frame and flush fitting aluminum door attached with steel
core nylon screws.
      4.   The standard shall be located a minimum of three feet (3') behind
back of curb. Where curbs do not exist, the standard shall be located at the
direction of the village engineer.
      5.   Foundations shall be helix or reinforcement concrete to be
determined and specified by the village engineer.
   E.   Luminaries And Mast Arms: Luminaries shall be high pressure sodium
units suitable for use on multiple 120/240 volts circuit containing an internal
constant wattage regulator type ballast. Luminaries shall be provided with mast
arms eight inches (8") in length attached to a slip fitter with heat treated
aluminum alloy castings and stainless steel screws capable of being attached to
a tenon type mount of the size indicated in subsection C of this section. In
addition, all luminaries shall provide type II and type III light distribution
and have an adjustable lamp socket.
      1.   Housing: Housing shall be constructed of one-eighth inch (1/8")
extruded aluminum sides and sheet aluminum top sealed with fasteners and RTV
silicone sealant.
      2.   Lens And Door Frame: Door frame shall be of extruded aluminum. Lens
shall be clear flat tempered herculite glass with gasketing that prevents any
metal to glass contact. Door frame assembly shall enclose the entire bottom of
the luminaire. Door frame assembly shall be retained by quarter turn fasteners
with black penetrate finish. A spring steel drop hinge shall allow for removal
of the entire door frame assembly. An extruded silicone rubber gasket shall
provide seal between door frame assembly and housing. An external auxiliary
vandal shield, one-eighth inch (1/8") thick polycarbonate must be provided.
      3.   Optical System: Optical system shall be composed of two (2) polished
alzak aluminum reflectors which shall allow for filed adjustments to desired
light distribution. Each reflector to be individually adjustable to allow for
combinations of light distribution, type II right beam and type III left beam.
System must be easily repositioned without the use of tools.
      4.   Ballast: All components shall be mounted on an inner vertically
sliding tray with a cover and retained in the closed position by three (3)
quarter turn fasteners. A quick disconnect electrical device must be provided.
Ballast to be high pressure sodium type for one hundred (100) or two hundred
fifty (250) watt lamp.
      5.   Mounting: Each luminaire is to be provided with two (2) mounting
bolts which extend from inside the rear of the unit through the eight inch (8")
extruded arm, also provided.
      6.   Finish: Dark bronze anodized finish, architectural class 1, AA-442,
with the integral anadic color, must be provided.
For residential purposes, the standard is Cooper lighting RCL-10-S-P-W-3D-4-V-
OA1064-MA1017. For industrial, commercial and office districts the standard is
Cooper lighting RCL-25-S-P-W-3D-4-V-OA1064-MA1017.
   F.   Alternative Luminaire: Luminaries shall be light emitting diode (LED)
units suitable for use on multiple 120/240 volts circuit.
      1.   For residential, industrial, commercial and office districts the
luminaire shall be a Cobrahead style GE Evolve LED series or approved equal.
      2.   Finish: Finish shall be black polyester powder painted.
   G.   Conductors: Wires shall be copper, softened annealed ASTM specification
B-3, national electrical code 1  or equal. The wire shall have six hundred
(600) volt insulation THW and shall be rated underwriters type use. The minimum
size of the conductor shall be number 8 AWG copper or equal. The wiring system
shall be a parallel system with a minimum of three (3) insulated conductors.
   H.   Conduit: All underground wiring shall be encased in polyethylene
uniduct or shall be installed in conduit of one inch (1") minimum diameter.
Conduit may be either standard hot dipped galvanized or high density
polyethylene or approved equal.
   I.   Construction Work: All work shall conform to all applicable sections of
the national electrical code 2 . All standards shall be installed in an
excavation, a minimum of ten inches (10") greater in diameter than the pole
butt and six inches (6") greater in depth than the embedded pole length. Six
inches (6") of backfill shall be compacted in the excavation prior to the
placement of the pole. After placing the pole and plumbing, screenings shall be
utilized to backfill the excavation and shall be compacted at no more than nine
inch (9") intervals up to the bottom of the cable entrances. Subsequent to the
installation of the required cable facilities, the remaining portion of the
excavation will be backfilled with screenings and compacted at no more than
nine inch (9") intervals to a point two inches (2") above the final ground
line. The components of the complete assembly shall be erected plumb with the
mast arm projecting perpendicular to the curb. The use of two inch (2") rigid
conduit with bushings will be required under all public sidewalk and street
crossings.
   J.   Electric Service: The subdivider shall arrange with the local electric
power company for electric service and shall bear the expense of any charges by
the power company to furnish the service connection(s). The location of all
service connections and the control equipment shall be shown on the drawings.
   K.   Controls: All control equipment shall be located in accordance with the
requirements of the local electric power company. All control equipment shall
be mounted within a weatherproof cabinet. The control cabinet shall be
constructed of aluminum or steel coated with an approved epoxy paint; have a
hinged, gasketed door with a flush mounted keyed lock and the words "street
lighting controls" cast on the door and shall have a screened vent weatherproof
opening; and shall have an adapter for mounting on a four and one-half inch
(41/2") OD tubular steel post. A concrete foundation with a ground rod shall
support a cast iron base for the post. The cabinet shall contain a main service
breaker, multiple relay, a light panel with circuit breakers, and a terminal
block for outgoing circuit wires. Residential lighting shall be so designed
that the maximum wattage from a given service can be obtained without metering
of the circuit. (A photoelectric control compatible with the multiple relay
shall be mounted on the top of the nearest streetlight pole and connected to
the control cabinet with number 12 copper wire.) (Ord. 2015-11, 3-5-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 8, chapter 1, article E of this code.
2 1. See title 8, chapter 1, article E of this code.
10-5A-5: STREET PAVEMENTS AND CURB AND GUTTER CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
The standards and requirements found in this section are for the materials and
construction of street pavements and curbs and gutters within the village.
   A.   Pavement Design:
      1.   All streets shall be constructed in accordance with the material
installation and testing requirements of the Illinois department of
transportation (IDOT) "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", "Interim Special Provisions (ISP)", and the "Supplement
Specifications" and "Recurring Special Provisions", latest edition including
supplements ("IDOT's specifications").
      2.   Pavement structures shall be based on the following minimum
structural numbers and/or pavement design:
Classification  Structural Number And Pavement Design    
Classification                        Structural Number And Pavement Design    
                                         
Residential local streets            3.35 12" aggregate type B CA-6
                                        3" CI. I bituminous binder course
                                        2" CI. I bituminous surface course
                                         
Residential collector street         4.22 12" aggregate type B CA-6
                                        4" BAM (M.S.1500)
                                        2" CI. I bituminous binder course
                                        2" CI. I bituminous surface course
                                         
Industrial, commercial and arterial  4.82 12" aggregate type B CA-6
street
                                        6" BAM (M.S.1500)
                                        2.5" CI. I bituminous binder course
                                        2" CI. I bituminous surface course
 
      3.   Complete pavement designs for roadways in commercial and industrial
areas shall be provided to the village for review and approval.
      4.   The subgrade soil shall be tested by a professional geotechnical
engineer at the developer's expense and shall have a minimum designated
Illinois bearing ratio (IBR) equal to three (3).
      5.   A soil investigation report shall be provided to the village to
verify the IBR value. Pavement structures with subgrade soil having an IBR
value less than three (3) shall have an increased pavement structure as
necessary to carry the design traffic loading.
   B.   Material Specifications:
      1.   All street construction materials shall be in accordance with IDOT's
specifications.
      2.   Aggregate for subbase course shall be uniformly graded and shall
conform to CA-6, grade 8.
      3.   Bituminous aggregate mixture (BAM), bituminous concrete binder and
bituminous concrete surface course shall conform to IDOT's specifications.
         a.   Bituminous aggregate mixture (M.S.=1500).
         b.   Binder course shall be hot mix asphalt IL-19.0. N50.
         c.   Surface course shall be hot mix asphalt mix "C" N50.
      4.   The tack coat (prime) shall be cut back asphalt, grade RC-70. (Ord.
2008-50, 11-20-2008)
   C.   Installation: Prior to beginning construction, the director of public
works or his designee shall be given forty eight (48) hours' notice of the
intended time of starting work. (Ord. 2008-50, 11-20-2008; amd. Ord. 2010-29,
5-20-2010)
      1.   Dust/Debris Control:
         a.   Traveled roadways shall be kept clean of mud/debris. All dirt and
debris tracked onto existing roads shall be promptly removed in accordance with
this code.
         b.   The developer or contractor shall follow all necessary procedures
to control dust on the project site at all times. Methods shall include, but
are not limited to, stone haul roads and a water application truck.
      2.   Subgrade: The subgrade shall be graded and rolled to provide uniform
density and shall comply with the profile and cross sections contained in the
approved drawings.
         a.   The subgrade shall be proof rolled in the presence of a
professional geotechnical engineer with a fully loaded tri- axle dump truck or
similar equipment prior to the placement of any fill materials or subbase
course. Maximum allowable deflection shall be one-fourth inch (1/4").
         b.   The subgrade shall be prepared in accordance with IDOT's
specifications.
      3.   Subbase Course: The subbase shall be prepared in accordance with
IDOT's specifications.
         a.   The subbase shall be proof rolled in the presence of a
professional material testing service with a fully loaded tri- axle dump truck
or similar equipment prior to the placement of any fill materials or subbase
course. Maximum allowable deflection shall be one-fourth inch (1/4").
         b.   The finished subbase course shall be fine graded in preparation
for paving.
      4.   Prime Coat: Prime coat shall be applied to the base course according
to IDOT's specifications.
      5.   Asphalt Paving: The work shall be in accordance with IDOT's
specifications.
         a.   The surface course shall not be applied until the binder course
has weathered through one (1) winter season.
         b.   All cracks greater than one-fourth inch (1/4") in the binder
course shall be sealed prior to application of the surface course.
         c.   Joints shall be lapped from binder course to surface course.
         d.   Tack (prime) coat shall be applied to the binder course prior to
the construction of the surface course to ensure proper bond. Tack coat shall
be applied at a rate of ten- hundredths (0.10) gallon per square yard.
   D.   Testing And Approval:
      1.   All subgrade and base course shall be proof rolled in the presence
of a professional geotechnical engineer with a fully loaded tri-axle dump truck
or similar equipment prior to placement of upper material layers or curb and
gutter.
      2.   Maximum allowable deflection shall be one-fourth inch (1/4").
      3.   The density of the binder course and the surface course shall be
measured either by nuclear test methods or from cores obtained by a
professional testing service arranged by and at the expense of the developer,
and shall meet the requirements of IDOT's specifications.
      4.   All testing shall be in accordance with IDOT's specifications, and
shall be arranged by and at the expense and responsibility of the developer.
Complete written test reports shall be submitted to the Village Engineer for
approval.
   E.   Concrete Curb, Gutter And Median:
      1.   All curbs shall be barrier type, six inches (6") in height. The
concrete curb, gutter and median shall be constructed in accordance with the
material installation and testing requirements of IDOT's specifications.
      2.   Curbs at driveway aprons shall be cast as depressed curbs where
driveway locations exist or are known, or neatly saw cut (by professional curb
saw cutting equipment) for a depressed curb. (Ord. 2008-50, 11-20-2008)
      3.   The top of all curbs shall be stamped, while the concrete is curing
to prevent damage to the integrity of the concrete, with an "S" at all sanitary
service crossings and shall be stamped with a "W" at all water service
crossings. (Ord. 2017-58, 10-5-2017)
10-5A-6: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
The standards and specifications enumerated in this section for materials and
construction pertain to sidewalk construction within the village. (1976 Code
§16-147.10)
   A.   Concrete Sidewalk: The sidewalk shall be of Portland cement concrete
constructed on a prepared subgrade with various joints as shown in the standard
and subscribed herein. (1976 Code §16-147.20)
      1.   Materials: The materials used to arrive at an acceptable concrete
mixture such as Portland cement, fine and coarse aggregates and water shall
conform with the quality requirements as enumerated in appropriate articles of
section 700, Materials, in the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", adopted October 1979, by the Illinois department of
transportation. (1976 Code §16-147.40)
      2.   Quality Of Mix: Concrete for sidewalks and sidewalk aprons shall be
composed of Portland cement; clean coarse aggregate; clean, sharp sand for fine
aggregate; and only clean potable water shall be used in mixing the concrete.
The Portland cement concrete shall have an air entrainment of five percent (5%)
to seven percent (7%) of the volume, and the mix shall be six (6) bags of
cement.
The concrete mix shall have a compressive strength of not less than three
thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds per square inch after twenty eight (28)
days' curing. The slump shall not be greater than three inches (3").
Air-entraining agents shall have proven compatibility with all local concrete
materials, including cement, and shall be capable of providing in the concrete
the required air contents and an air-void system known to produce durable,
scale-resistant concrete.
Admixtures other than air-entraining agents shall not be used until trial mixes
with job materials have shown them to be compatible at job temperatures. Trial
mixes must also show that desired properties will be imparted to the fresh
concrete without any subsequent loss of strength or durability in the hardened
concrete. (1976 Code §16-147.43)
      3.   Mixing Concrete: Concrete shall be mixed in a batch mixer for not
less than one and one-half (11/2) minutes after all the materials are in the
mixer drum and until there is a uniform distribution of the materials and the
mass is uniform in color and is homogeneous. Small amounts of concrete may be
mixed by hand, subject to approval by the village engineer.
Concrete from a central plant or mixed in transit mixer trucks may be used if
it complies with these specifications. There shall be free access at all times
to the batching and mixing plant for sampling of all materials. Concrete shall
be delivered in watertight containers which will not permit segregation of the
materials. When delivered, the concrete shall be uniform throughout the mass.
All concrete used is subject to the necessary tests as to slump, strength,
etc., at the discretion of the village engineer and all unsuitable materials
used shall be removed and replaced at the contractor's expense. (1976 Code §16-
147.44)
   B.   Sidewalk Thickness: The concrete shall be on one course minimum
thickness of four inches (4") constructed on the prepared subgrade, six inches
(6") where vehicle crossing is permitted on the sidewalk. (1976 Code §16-
147.21)
   C.   Subgrade Preparation: The subgrade shall consist of four inches (4") of
either limestone screening, stone or granular material which shall be tamped or
rolled until thoroughly compacted and shall be constructed true to grade and
cross- section. Until the subgrade and forms are approved by the Village
Engineer, no concrete shall be poured. All topsoil shall be removed for its
full depth and for a width not less than six inches (6") wider on each side
than the width of the sidewalk. Excess cut, to remove topsoil, shall be
replaced with compacted stone. Tree roots exposed by excavation should be cut
off at least three inches (3") outside of the new walk and three inches (3")
below subgrade. Subgrade shall be tamped or rolled until thoroughly compacted
and shall be true to grade and cross-section for the bottom of the sidewalk.
(1976 Code §16-147.31)
   D.   Forms:
      1.   Side forms shall be of lumber of not less than one inch (1") nominal
thickness or of steel of equal rigidity. They shall be four inches (4") or six
inches (6") in depth. They shall be held securely in place by stakes or braces,
with the top edges true to line and grade. The forms for the sidewalks shall be
so set that the slab will have a fall of one-quarter inch (1/4") vertical to
one foot (1') horizontal from the edge farthest from the street toward the edge
nearest the street. Forms for the sidewalk aprons shall be so set that the slab
will have a uniform fall between the sidewalk proper and the curb grade. Forms
shall be oiled before concrete is placed. (1976 Code §16-147.41)
      2.   Forms shall remain undisturbed for a minimum of twelve (12) hours
and until the concrete has attained sufficient strength to sustain its own
weight in addition to any temporary and permanent loads that may be placed upon
it. (1976 Code §16-147.42)
   E.   Placing and Finishing Concrete: Subgrade and forms shall be moistened
just before concrete is placed. Concrete shall be placed in successive batches
for the entire width of the slope, struck off from one-half inches (1/2") to
three-quarter inches (3/4") higher than the finished slope, tamped until all
voids are removed and free mortar appears on the surface, thoroughly spaded
along the edges, struck off to the true grade and finished to a true and even
surface with floats and trowels. Final troweling shall be done with a steel
trowel leaving a smooth, even surface, but excessive working avoided. After the
water sheen has disappeared, the surface shall be given a final broom finish.
In no case shall dry cement and/or sand be applied to dry up the surface. The
broom shall be drawn across the sidewalk at right angles to edges of the walk,
with adjacent strokes slightly overlapping, producing a uniform, slightly
roughened surface with parallel broom marks.
The surface shall be divided by grooves constructed at right angles to the
center line of the sidewalk. These grooves shall extend to one-fourth (1/4) the
depth of the sidewalk, with the width being neither more than one- fourth (1/4)
nor less than one-eighth (1/8). The groove shall be edged with the edging tool
having a one-fourth inch (1/4") radius. The walk shall be grooved at five foot
(5') intervals.
Concrete, when placed in the forms, shall have a temperature of not less than
seventy degrees (70°) Fahrenheit nor more than one hundred degrees (100°)
Fahrenheit. It is desirable that freshly placed concrete shall be maintained at
a temperature of fifty to eighty degrees (50° - 80°) Fahrenheit for a period of
not less than four (4) days after placing. (1976 Code §16-147.50)
   F.   Expansion Joints: Expansion joints of the thickness specified below
shall consist of preformed joint filler. The top of the joint shall be placed
one-fourth inch (1/4") below the surface of the sidewalk.
      1.   One-Half Inch (1/2") Thick Expansion Joints: Expansion joints one-
half inch (1/2") thick shall be placed between the sidewalk and all structures
such as light standards, traffic light standards and traffic poles, which
extend through the sidewalk.
      2.   Three-Fourths Inch (3/4") Thick Expansion Joints: Expansion joints
three-fourths inch (3/4") thick shall be placed at intervals of forty five feet
(45') in the sidewalks or wherever it is practical.
Expansion joints shall be placed at locations where sidewalk abuts existing
building, driveway pavement, curb, sidewalk at grade changes and at locations
where it is deemed necessary by the Village Engineer. (1976 Code §16-147.60)
   G.   Curing: The surface of the newly laid pavement shall be cured in a
manner as called for in section 625 of the "Standard Specifications for Road
and Bridge Construction", adopted October 1979, and satisfactory to the Village
Engineer. The material used for curing shall conform with the material
specifications per article 718.04 of the specifications noted above.
Special attention is hereby called for the protection of fresh concrete against
cold weather which could follow the measures discussed in article 625.06 of
section 625 of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction",
adopted October 1979, in the State of Illinois.
A minimum of five (5) days' curing period, two (2) days for high early strength
concrete, is required. All exposed surfaces shall be protected against wash by
rain. (1976 Code §16-147.70)
   H.   Excavations: The excavation shall consist of removing all topsoil to a
width of one foot (1') on either side of the sidewalk, cutting or filling to
within six inches (6") of the top of the sidewalk and compacting all fill to a
minimum of ninety percent (90%) Standard Proctor Density, AASHO, Designation
T9. (1976 Code §16-147.30)
After the concrete has been cured, the spaces along the edges of the sidewalk
shall be backfilled to the required level with approved material. The material
shall then be compacted until firm, and the surface neatly graded to receive
grass cover. (1976 Code §16-147.80)
   I.   Protection of New Sidewalk: Vehicles shall be kept off of concrete for
seven (7) days. (1976 Code §16-147.90)
10-5A-7: WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
   A.   Scope; Specifications: The standards and requirements found in this
Section are for materials and construction of water mains within the Village.
Specifications references made herein for manufactured materials such as pipe,
hydrants, valves and fittings refer to designations for American Water Works
Association (AWWA) or to the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).
Nothing herein shall constitute or imply an endorsement by the Village of any
one material over another. (1976 Code §16-146.10)
These specifications cover pipe fittings and accessory items normally used for
water distribution systems. Special considerations will be covered in the plans
and special provisions. Water distribution systems shall be constructed in
accordance with "Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction
in Illinois", as amended. (1976 Code §16-146.11)
   B.   Fire Flow Requirements: The fire flows listed below are the minimum
allowed in the Village. The building construction, on- site fire protection
systems and the hazard of contents will be used in determining the exact flow
requirements within the minimum range. The required fire flow is to be
calculated using a residual pressure of twenty (20) pounds per square inch.
                                                     GPM
Single-family                                          
detached residential homes                          
                                                      1,000–1,500
Town, row or cluster housing                       1,500–2,000
Apartment-type buildings                           3,000–4,000
Manufacturing                                         3,000–5,000
and storage   
Institutional                                      3,000–4,000
Business and                                          2,500–3,500
office uses   
Commercial, mercantile or regional shopping center  3,000–5,000
 
(1976 Code §16-146.12)
   C.   Pipe Specifications:
      1.   Ductile Cast Iron Pipe: Ductile cast iron pipe shall conform to ANSI
Specification A21.51 or AWWA C151, Class 2 (52) thickness designation. Casting,
marking, testing, etc., shall be provided in accordance with applicable ANSI or
AWWA standards. (1976 Code §16-146.21)
      2.   Lining: Double thickness cement lining shall be included in
accordance with ANSI-4 (AWWA-104). (1976 Code §16-146.22)
      3.   Pipe Fittings: All cast iron fittings shall conform to the latest
ANSI Specifications A21.10 for short body, cast iron fittings twelve inches
(12") and less, and AWWA C110 for fittings fourteen inches (14") and larger.
Lining or other special items shall be specified in special provisions. (1976
Code §16-146.23)
   D.   Installation of Pipe:
      1.   General Requirements: Pipe shall be installed in accordance with the
manufacturer's specifications and instructions for installing the type of pipe
used. (1976 Code §16-146.41)
      2.   Excavation and Backfill: Excavation and backfill for water mains
shall conform to the provisions as required in other sections of the "Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois". (1976 Code
§16-146.42)
      3.   Depth of Pipe Cover: Unless otherwise shown on the plans or
indicated in the special provisions, all pipe shall be laid to a minimum depth
of five feet (5') measured from the existing ground surface or established
grade to the top of the barrel of the pipe. In areas subject to subsequent
excavation or fill, the mains shall be laid to grades shown on the plans. (1976
Code §16-146.43)
      4.   Pipe Foundations: The trench, unless otherwise specified, shall have
a flat bottom conforming to the grade to which the pipe is laid. The pipe shall
be laid on an aggregate base a minimum of four inches (4") thick and such that
the barrel of the pipe will have a bearing to its full length. Earthen dams
constructed to obstruct the passage of ground water shall be placed on one
hundred foot (100') intervals. Bell holes shall be excavated for joints. Any
part of the trench excavated below grade shall be corrected with an approved
material and thoroughly compacted. (1976 Code §16-146.44)
      5.   Dewatering of Trench: Where water is encountered in the trench, it
shall be removed during pipe laying and jointing operations. Provisions shall
be made to prevent floating of the pipe. Trench water shall not be allowed to
enter the pipe at any time. (1976 Code §16-146.45)
      6.   Handling of Pipe:
         a.   All types of pipe shall be handled in such a manner as will
prevent damage to the pipe or coating. Damaged pipe, specials and other
accessories shall be rejected and replaced to the satisfaction of the Village
Engineer. The methods of handling shall be corrected to prevent further damage
when called to the attention of the contractor.
         b.   Threaded pipe ends shall be protected by couplings or other means
until laid.
         c.   The pipe ends shall be protected by the contractor for defects
while suspended above grade.
         d.   Dirt or other foreign material shall be prevented from entering
the pipe or pipe joint during handling or laying operations and any pipe or
fitting that has been installed with dirt or foreign material in it shall be
removed, cleaned and relaid. At times when pipe laying is not in progress, the
open ends of the pipe shall be closed by a watertight plug or by other means
approved by the Village Engineer to ensure absolute cleanliness inside the
pipe. (1976 Code §16-146.46)
      7.   Laying of Pipe on Curves:
         a.   Long radius curves, either horizontal or vertical, may be laid
with standard pipe by deflections at the joints. If the pipe is shown curved on
the plans and no special fittings are shown, the contractor can assume that the
curves can be made by deflection of the joints with standard lengths of pipe.
If shorter lengths are required, the plan will indicate maximum lengths that
can be used.
         b.   Where field conditions require deflection of curves not
anticipated by the plans, the Village Engineer will approve the methods to be
used.
         c.   Maximum deflections at pipe joints and laying radius for various
pipe lengths are found in the following standards:
 
Ductile cast iron pipe mechanical joints  AWWA C-600
Ductile iron pipe push-on joints         AWWA C-600
 
         d.   When rubber gasketed pipe is laid on a curve, the pipe shall be
jointed in a straight alignment. Trenches shall be made wider on curves for
this purpose. (1976 Code §16-146.51)
      8.   Joints:
         a.   Joints for Ductile Cast Iron Pipe: Joints for cast iron pipe
shall consist of one of the two (2) following types unless otherwise provided
in the special provisions:
            (1)   Mechanical joints.
            (2)   Push-on rubber gasket joints. (1976 Code §16-146.52)
         b.   Jointing Mechanical Joint Pipe:
            (1)   The outside of the spigot and inside of the bell of
mechanical joint pipe shall be thoroughly cleaned to remove all foreign matter
from the joint. The cast iron gland shall then be slipped on the spigot end of
the pipe with the lip extension of the gland toward the socket or bell end. The
rubber gasket shall be placed on the spigot end with the thick edge toward the
gland. The pipe shall be pushed forward to completely seat the spigot end in
the bell. The gasket shall then be pressed into place within the bell, being
careful to have the gasket evenly located around the entire joint. The cast
iron gland shall then be moved along the pipe into position and bolted.
            (2)   Nuts spaced one hundred eighty degrees (180o) shall be
tightened alternately to AWWA C-600 standards in order to produce an equal
pressure on all parts of the gland. (1976 Code §16-146.53)
         c.   Jointing Rubber Gasket Joint Pipe (AWWA C-111):
            (1)   The inside of the bell shall be thoroughly cleaned to remove
all foreign matter from the joint. The circular rubber gasket shall be inserted
in the gasket seat provided.
            (2)   A thin film of gasket lubricant shall be applied to inside
surface of the gasket. Gasket lubricant shall be a solution of vegetable soap
or other solution supplied by the pipe manufacturer and approved by the Village
Engineer.
            (3)   The spigot end of the pipe shall be cleaned and entered in
the rubber gasket in the bell, using care to keep the joint from contacting the
ground. The joint shall then be completed by forcing the plain end to the seat
of the bell.
            (4)   All pipe shall be furnished with a depth mark to assure that
the spigot end is inserted to the full depth of the joints.
            (5)   Field-cut pipe lengths shall be bevelled to avoid damage to
the gasket and facilitate making the joint. (1976 Code §16-146.54)
         d.   Bell and Spigot Pipe with Lead Joints: This type allowed only
when required by special conditions. Details of such installations shall be
specifically approved by the Village Engineer. (1976 Code §16-146.55)
         e.   Thrust Blocking:
            (1)   Blocking to prevent movement of lines under pressure at
bends, tees, caps, valves and hydrants shall be Portland cement concrete, a
minimum of twelve inches (12") thick, placed between solid ground and the
fittings and shall be anchored in such a manner that pipe and fitting joints
will be accessible for repairs.
            (2)   All bends of eleven and one-quarter degrees (111/4o) or
greater, and all tees and plugs shall be thrust protected to prevent movement
of the lines under pressure. (1976 Code §16-146.56)
   E.   Protection of Water Mains: Wherever pipelines designated to carry
potable water supplies cross or are laid less than ten feet (10') horizontally
from existing or proposed drain or sewer lines, or cross house sewers, storm
drains or sanitary sewers, special precautions shall be taken.
In addition, this subsection covers material specifications and installation
procedures for polyethylene encasements to the underground installations of
gray and ductile cast iron pipe. A corrosive soil test shall be performed at
the discretion of the Village Engineer. (1976 Code §16-146.31)
      1.   Parallel Water Mains and Sewers:
         a.   Should conditions prevail which prevent a lateral separation of
ten feet (10'), the pipeline may be laid closer than ten feet (10') to a storm
or sanitary sewer, provided the main is laid in a separate trench and at such
an elevation that the bottom of the water main is at least eighteen inches
(18") above the top of the sewer.
         b.   If it is impossible to obtain a horizontal separation of at least
ten feet (10') and a vertical separation of at least eighteen inches (18") as
stipulated above, the sewer shall be constructed or reconstructed of mechanical
or slip-on joint ductile iron pipe, or concrete pressure pipes specified
herein, and be pressure tested to assure watertightness. (1976 Code §16-146.32)
      2.   Water Main Crossing Sewers:
         a.   Whenever the pipeline crosses house sewers, storm drains or
sanitary sewers, the pipeline shall be laid at such an elevation that the
bottom of the line is at least eighteen inches (18") above the top of the drain
or sewer. This minimum vertical separation shall be maintained for that portion
of the pipeline located within ten feet (10') horizontally, or any sewer or
drain crossed; said ten feet (10') to be measured from the center line of the
drain or sewer normal to the pipeline center line.
         b.   Under conditions that the minimum vertical separation set forth
in the above paragraph cannot be maintained or it is necessary for the pipeline
to pass under a sewer or drain, the water main shall be centered so that joints
will be equi- distant from the sewer and as remote therefrom as possible.
         c.   Where a pipeline must cross under a sewer, in addition to above,
a vertical separation of eighteen inches (18") between the bottom of the sewer
and the top of the water main shall be maintained. The sewer shall be supported
to prevent its settling as directed by the Village Engineer. (1976 Code §16-
146.33)
      3.   Corrosion Protection:
         a.   Materials: The materials used for the job shall be in accordance
with the Table I as follows:
   TABLE I
   RAW MATERIAL USED TO MANUFACTURE
   POLYETHYLENE FILM

(1976 Code §16-146.340)
         b.   Thickness: Polyethylene film shall have a minimum nominal
thickness of 0.008 inch (8 mils). The minus tolerance on thickness shall not
exceed ten percent (10%) of the normal thickness. (1976 Code §16-146.341)
         c.   Tube Size or Sheet Width: Tube or sheet size for each pipe
diameter shall be listed on the following table:
   Minimum Polyethylene Width Inch
